metaDescription: A weekend with 30 women and 10 cars: An Aston Martin DB9 and several more prosaic vehicles were up for the driving at the third annual Heels & Wheels event in Oregon. Read about it on JeanKnowsCars.com.

contributors.bio: When people ask me how I started writing about cars, I tell them I'm from Detroit. I tell them about my father, who was a Chrysler engineer, and the crazy cars he would bring home to test drive. But before I discovered the glamorous life of an automotive journalist, I was a writer living in the Motor City, covering music and art in the Nineties. Things changed when I became curious about the industry that made the city tick and interned at AutoWeek magazine. I moved to New York City in 2003, where I’ve worked as a freelance writer for almost a decade. I’ve written for more than 100 magazines, newspapers, and websites, including the New York Times, Rolling Stone, Forbes, Jay-z’s Life and Times, Vibe, Automobile Magazine, AutoWeek and the Detroit Free Press. I finished an MFA in creative writing at the New School this year. I live with two car buffs, Lee Quiñones and our four-year-old son, who both think what I do is pretty cool.

pageElements.text: As soon as I arrived in Portland, Oregon, for the third annual Heels and Wheels event, I jumped in a car and headed southeast. Cold rain obscured my view of Mount Hood from the windshield of the Aston Martin DB9. I wondered if the foul weather was going to put a damper on the event that brings together thirty women in the automotive industry to focus on car coverage for and by women. For the record, I was impressed with the way the DB9 handled the wet roads, although I confess that my knuckles were pale from gripping the wheel through the sharp bends. But suddenly, the landscape shifted dramatically, and I was cruising along smooth, dry roads in the Oregon desert, dotted by a backdrop of snow-capped mountains. At last, the accelerator and I were one as the driving euphoria kicked in, the scenery vast in the foreground. A caravan of women followed me onto the road, and suddenly I knew that Heels and Wheels was going to be fun.

I pulled into a rest stop tucked within the boundaries of the Warm Springs Indian Reservation off U.S. 26. A man emerged from the rolling stream in waders, fishing pole in hand. We had officially left the city and found our way back to nature. I switched to my next ride, a Mazda 6 sedan, and sped along to my destination in central Oregon, passing by wild horses galloping out yonder. When I arrived at the Brasada Ranch, about twenty minutes from small-town civilization in Bend, I found myself nestled in some kind of wild western paradise. It felt like the right kind of environment for the ladies to kick up their heels.

The setting of Heels and Wheels set the tone of the conversations that occurred over three whirlwind days. We take it for granted that women have been writing about cars for some time now, best embodied by the careers of hall-of-famer Denise McCluggage and one woman who is the editor in chief of an influential automotive magazine and who shapes and defines the way men and women learn about, discover, and see cars. (We see you, Jean.)

Yet, the idea that women read car magazines is still hard to sell to the mainstream. The idea of how to talk about women and cars is still being debated by marketers and car dealers on a daily basis. Yes, we women make most of the decisions about car ownership, but how do we expand the conversation? That’s where programs like Heels and Wheels become important. The auto industry is still overwhelmingly a boys’ club, and far too few women are a part of this conversation. It certainly doesn’t hurt to gather and discuss what car journalism for women means in the era of blogging and social media, and how the playing field is changing as the world around us does, too. Our media niches define us as consumers, whether we read mom blogs or hunt obsessively for automotive deals online. Sometimes our audiences don’t overlap, but often our intentions do. These themes came up in both formal and informal conversation at Brasada Ranch.

Also, as women know, an all-ladies trip is fun. Take women away from their busy lives and give them some open road and the chance to speak freely, and the soundtrack soon turns to laughter. The event organizer, Heels and Wheels CEO Christine Overstreet, opted to make the gathering more experiential than business specific. This format allowed for attendees to focus on their cars of choice. Overstreet invited presenters from AutoPacific, Kelley Blue Book, Jeep, and Cooper Tire to talk about ideas specific to the women’s market. Some of the information was familiar, but I picked up tidbits that were news to me. For instance, did you know that more women than men are licensed to drive (a fun fact presented by the representative from Cooper Tire)? Female representatives from Aston Martin, Buick, Hyundai, Jeep, Kia, Mazda, Mitsubishi, and Volkswagen were in attendance to answer questions about the vehicles available for test drive and to contribute to the conversation. Jeep sent Chris Barman, vehicle line executive for Chrysler’s C and D segments, to talk about the 2014 Jeep Cherokee. She provided detailed explanations on matters of technology and interior options.

For many of the bloggers in attendance, Heels and Wheels was their first chance to test out the new vehicles. The car candy available for testing included a Jeep Grand Cherokee, a Volkswagen Jetta Hybrid, a Mini Roadster, a Hyundai Santa Fe, a Mitsubishi Outlander, a Kia Cadenza, and a Dodge Dart GT, in addition to the DB9, the Mazda 6, and the Cherokee.

After lunch on the second day of the program, Hyundai brought ultramarathon runner Jenn Shelton to speak to the group about her adventures and quests to push her body and mind to the limit. In a rare moment of stillness, the women listened to Shelton read from her memoir. Then it was back out to the expansive desert landscape for more driving, where, under a bright blue sky, everything felt possible.

contributors.bio:
Jean Knows Cars is not just the name of this website; it's a true fact. I have been writing about cars and the car business for more than 30 years, having learned about cars at the kitchen table from my late father, Robert Lienert, who was the editor of Automotive News. At age eighteen, I bought a used car, painted it yellow, installed a toplight and a meter, and joined the Yellow Cab Company in Ann Arbor, Michigan, as an owner/operator. Five years later, I got a job at Chrysler’s test track as a test driver, welder, and mechanic in the impact lab. In 1980, I was hired as a writer at Car and Driver magazine after getting laid off at Chrysler, and in 1985 I left to establish Automobile Magazine with David E. Davis, Jr. I was the magazine’s first Executive Editor, became Editor in Chief in 2000, and added the title of President of Automobile Magazine in 2006.

I’ve been profiled in The New Yorker and have been a guest on the Tonight Show with Jay Leno. I was a guest on the Oprah Winfrey Show, teaching Oprah and her studio audience how to change a tire and to jump a battery. I was Good Morning America’s automotive correspondent from 1994 to 2000 and then did the same thing for the Oxygen network.

 I have won awards for feature writing, car reviews, and my monthly Automobile Magazine column, “Vile Gossip,” including the 2007 Ken Purdy Award for Excellence in Automotive Journalism.  I’m a regular on-air contributor to Fox Business Network; CNBC’s Closing Bell, Squawk Box, Behind the Wheel, and Power Lunch; MSNBC; CBS This Morning and Evening News; and CNN’s American Morning and Headline News. In fact, I would almost call myself a TV slut, but I’m proud to say that I turned Geraldo down.

All of this has taken place in a male-dominated automotive space, where I’m all too frequently the only woman in the room. I know the secret handshake, but JeanKnowsCars.com is going to be a place where you don’t have to. 

I live in the Michigan countryside with my husband, Tim, and the entire food chain. You’re going to get to know my driveway and my dogs really, really well. Just keep reading.

Our Group of Seven driving test could not be completed without lining up the crossovers next to my red barn and stuffing them with as much gear as the women could get into the cargo hold and second-row seat. Panelists took turns loading several items into each vehicle. 
Janet Popper praised the Honda CR-V’s low cargo floor, which simplifies packing and unpacking gear. The Ford Escape won praise from Heather Sager and Anna Eby for ease of installation of the child seat. Jacqueline Dufek gave the Kia Sportage high marks for its iPod holder, located intuitively “right under the volume controls,” while Val Luepke said the Buick Encore felt cramped. 
The video shows the G-7’s efforts in installing a child safety seat and packing a cooler in the back, next to two sets of golf clubs. Watch it! And check out the specs below.

title: 2013 Honda Odyssey Touring Elite
subTitle: Should you buy this minivan?
promoTeaserSmall: I like its style, plus: name anything/anyone it won't fit. But what does the Peanut Gallery think?
promoTeaser: I like its style, plus: name anything/anyone it won't fit. But what does the Peanut Gallery think?
metaDescription: 2013 Honda Odyssey Touring Elite: read our "should you buy it?" review and comments from other staffers up in the Peanut Gallery. It's on JeanKnowsCars.com.

pageElements.text:
The Car:

Price: $44,755 as tested (including destination charge)
Engine: 3.5-liter 24-valve V-6, 248 horsepower
Transmission: Six-speed automatic
Fuel economy: 19 mpg city/28 mpg highway
My favorite standard features: Tilting power moonroof, ultra-wide 16.2-inch rear DVD entertainment system with wireless headsets, integrated sun shades (second and third rows on Touring and Touring Elite; second row only on EX and EX-L models)
Options I can’t live without: Blind spot information system (only on Touring Elite model)
You might also be considering: Chrysler Town & Country Limited, Nissan Quest LE, Toyota Sienna Limited
See more specs in our Car Guide.

What I Think:

Hikers have shoes with Vibram soles; rock climbers have rope and carabiners; attorneys have briefcases; and the well-equipped mom has something like this Honda Odyssey Touring Elite. With this minivan as your base of operations, there is no field trip, no trip to a travel soccer game, no weekend at the beach or commute to school for which you will be unprepared.

And that had better be the case for a vehicle that, in this top-of-the-line form, costs almost $45,000. For that kind of money, I want to feel cosseted in luxury and prepared for anything, and I had both feelings while driving the Odyssey.

You won’t be mistaken about whether you’re in a minivan or not. From the time you pull the door open, you are confronted by acres of plastic, which is only somewhat ameliorated by the leather seating. That cavernous feeling may be foreign to the person who is used to a small, sporty car, but it’s part of the roominess and versatility that a minivan is all about.

Driving it, you are also not mistaken about the size of the thing. You are driving a 4,500-pound, 16.9-foot-long van. Having said that, it accelerates nimbly, handles smoothly, and has light, intuitive steering—although almost too light for my comfort. I was driving across town in this Odyssey when a tremendous rain whipped up, flooding city streets in what was later called a once-in-fifty-year storm. The next day, the Ann Arbor News displayed photos and videos of people kayaking down side streets. I felt absolutely protected inside the Odyssey as I navigated around the city, seeking out the highest-sitting neighborhoods and avoiding the high water. The ability to calmly manage adverse conditions is a great test of any vehicle, and the Odyssey won my trust right then.

Among the can’t-live-without amenities that you’d get used to quickly are a “cool box” below the stereo controls, big enough to keep your Diet Coke and yogurt or a dozen juice boxes nice and cool while you drive; a truly tremendous number of places to plug in and charge (no more fights over the outlet up front; there are two); and the flip-up trash bag ring, solving the constant problem of a trash receptacle that doesn’t roll around on the floor of the van or get tipped over.

The second-row seats roll forward and back into place, making it easy to gain access to the third row. The center seat in that row folds down into a center console for two passengers, eliminating fights about personal space. Don’t worry, they’ll think of something else to argue about!

The Odyssey comes in LX, EX, Touring, and Touring Elite trim levels. The 2014 model has just gone on sale, with pricing for the base model only about $150 higher than its 2013 counterpart, and all models now have a six-speed automatic transmission. (For 2013, only the Touring- and Touring Elite-level Odysseys did.) The Touring Elite model I drove has several features you don’t get on the entry-level model, but the base LX’s price is a reasonable $29,655 for 2014, including destination, and you still get the capable 248-horsepower V-6 and a whole lot of great safety and convenience features.

There are several good reasons to spring for the higher-end Odyssey, though. The EX-L and Touring/Touring Elite models have the ultra-wide 16.2-inch rear DVD system, the high-end audio, that cool box up front, and, on the top Touring Elite for 2014, the awesome integrated vacuum (right) in the back. Less frivolously, they also have lane departure warning, forward collision warning, and a blind spot information system. I think a big reason to go out and buy a new car or minivan this year is that all these technologies are becoming available. There’s nothing a distracted minivan pilot needs more (besides a trip to Starbucks) than systems that help keep her as aware as possible and her passengers safer as a result.

The Verdict:

If I were shopping for a minivan right now, and price were no object, I would get one of the higher trim levels (Touring or Touring Elite) of the 2014 Odyssey without a backward glance. Then I’d enjoy finding ways to use all the seat configurations, the cup holders, the outlets, and the video capability while going on lots of long road trips in it. A minivan this versatile kind of makes you want to go out and have a bunch of kids, or start a band, or gather four or five old friends and go on a long, long drive.

Peanut Gallery:

Molly: Love the design of the center instrument panel; the angle is perfect for quick access while keeping my eyes on the road. The navigation screen's location is perfect for actually reading the screen because it is not affected by glare, but it is really far away from the driver. I also liked the "title" button that brought up song titles, but I would prefer to have the radio screen integrated with the navigation screen.

Christina: If you're going to have a minivan, this is definitely the one to have. I love the way the seats slide back and forth and fold down by just pulling a lever or a strap. You can do almost everything with one hand! The rear visibility is fantastic, and the car is spacious enough to offer you and your passengers enough room to be comfortable, but not enough to feel like you're driving a yacht down the road. This one is a winner.

Annie: I'm still a long way off from the Married With Children portion of my life, so it's hard for me to imagine a minivan as my car of choice. I wasn't a fan of the Odyssey's big, boat-like attitude, but I was duly impressed by the wide array of comfort features this top-of-the-line Odyssey offered. From a drink cooler built into the center console, to the dual-screen DVD player, to the acres and acres of space between passengers, it's easy to see why families fall for the Odyssey. Ask me again in ten years.

Scott: I took the Odyssey on a 150-mile round trip carrying my video equipment on the way there and the equipment for myself and another videographer on the way back. It was a lot of stuff. Everything fit snugly, and nothing was rolling around, yet there was still room for two passengers in the back. I have always driven Hondas and always liked them because they’re durable; you can run them into the ground. So maybe I’m biased, but I think the Odyssey is great.

Jean: I like how refined all the controls are, especially for the people in the back. I don't personally like the video screen hanging down, because I can't bend my neck back like that without getting dizzy, and tilting the seat back, although a great feature, doesn't much help. If you're looking for a minivan, this Odyssey is great, but if you think adults will be comfortable looking at the screen in the second row, guess again. The video screen would be much better just in the back of the headrest, even for a kid.

metaTitle: Hyundai Blue Link by the Numbers - JeanKnowsCars.com
metaKeywords: Hyundai Blue Link by the Numbers
metaDescription: Hyundai Blue Link by the Numbers: the automaker has released graphic details about how many people are using their services. Must-read for numbers junkies. Read it on JeanKnowsCars.com.

contributors.bio:
I am a recent graduate of Boston University thrilled to be working my first real job (in this case, “real” means I never have to use a mop).  I have previously appeared as a lifeguard, a mailroom lackey, a part-time nanny, and a fudge chef, but the real reason I'm here today is because someone once told me I could write and I believed them. As a writer and publisher for BU’s online magazine, I wrote about politics and current events and wrote two series: Foxy Congressperson of the Week, which is exactly what it sounds like, and An American in Paris, detailing my misadventures abroad. 

Growing up in Southeastern Michigan means that love of cars is practically a birthright, and one I’ve always been proud of. I still drive my first car, a beloved orange Chevy HHR that has been through the war and keeps on chugging. After three years on the East Coast, I’m happy to be back in a place where the speed limit is treated more as a guideline than a rule.

pageElements.text: Ever wonder if all those monthly subscriptions people buy for in-car telematics systems ever go to waste? I have an OnStar subscription that I have never, ever used—although I do like knowing that my car would call an ambulance for me if I got in a serious accident.  Am I the only one wasting my monthly payment? A recent internal Hyundai study of more than 400,000 Blue Link subscribers suggests that I might, indeed, be in the minority.

Hyundai Blue Link provides a bevy of services including emergency alerts, roadside assistance, navigation, and vehicle safeguard tools like curfew alert, geofencing, and stolen vehicle recovery. Since its launch nearly two years ago, Blue Link customers have interacted with the system an impressive 6.8 million times. Of those interactions, 2.9 million were for remote locking, unlocking, or starting, and 3.2 million were for monthly vehicle health reports.

Other features were less ubiquitous but still helped thousands of drivers. Blue Link users scheduled 300 vehicle service appointments per day. More than 10,000 Blue Link customers have needed emergency support. Nearly one million customers have received a smartphone alert letting them know that their car alarm was going off. If that car alarm was going off for a good reason, the owner could be better off than someone without Blue Link. Hyundai says that 88 percent of stolen Blue Link vehicles are recovered, compared with 57 percent of all stolen vehicles.

The highest rates of calls to SOS Emergency Assistance came from Michigan and Vermont, while the highest rates of use for Blue Link’s weather services came from Wyoming, Alaska, West Virginia, Kentucky, and Montana. Drivers in Southern and Mid-Atlantic states had some of the highest rates of Blue Link interactions per subscriber, while Alaska and the Plains states had some of the lowest rates.

Blue Link users have downloaded points of interest to their navigation systems more than two million times, and (perhaps predictably) the fifth most searched for restaurant was McDonald’s, coming in behind Italian, Mexican, Starbucks, and American.

These figures are interesting to the casual observer, but Hyundai will no doubt use them for more than just interesting anecdotes. The company says it will use the information it has gathered to improve the Blue Link platform and “find new ways to delight” its customers.

title: Datsun Is Back!
subTitle: Do you have Datsun memories? I do
promoTeaserSmall: It has been Nissan for years. Now India is getting the Datsun Go. Do you have Datsun memories? I do.
promoTeaser: It has been Nissan for years. Now India is getting the Datsun Go. Do you have Datsun memories? I do.
metaDescription: Datsun Is Back! The celebrated name dates back a century but was changed to Nissan in the 1980s. Read some memories about the brand on JeanKnowsCars.com.

pageElements.text: Datsun is back! Although not for the U.S. market. Still, we're glad to see the return of a great automotive name.

What does the name Datsun mean to you?
Maybe nothing, unless you’re a late Baby Boomer or early Gen-Xer, in which case it likely brings back a flood of memories from your teenage and early adult years. Two of the most influential cars of my twenties were Datsuns. The lame “The Name Is Nissan” campaign that pushed the name out the door in 1981 did nothing for me.

The all-new Datsun Go (above) is a sub-$7,000 hatchback that will be sold in India, Russia, and Indonesia starting early next year. It made a splashy debut on July 15 in New Delhi alongside its slogan, “the badge of the risers,” which presumably means something to prospective customers in India who are shopping for a car for the first time. The new little car is economical, simply designed, and seats five.

Sounds a lot like the B210 Honey Bee my friend owned in the 1970s. One summer evening after dinner, three of us were going west on I-94, taking the quickest route to a shopping center. I was in the back seat. My friend was minding her own business in the right lane when a semitruck driver cut right into her without signaling. I saw the giant slab sides of the truck getting closer and closer, and then bam! The tiny Datsun spun around, hit the truck again, and spun twice more, before ending up on the shoulder, facing in the right direction. Miraculously, nobody in the car was seriously injured. All that, plus (arguable) good looks and dozens of mpg!

image.caption: Datsun Li'l Hustler pickup, long-bed version

pageElements.text: The other important Datsun in my life was a truck. It was a 1979 Li'l Hustler, the dumb name of a very smart product: the small pickup, which used to be seen everywhere. It had a long wheelbase and white stripes along the sides. Brilliant red at first, after several years it had faded to a matte color like the rouge on the face of a dance-hall girl in a cowboy movie. The Datsun truck went to the dump so often, it could probably have found its way on its own. It was on the job to help tear apart and rebuild entire houses inside and out, after which it would head downtown to dinner at the Central Café with aplomb. It bit the dust after many years of loyal service, and they just don’t make something like it anymore.
Except, I guess, in India, where aspirational buyers may be about to have the same kind of memorable experience with small, can-do cars that my friends and I had all those years ago.

It may be thirty years since the U.S. has had Datsuns, but the very first one actually came out in Japan just about 100 years ago. It was named the Dat-Go. “Dat” in Japanese means “lightning fast,” but let’s not follow that idea too far down the road when looking at the new Go, shall we? The “Dat” nowadays stands for “Dream, Access, and Trust,” according to Nissan.
The new Datsun Go gets a 1.2-liter engine and a five-speed manual transmission. Although it’s not going to knock anyone out with high-tech add-ons, there is a mobile docking station for smartphones.

Nissan anticipates bringing out more models under the Datsun name, but you other nostalgic Americans shouldn’t hold your breath about getting one here. Spoiled by more modern rides, we probably wouldn’t appreciate them as much anymore, anyway.

title: Decoding Your VIN
promoTeaserSmall: The vehicle identification number tells you so much about your car. Let's crack the code together.
promoTeaser: The vehicle identification number tells you so much about your car. Let's crack the code together.
metaDescription: Decoding your VIN: What does your car's VIN mean? Find out what all those numbers and letters are trying to tell you. The story is at JeanKnowsCars.com.

contributors.bio: When I turned sixteen, my dad brought home the very first-generation Ford Escort wagon, and it just so happened to have a manual transmission. Since—like every other sixteen-year-old—I knew everything, I was sure that I would just get behind the wheel and effortlessly shift gears. Visions of screeching into the school parking lot with my shiny red "world car" and impressing all the burnouts who hung out near their Detroit muscle cars danced in my head. All of those dreams were quickly extinguished in the first fifteen minutes of my driving lesson from my dad. Although he has a teaching certificate, patience is not his strongest skill. The subtle foot-hand coordination escaped me, and we were jerking around the subdivision like the contestants in a game of Red Light Green Light. I blamed my dad, and he blamed me. To my astonishment, he decided it was best to abandon ship and allow me to figure out how to get home. Somehow I managed to limp home without needing therapy for whiplash. After our wounds had healed I did end up learning to drive a manual on that trusty steed. I ended up driving my Escort to Northern Michigan University in Marquette, in Michigan’s frigid Upper Peninsula, where I obtained a BFA, with a concentration in Graphic Design, and a future husband. I joined Automobile Magazine at the tender age of twenty-eight and fell in love with the energy and passion for automobiles and the way they enhance our lives. Later, I took a five-year hiatus and boned up my design and web skills and am now turbocharged to be a part of the Jean Knows Cars team. Many years have passed, and now my sixteen-year-old only child is poised to learn to drive a manual, and I can’t help but be transported back to my teens. Unlike my parents, I am a helicopter mom. Riding in the passenger's seat with her behind the wheel is like waterboarding. I want to order her to pull over and allow me to drive and throw her in the back seat with airbags strapped directly on her. Many of her peers will not learn to drive a manual, but I believe that it is the building block for a good safe driver. It is a perfect synergy watching my daughter learn to drive and helping Jean Knows Cars celebrate and embrace the automobile and how it is woven into our lives.

pageElements.text: No math required, but I am going to be hurtling numbers at you, so be prepared to duck. Just as each U.S. citizen has a nine-digit Social Security number, our vehicles each have a seventeen-character vehicle identification number (VIN). If you are anything like me, you are grabbing your pillow right about now to get comfortable for this snorefest. Well, put your pillow away, because those numbers are actually quite interesting.

The practice of assigning VINs began in 1954. Each manufacturer had its own formula, so, as you can imagine, they were confusing. In 1981, the National Highway Traffic Safety Administration developed a standard for all over-the-road vehicles. The current method for assigning VINs in the United States is based on standards set by the International Organization for Standardization. The European Union uses the same standards but applies them differently. The U.S. VINs now each have seventeen characters, and here is a little-known gem—they do not include the letters I, O, or Q.

You may be asking yourself, “Why should I care?” Well, you should care because knowing the VIN for a vehicle can reveal all the deep, dark secrets of a car’s life.  Throughout the life of a vehicle, the VIN is used to record important information such as lemon history, airbag deployments, service and repair information, relevant recalls, and even if the vehicle was used as a taxi. Examining VIN-related records is like reading someone’s personal diary. Especially useful is the title, as it may reveal flood damage, salvage details, or other insurance-related information.

One more thing you need to know is where to locate this magical number. It is on the very top of the dash where it can be viewed through the windshield from outside the vehicle. It is also on a sticker on the driver’s-side doorjamb. There is not an industry standard, but it is also sometimes on engines, hoods, and other parts.

Nerds probably already guessed it, but there is a hidden code in each VIN. This is where the lesson really gets exciting.
    • Positions one to three are the World Manufacturer Identifier.

<ul>
o	Position one identifies the country where the vehicle was manufactured (for example, K for Korea, W for Germany, and 1, 4, or 5 for the United States).
o	Position two is the manufacturer code (for example, T for Toyota or Lexus, D for Mercedes-Benz, and 6 for Cadillac).
o Position three can be used to identify a division or vehicle type. If it is not needed, a nine is used.

• Positions four to eight identify the vehicle’s attributes, such as platform, model, and body style. It is at the discretion of each manufacturer to use this section as it pleases. The eighth digit is commonly used to identify the engine.
• Position nine is a check digit, the result of a crazy mathematical equation that checks to see if there is an error in the VIN.
• Position ten is the model year. Every year is assigned a code character. (The character for 2013 is D.)
• Position eleven is the plant code, which identifies the plant where the vehicle was built.

• Positions twelve to seventeen are the production sequence. This number is given to the vehicle as it comes off the assembly line. Since there is no fixed standard for this number, each manufacturer may use it differently.

So if, for example, you are looking to find out all about a used car before you buy it, a quick way to access knowledge is the VIN. You can find many websites with a quick Google search that let you enter a VIN and find out information about a vehicle. Congratulations! You are now one of a small segment of the population that knows the secrets a VIN can reveal.

relatedArticles.title: Driving into Retirement

pageElements.text: It’s a whole new car-shopping world out there. It used to be, you’d go out to the dealership and pay cash for a new car or finance it over a couple of years. Gradually, as car prices have increased and more luxurious choices in transportation have become available, those finance terms have started to grow until, today, it’s not unusual to see five-year or even six-year finance contracts.

So it’s not so surprising that people have started to see leasing as a viable alternative: get a nice new car, take on an affordable monthly payment, and repeat every few years. It seems counterintuitive that, in a marketplace where the average age of cars on the road is eleven years, leasing should be so strong (every month this year, J.D. Power and Associates reports, at least 22.5 percent of deals have been leases). Behind both statistics, you’ll find the same reason: cost saving.

When you lease, you’re using that new car for a set length of time and then giving it back. In that way, it’s like renting a house instead of buying one: it’s yours, but it’s not really yours. The benefit is that you are getting a brand-new vehicle—and probably one that is fancier than you would have been able to afford to buy—and only worrying about fuel and insurance, not long-term maintenance and resale.

Once reluctant to lease rather than buy, today women are increasingly interested in leasing, according to a study just released by the trading website Swapalease.com. More than 67 percent of women surveyed said they are “likely” or “extremely likely” to consider a lease next time they shop for a vehicle.

The study also reports that women are more practical and rational about leasing.  More than 44 percent of women surveyed are looking for monthly payments at or below $299 per month, compared with only 24.7 percent of men. And they are looking more often to lease from brands such as Honda and Toyota than brands such as Cadillac and BMW.

While leasing is especially popular for luxury and high-priced vehicles, it’s increasingly popular for more mainstream cars, too. Take, for example, the Toyota Camry, available in August at a $199-per-month lease rate over twenty-four months, with $999 due at signing. How can they afford to offer such a deal? It’s because the residual value of that car is so high; Toyota has no doubt its dealers will find buyers willing to pay good money for the two-year-old, low-mileage Camrys it will have on its lot at the end of the lease term.
You might be one of those people looking for a great lease deal as a way to get more car than you could otherwise afford. What do you need to know to do it right? Here are some guidelines.

1. Don’t let the monthly payment be the only number you think about.

Leasing is a kind of financing, too. For one thing, you might want to buy the car outright at the end of the lease, and you’ll then be held to the price you have signed for. You want to make sure the car is going to be worth that number in the end. In dealer speak, the total price of a leased car is the “capitalized cost,” which should be close to the price you’d pay if you were buying it. Negotiate the total price of the car, just as you’d do as a buyer, and only then let the salesperson break it down into lease numbers.

Now, if you are getting a great deal like the one on the Camry mentioned above, you might not be able to negotiate anything about the total price. These are called “subsidized leases,” and the low price you’re getting will probably be a good enough deal as is, as long as the dealer doesn’t add a bunch of fees on top of it.  Which leads us to:

2. Pay attention to fees.

Document fees, title and registration fees, an acquisition fee, a disposition fee (to be paid if the lessee doesn’t buy the vehicle at the end of the lease), even a tire fee showed up on the lease agreement a New York Times reporter signed for a new Infiniti G37x. Each of these fed into the overall lease payment and nudged it upward.

3. Don’t just take the lease language for granted.

A big sticking point for many people considering a lease is that the number of miles you can drive the car is limited, usually to less than 15,000 miles per year. Consumer Reports suggests you negotiate that number or ask about buying extra miles up front, with the understanding that the money you put down will be refunded if you don’t go over the limit. You should also negotiate the down payment, known in leases as the “capitalized cost reduction.”

However, there's one thing you probably can't negotiate: the length of the lease. There’s usually a big penalty if you turn the leased car in before the term ends. That explains the proliferation of lease-swapping websites. Uncomplicate your life, and don’t impulsively sign on to a lease you may not want to follow through on.

The bottom line is, ask yourself if you are a thirty-nine-month person or an eleven-year person. Are you the kind of person who can feel good about turning in a car after a few years and starting fresh with a new one, or would you prefer to stick with one car and build equity over several years? Interest rates are low, and residual values are high as cars continue to improve in quality and longevity. Both of those trends mean it’s a good time either to buy or to lease a car—it’s up to you how you go about it.

title: Bright Colors Are Coming Back
promoTeaserSmall: Are you driving a white or silver car but feeling an urge for chartreuse? BASF study says you will.
promoTeaser: Are you driving a white or silver car but feeling an urge for chartreuse? BASF study says you will.
metaTitle: Bright Colors Are Coming Back - JeanKnowsCars.com
metaDescription: Bright colors are coming back! The latest BASF study on automotive color trends reveals that North Americans are feeling optimistic and will soon want brighter-colored cars. See the details on JeanKnowsCars.com.

pageElements.text: Are you driving a white or silver car but feeling an urge for bright green coming on? Well, two to three years from now, apparently, we will all be buying cars in brighter colors and with more interesting paint textures. That’s according to the annual automotive color trend survey from paint supplier BASF. Green and yellowish-green are going to be big, and matte finishes or special effects that make color look three-dimensional will be popular, or so it says.

Jewel Tones, Anybody?

The company has released a new palette of sixty-five colors for automakers and designers. For North America, the BASF color groups are called Aspire, Dequalize, Multiverse, and Syncopace. Good thing this company is only updating the car color lexicon, not the dictionary! From the way people chose among the colors, BASF sees “optimism” in our future: 60 percent of North American consumers are currently driving a silver, black, or white car. But what 49 percent liked best on the BASF future-color wheel were jewel-toned shades of red and blue.

Europe Feeling Rational

In the Asia-Pacific region, the survey shows that neutral colors are going to stay on top, but “sophisticated intermediate” shades such as olive green and bluish gray will gradually gain popularity, says BASF. In Europe, which is struggling through economic and energy challenges, rationality wins the day. A subtle metallic color called Particular Gray was popular, but survey respondents also liked black as well as “courageous colors” including red and green. But, perhaps departing from rationality for a minute, Europeans also went for Fiberphyllic, described as "a bold yellowish-green offering a more expressive coarse feel."

More Matte to Come?

You can already buy limited-edition matte paint on the Hyundai Veloster Turbo (right, in Matte Gray), the BMW M3, and several models of Mercedes-Benz. The flat look is unusual and, in my opinion anyway, gorgeous, but it’s reputedly much harder to care for than the glossy kind. Will we all be driving matte-paint cars, or chartreuse crossovers, five years from now? And won't the street scene be more interesting if we are?

Here are more color stories for you, leaving little doubt as to where we stand on bright colors for cars.

title: 2012 Toyota Prius Four
promoTeaserSmall: I got no thrills, except when I checked out my fuel economy! But what does the Peanut Gallery think?
promoTeaser: I got no thrills, except when I checked out my fuel economy! But what does the Peanut Gallery think?
metaDescription: 2012 Toyota Prius Four: I'll tell you what I thought about this iconic hybrid, and recommend whether you should buy it. The Peanut Gallery will weigh in, too. Read it on JeanKnowsCars.com.

contributors.bio:
I am a recent graduate of Boston University thrilled to be working my first real job (in this case, “real” means I never have to use a mop).  I have previously appeared as a lifeguard, a mailroom lackey, a part-time nanny, and a fudge chef, but the real reason I'm here today is because someone once told me I could write and I believed them. As a writer and publisher for BU’s online magazine, I wrote about politics and current events and wrote two series: Foxy Congressperson of the Week, which is exactly what it sounds like, and An American in Paris, detailing my misadventures abroad. 

Growing up in Southeastern Michigan means that love of cars is practically a birthright, and one I’ve always been proud of. I still drive my first car, a beloved orange Chevy HHR that has been through the war and keeps on chugging. After three years on the East Coast, I’m happy to be back in a place where the speed limit is treated more as a guideline than a rule.

pageElements.text:
The Car:

Price: $33,118 as tested (including destination charge)
Engine: 1.8-liter Atkinson cycle four-cylinder with electric motor, 134 net system horsepower
Transmission: Continuously variable
Fuel Economy: 51 mpg city/48 mpg highway
My favorite standard feature: Multi-information display
Option I can't live without: Deluxe Solar Roof package, including solar roof panels with power moonroof ($3,820)
You might also be considering: Chevrolet Volt, Ford C-Max, Honda Insight
See more specs on the Prius in our Car Guide.

What I Think:

The Toyota Prius wasn't the first hybrid to hit the U.S. market—that honor belongs to the Honda Insight—but it is the best-selling hybrid vehicle on these shores and one of the most instantly recognizable. That geometric glass rear greenhouse has become part of the design language for alternative-fuel cars across the market.

I've always been a little dubious of the Prius's "Look at me, I'm green" styling, but here in Ann Arbor, it looks like I'm the only one. There's a Prius on every street corner in this old hippie town and often more than one. Driving a hybrid down the streets of Ann Arbor was like being part of a slightly self-righteous club. It may not be that way everywhere, but it's easy to imagine how Prii could spread like wildfire in certain parts of the country.

The Prius comes by its earth-friendly image honestly. There are four Prius models for the 2013 model year, and none of them is rated below 40 mpg on the highway. The Prius Four we tested is the "normal" Prius. It falls in the middle of the family’s price range and is rated at 51 mpg in the city and 48 mpg on the highway. I was very impressed when the Prius returned an indicated 53.1 mpg on a two-and-a-half-hour highway drive without my making any particular effort to get good gas mileage. Better yet, with a starting price of $24,200 (although the one shown here started at a still reasonable $28,235), it won't take years of gas savings to make up the difference in price between a Prius and a similar traditional gasoline car.

Of course, gas mileage that good comes at a cost, and in the case of the Prius, that cost is driving enjoyment. You won't get a thrill from pressing the accelerator, and I don't recommend throwing the Prius around tight corners. But for drivers who are just trying to get from Point A to Point B, the Prius's 1.8-liter 98-horsepower engine (which gets help from the small electric motor to make 134 horsepower under heavy acceleration) will be perfectly adequate. It's also a little addictive to try to drive as efficiently as possible. The Prius has a B position on the shifter that increases regenerative braking, best for use in city driving: it increases the energy recaptured by the battery when the car is slowing down.

If you desperately want a Prius but the Prius Four isn't quite the variety you're looking for, you may just find the hybrid of your dreams in the Prius c, the Prius v, or the Prius Plug-in. The Prius c is smaller and cheaper than the Prius Four, so it might be a little better suited to drivers living in a cramped city. The Prius v is for customers who think the Prius could stand to be just a little bigger, and while it doesn't get quite the gas mileage of its smaller siblings, it still does better than just about any non-hybrid vehicle at 44 mpg city and 40 mpg highway. The Prius Plug-in allows drivers to experience up to eleven miles of electric range, thanks to a slightly larger battery that can be fully charged in an hour and a half at a 240-volt outlet. That model earns 95 MPGe.

The Verdict:

There's a reason Toyota has sold millions of Prii worldwide since the automaker brought the car to the U.S. market. The Prius does exactly what it says it will do: deliver excellent fuel economy in a practical package. The interior is comfortable and relatively attractive, the exterior is distinctive and often worn as a badge of honor, and the hybrid powertrain will let you blow past gas stations like they've gone out of style.

If you're looking for a car with great driving dynamics, this isn't it. The Prius has plenty of worthy competition in the hybrid market (check out the Ford C-Max), but it's still the best-selling hybrid nameplate in the country, and there are enough flavors of Prius that you're almost certain to find one that suits you.

Peanut Gallery:

Molly: I have said it before and I'll say it again: the back end of the Prius looks like the back end of a Pontiac Aztek. The first concept Prius made its debut in 1995, and the Aztek concept followed four years later. Coincidence? I think not. The Aztek has repeatedly been crowned as one of the ugliest cars of all time, and I think they should make room on the podium next to it for the Prius. That being said, it is a perfectly adequate car that makes a lot of environmental sense.

Scott: I'm afraid to say that I like the Prius because of all the negative comments I have heard about the car, but I do like it. I was pleased with how big the interior is, and the controls were easy to navigate. I felt like it was very open inside, yet it also felt very safe. When I drove the Prius around town, I found that the steering was easy and smooth, and the car didn't feel underpowered at all, which was not what I expected. If I had to discredit the car, I'd say that, for how big the rear window is, it's still hard to see out the back. For the nearly $30,000 this costs, I'd buy a Honda Accord instead and keep the change.

Laura: The Toyota Prius is as much a symbol as it is a car: the Converse All-Star sneaker, the Campbell's soup can, the I Love Lucy of hybrids. Well, those things didn't get their status by being unpredictable, and neither did the Toyota Prius. An expanded list of sizes and price points, plus Toyota quality and predictability, put the Prius into a very special position among hybrids. Who wants to argue with that? You say Prius drivers are self-satisfied? They are getting better fuel economy than most people. People drive too slow in the Prius? They're just trying to get even better fuel economy than they already are. The car is boring? Toyota doesn't make these things for the same people who buy the Porsche Boxster. I appreciate the Prius for what it is: an icon. Yes, I used the I word. If I were shopping for a hybrid, it would be ridiculous not to give it serious consideration.

title: Why Don't Teens Want Licenses?
promoTeaserSmall: I don't get it: why don't teens want their freedom? A survey breaks down reasons for the reluctance.
promoTeaser: I don't get it: why don't teens want their freedom? A survey breaks down reasons for the reluctance.
metaTitle: Why Don't Teens Want Licenses? - JeanKnowsCars.com
metaDescription: Why Don't Teens Want Licenses? A survey from the driver's-license-enabling website driving-tests.org tries to figure that out. Read the details on JeanKnowsCars.com.

contributors.bio:
I am a recent graduate of Boston University thrilled to be working my first real job (in this case, “real” means I never have to use a mop).  I have previously appeared as a lifeguard, a mailroom lackey, a part-time nanny, and a fudge chef, but the real reason I'm here today is because someone once told me I could write and I believed them. As a writer and publisher for BU’s online magazine, I wrote about politics and current events and wrote two series: Foxy Congressperson of the Week, which is exactly what it sounds like, and An American in Paris, detailing my misadventures abroad. 

Growing up in Southeastern Michigan means that love of cars is practically a birthright, and one I’ve always been proud of. I still drive my first car, a beloved orange Chevy HHR that has been through the war and keeps on chugging. After three years on the East Coast, I’m happy to be back in a place where the speed limit is treated more as a guideline than a rule.

pageElements.text: When I was in high school, I was so desperate to get my driver’s license that I took the driving test a month early and begged my parents to pull me out of second period world history so I could be at the Secretary of State the moment it opened. I saw that license as my ticket to freedom, and I wasn’t going to wait for it a second longer than I had to. So, despite my status as a millennial, I’m as confused as anyone when I hear that today’s teenagers aren’t tripping over themselves to get a taste of the sweet, sweet freedom that is unsupervised driving.

A study from the University of Michigan says that just 28 percent of sixteen-year-olds had driver’s licenses in 2010, down from more than 40 percent in 1983. So why aren’t kids driving? A new study from Driving-Tests.org surveyed more than 1,400 young people and asked them about their attitudes toward and concerns about driving, seeking to find answers in the mysterious case of the missing teenage drivers.

They didn’t come up with a conclusive answer to the “where are the young drivers?” question. What they did find is that young drivers are concerned about safety and are worried they won’t pass their driving tests. Perhaps most encouraging is that 75 percent of the teens surveyed listed texting or talking on the phone as the most dangerous thing a driver can do behind the wheel, so those “don’t text and drive” PSAs seem to be doing their job. Less encouraging is that just ten percent of the teens that responded to the survey thought drinking and driving was a “critical risk.”

Although none of the teens surveyed said cost was influencing their decision to get a driver’s license, fourteen percent of respondents said they were afraid of driving, and twelve percent felt “emotional pressure” about driving. Twenty-nine percent of teens said they were concerned about learning basic driving skills like parallel parking and driving next to large trucks.

Local eighteen-year-old Tegwyn John gave two reasons for her choice not to take the final test and get her driver's license. Even though she went through the driver education course, she says, "I don't want to pay the higher insurance rates associated with very young drivers, and I have easy access to public transportation."
Whether reluctant teenagers have rational reasons like Tegwyn's or are afraid, the study offered some tips for parents hoping to help their teens turn into safe, responsible drivers.

<ul>
•	Make sure you’re setting a good example for your kids when you’re driving them around. Of the teens surveyed, 53 percent said they’d seen their parents texting or talking on the phone behind the wheel. If you don’t want them to text and drive, you shouldn’t, either.

•	Talk to your kids about what it means to be a safe driver. Don’t just focus on texting, either. Make sure your teens know how dangerous drinking and driving is, too. For a little added incentive, consider drawing up a driving contract so your teen can see your expectations in writing and agree to them with a signature.

• If your kid is a nervous driver, spend extra time on the tricky parts of driving, like driving on the freeway or making lane changes on busy roads. If he or she still isn’t confident, look into a defensive driving course to help your teen build confidence.

I am a recent graduate of Boston University thrilled to be working my first real job (in this case, “real” means I never have to use a mop).  I have previously appeared as a lifeguard, a mailroom lackey, a part-time nanny, and a fudge chef, but the real reason I'm here today is because someone once told me I could write and I believed them. As a writer and publisher for BU’s online magazine, I wrote about politics and current events and wrote two series: Foxy Congressperson of the Week, which is exactly what it sounds like, and An American in Paris, detailing my misadventures abroad. 

Growing up in Southeastern Michigan means that love of cars is practically a birthright, and one I’ve always been proud of. I still drive my first car, a beloved orange Chevy HHR that has been through the war and keeps on chugging. After three years on the East Coast, I’m happy to be back in a place where the speed limit is treated more as a guideline than a rule.

pageElements.text:
Price: $20,580 as tested (includes destination charge)
Engine: 1.5-liter SOHC 4-cylinder, 117 horsepower
Transmission: Five-speed automatic with paddle shifters
Fuel economy: 27 mpg city/33 mpg highway
My favorite standard feature: Easy-fold “Magic Seats”
Option I can’t live without: No options; the Fit’s top trim level comes standard with all available options
You might also be considering: Chevrolet Sonic, Ford Fiesta, Toyota Yaris
See more specs on the Fit in our Car Guide.

What I Think:


It’s hard out there for a car shopper on a budget. Most people seeking a car in the $20,000-and-under price range aren’t shopping a dream car. They’re looking for something that will be reliable, efficient, and (perhaps hardest of all) that won’t announce itself as an econobox. It’s not an easy balance to strike, but it’s one the Honda Fit, Honda’s most affordable model, is searching for.

In my experience, Fit owners are among the drivers most likely to have an evangelistic enthusiasm for their automobiles. They tell a story of a car that’s fun to drive, endlessly useful, and easy to love. I was never quite convinced by all this fawning over the Fit, but after driving it for several days, I’m starting to understand the hype.

The Fit’s key feature (aside from its tiny price; our top of the line model barely crests $20,000, and a base model can be had for $16,215) is its surprisingly spacious interior. With the rear seats down, the Fit has more cargo room than any of its competitors, besting the nearest challenger by nearly ten cubic feet. The Fit owes its impressive 57.3 cubic feet of cargo space at least in part to what Honda has dubbed the Magic Seat. It’s a rear seat that folds into a variety of configurations, including a completely flat load floor, to accommodate whatever you might be carrying.

This Fit Sport with Navigation came standard with every available option, most notably a factory-installed navigation and infotainment system. I found the system easy to use, and I especially appreciated the ease of Bluetooth audio streaming, my most frequent source of infotainment frustration in cars. The system feels a little aftermarket, and it won’t rival Chevrolet’s MyLink, for instance, but it still accomplishes its appointed task well. The rest of the Fit’s interior feels spartan, and there’s a lot of road noise, particularly at highway speeds.

The Fit makes just 117 horsepower with its 1.5-liter four-cylinder engine, but it makes up for its lack of power by earning a combined 30 mpg. The Fit Sport with Navigation has sixteen-inch tires in place of the base model’s fifteen-inchers, and it gets revised gear ratios along with a host of appearance upgrades for a sportier feel. Even so, it might be going a bit far to call the Fit sporty. With its large windshield and airy cabin, what the Fit does feel like is a much larger car. And for the shopper who’s looking for versatility and utility in a small car, the wide open spaces could make all the difference.

The Verdict:


Even though I knew the Fit was designed to maximize cabin space, I was still surprised at how large it felt. Every time someone asked me what I thought of the car, I said it felt “cheap and spacious,” which is pretty much exactly what it is. Sure, Honda could have given the Fit a few more creature comforts, but the car doesn’t feel deficient when you consider how affordable it is. It may not be an aspirational car, but it feels just right for a first-time car buyer looking for something to bridge the gap between a cute ute and a microcar.

Peanut Gallery:

Laura: Strangely enough, I have to disagree with Annie's assertion that the Fit is not an "aspirational car." As a person who has driven large vehicles for years (thanks to my four kids), the Fit has been my aspirational car for several years now. I see one of these cute little runabouts on the street, and I say to myself, Someday I will get to drive something that fuel-efficient and adorable. Having actually driven this Fit, I may have wavered slightly based on the driving experience, because you can feel the road as though you were making a rubbing of every bump and striation. The Fit would be an adjustment for anybody who was downsizing from any kind of larger, more cushy vehicle.

But it might be worth it, and the photos of Annie stretched out under her blanket inside the Fit totally closed the deal for me. I would have loved this car when I was young enough to sleep in the car on cross-country drives! Maybe I'll do some yoga to keep me capable of that when I am old and free of responsibility enough to take solo cross-country drives again.

Scott: The Honda Fit Sport is billed as a car, but it's a mini minivan. There's a ton of room inside. I could fit all my music equipment before going and playing a show in this car and fit a second person in the passenger's seat without feeling crammed in. As a Honda Civic owner, I am used to having my arm right on the door armrest when I drive. This car felt more like a minivan because there was more space in the driver's area between the seat and the door. I do wish that the rear seat could be sectioned in three parts instead of two so you could fit a third person, but I'm not sure it's wide enough. On the road, when shifting into reverse or drive, I felt a little looseness and hesitation. But overall, I enjoyed driving it.

pageElements.text: At Jean Knows Cars, we’re big fans of manual transmissions, and we think everybody should learn to drive stick shift, but we’re willing to admit that for drivers who frequently navigate in heavy traffic, driving a stick can turn into a chore. It’s always been a choice that shifting enthusiasts are faced with: drive an automatic so you don’t spend half your driving life with your foot hovering over the clutch pedal, or stick with the stick and accept sore shins as part of the bargain.

If automotive parts supplier Bosch has its way, though, this decision could soon become a thing of the past. Bosch has developed a technology it calls the eClutch, which allows drivers to shift into first gear without using the clutch pedal. Essentially, this means that a car equipped with eClutch could be driven like an automatic, using only the brake and gas pedals, in stop-and-go traffic.

The Art of Shifting into First

Drivers will still need to use the clutch to shift into second and higher gears, but Bosch believes the eClutch can “close the gap” between driving a manual and an automatic. Practically anyone who’s learned (or tried to learn) how to drive a stick shift will agree that mastering the art of shifting into first gear from a standing stop is the toughest part of the process. Even for shifts into higher gears, the system will help ensure smooth gear changes by automatically adjusting engine speed when it detects that the driver is changing gears.

Coasting to Improve MPG

The eClutch could also result in significant fuel economy savings in equipped cars, thanks to a coasting function that decouples the engine from the clutch when the driver stops accelerating, allowing the car to coast and resulting in what Bosch says could be up to a ten percent saving in fuel economy.

Any Takers?

Looking back on my own experience learning to drive a manual transmission, I can’t help thinking that the whole process would have been much smoother if the car could have shifted into first gear for me. Could this be the magic bullet for reluctant learners? Bosch hasn’t said whether it’s found a customer for eClutch, but if anyone’s asking us, we’re all for it!

title: Strap In Those Kids
promoTeaserSmall: Do you ever (just this once) let kids ride unsecured? GM-backed study says it's shockingly common.
promoTeaser: Do you ever (just this once) let kids ride unsecured? GM-backed study says it's shockingly common.
metaDescription: Strap In Those Kids - A new study by Safe Kids Worldwide, backed by the General Motors Foundation, says an alarming number of parents think it's okay to let their children ride in cars unsecured sometimes. Read about it and check out a checklist for car seat safety. It's on JeanKnowsCars.com.

pageElements.text: I remember it like it was yesterday. One bright, sunny afternoon, I lifted up my one-year-old baby boy, the joy of my life, and lovingly, carefully strapped him in to the car seat in the back seat of the test car that I was driving that day. I paused for a moment to kiss his round, pink cheeks. Then I got in the driver’s seat and drove out of the parking lot. It was only moments until I rounded the first bend and noticed, out of the corner of my eye, that the car seat had slalomed over to the other side of the back seat. Horror! I had done everything right—except remember to strap the car seat in to the car.
Fortunately, that baby boy was fine (he’s twenty now), and I never did that again.

But apparently, I am not the only one to have made that mistake. A newly released report says one in four parents has driven without making sure that baby and child passengers are strapped in properly or even in a safety seat at all.

It’s even more alarming to know that the parents admitted this to the wonderful organization Safe Kids Worldwide, which takes it upon itself to ensure car-seat safety. The General Motors Foundation underwrote the study, in which Safe Kids Worldwide surveyed 1,002 parents and caregivers of children aged ten and under.

The study actually found that the more education and financial resources a parent has, the more likely he or she is to make an exception and let a child ride improperly secured. It also found that young parents and men are more likely than older parents and women to do so.
Listen to GM executive Mike Robinson, a GM Foundation board member, when he says, “Exceptions can lead to tragedies.”

What are the reasons parents make “exceptions”? The study gave a few examples: how about if you are only going a short distance? Twenty-one percent of parents said going unrestrained was OK for kids on short trips—but 60 percent of accidents involving children happen within ten minutes of the child’s home. And how about this statistic: 34 percent of parents with household incomes over $100,000 were okay with unrestrained children on short trips. Only 15 percent of parents with household incomes under $35,000 thought so. And parents with graduate degrees are twice as willing to travel with unsecured children than parents with only a high-school education.

How about if the child will be in the car overnight? Nearly a quarter of the parents under thirty felt it would be acceptable, and thirteen percent of older parents said it was okay—but children are most likely to be injured in an accident during nighttime hours.

Other reasons people offered for leaving children at risk in the car: if there was no booster or child safety seat on hand, if someone was holding the child on a lap, or—my favorite—as a “reward.” I don't care what socio-economic group you come from; this is just plain wrong.

It’s National Child Passenger Safety Week (through September 21), so let’s all look our kids in the eye, kiss their rosy little cheeks—and make absolutely sure they are strapped in securely and safely whenever we take them out in the car. Here's the Safe Kids checklist to help you make sure you're doing it right.

pageElements.text: Cadillac's Art and Science design philosophy now extends to the sounds you hear. The 2014 CTS has microphones placed inside the cabin to pick up engine noise, amplify it, and pump it back through the car’s Bose stereo system. The microphones, in concert with an electronic sound enhancement system, pick out the most “desirable” tones (as identified by a team of Cadillac engineers) and magnify them.

Cadillac has created three distinct engine soundtracks, tied to the CTS’s driving modes. In Touring mode, the artificially enhanced engine sounds will “purr with refinement” (or so says Cadillac). In Sport mode, the engine “growls with power.” In Track mode, only available in the 556-horsepower CTS VSport model, it “roars even more aggressively.” This is what Track mode sounds like from inside the car:

title: Rush: A Car Movie about People
promoTitle: Rush: A Car Movie about People
promoTeaserSmall: Whether you love Formula 1 or not, is there a reason to see this film about two of its legends? Yes!
promoTeaser: Whether you love Formula 1 or not, is there a reason to see this film about two of its legends? Yes!
metaTitle: Rush: A Car Movie about People - JeanKnowsCars.com
metaDescription: Rush: A Car Movie about People. Read my review of this new movie that focuses in tightly on two legends of Formula 1 racing. It's on JeanKnowsCars.com.

contributors.bio: Holly has reported on cars, lifestyle, travel, and everything else for publications including the New York Daily News, Redbook, Elite Traveler, and Fox TV. She lives in New York City with her family, including Jack, a toy poodle (and test driving partner!).

pageElements.text: A new movie from director Ron Howard, the auto racing film Rush, is not just for people like me (and, probably, you) who love cars. It has one thing that you don't usually get enough of in a big-budget sports movie: character development. It also has an indie-movie feeling that makes it feel like much more than a traditional crash-and-smash car-chase blockbuster.

Don't get me wrong; over the years I have test-driven cars on racetracks and attended several races. In other words, I have smelled the oil and burning rubber, been jolted by the energy of the crowds, and heard the grind of the gears. I get it. But if you're not the type to be intoxicated by the world of racing, will this movie work for you? All I can report is that my friends who have seen the trailer are keen to see the movie, and I'm going to encourage them (and you) to go see it.

Rush turns its focus to a golden age of Formula 1 racing, the mid-1970s, in a landscape of disco and miniskirts, when the track scene was one big party. This is the compelling true story of the clash of two bigger-than-life superstar rivals, McLaren's James Hunt and Ferrari's Niki Lauda, competing to win the 1976 world championship. The tale has the advantage of being true; here's a photo of the two real-life stars on the track at Japan, the momentous last race of that championship season.

Screenwriter Peter Morgan has crafted a gripping, colorful and sensitive story that combines the leanness of a good documentary with the fantasy of film. Casual, handsome, fun-loving Brit James Hunt (Chris Hemsworth) is a perfect counterpoint on film, as he was in life, to the ultra-stern Austrian Niki Lauda (Daniel Brühl), an icy, calculating, efficient, and exacting gearhead.

The hedonistic Hunt drinks champagne, smokes grass, and sleeps with women before a race. Lauda plays the polar opposite, preparing for a race by going to bed early and staying on the straight and narrow. Yet that’s also where the sensitivity chip shows up, and there is a palpable amount of respect between the two athletes as the story unfolds.

The tension on the racetrack is equally tangible, but director Howard goes beyond the exterior shots of the action. Instead, the camera takes you into the cockpit and behind the helmets to focus intensely on the eyes of Hunt and Lauda. The sounds are guttural; the colors are brilliant; the crashes are explosive, and the director does not shy away from their violence. But this is not a movie punctuated by special effects. What you see in the film is very close to what you get on a track. The film's R rating will probably keep you from taking your car-crazy ten-year-old to the theater, but that's okay. I'm happy to report that, unlike so many movies these days, Rush is a very grown-up story about human striving and achievement.

title: Honda Helping Cars Spot Walkers
promoTeaserSmall: Vehicle-to-Pedestrian communication is the kind of thing that will save lives.
promoTeaser: Vehicle-to-Pedestrian communication is the kind of thing that will save lives.
metaTitle: Honda Helping Cars Spot Walkers  - JeanKnowsCars.com
metaKeywords: University of Michigan Transportation Research Institute
metaDescription: Honda Helping Cars Spot Walkers: Technology to help vehicles communicate with pedestrians and motorcyclists, with the aim of making everybody safer on the road. Details and photos of what Honda's working on are at JeanKnowsCars.com.

pageElements.text: It’s not just people milling around in the road looking at smartphones who are at risk as pedestrians. (See Christina Tynan-Wood's story on the zombie apocalypse in the modern crosswalk.) It has been in the forefront of my mind lately that it’s dangerous for just about anybody, at just about any time, to cross the street. In the pedestrian-heavy college town of Ann Arbor, Michigan, where I live, the city has gone to seemingly extreme lengths to protect pedestrians, and still: on a summer afternoon, in broad daylight, a college student was crashed into and killed by a car just a few weeks ago. Making matters worse, she was crossing at one of those special HAWK (high-intensity activated) crosswalks with bold signage, wide stripes—and flashing lights to warn that someone was crossing the street. This is what it looked like, and it still wasn't enough.

This kind of tragedy is a motivating force behind Honda’s experimental safety technologies that aim to keep walkers and motorcycle riders safer from collisions with cars. As a bonus, the Vehicle-to-Pedestrian (V2P) and Vehicle-to-Motorcycle (V2M) technology will help protect the occupants of the vehicles, too.

Honda’s experimentation involves Dedicated Short Range Communications, or DSRC. This technology uses GPS and requires that both the pedestrian and driver have DSRC enabled. The pedestrian’s is on a smartphone, and the driver's shows up on a head-up display, as shown here. If the pedestrian has a smartphone enabled with the DSRC technology, it will warn both the pedestrian and the cars around him or her about traffic. Honda says this will be a big help when the pedestrian is not easily seen by a driver, such as when there’s traffic in the way or the pedestrian is stepping out from behind parked cars. Both sound—a series of loud beeps—and an on-screen visual warning are sent to the smartphone and the car.

It’s interesting to note that the vehicle can also get information about whether the pedestrian is on the phone, texting, or listening to music…too bad the pedestrian can’t learn the same about the driver.

Vehicle-to-Motorcycle (V2M) works in much the same way. Its advantage, as Honda explains it, is that the motorcycle can be detected by the car’s DSRC setup even when the driver can’t see a bike, such as when it’s obstructed by other traffic or the surrounding landscape.

Honda has eight vehicles participating in the pilot car-to-car communication study by the University of Michigan Transportation Research Institute. The automaker has also been doing pedestrian safety research for years with its Polar pedestrian safety crash test dummies. The Polar I, II, and III series dummies have helped spur such advances as collapsible hood hinges and windshield wiper pivots to help keep the heads of pedestrians safer in the event of an accident.
