metaDescription: Fast, fun, a little unrefined: that's the 2014 Ford Mustang GT, all right. Read my review, and the responses from our Peanut Gallery, on JeanKnowsCars.com.

contributors.bio:
I am a recent graduate of Boston University thrilled to be working my first real job (in this case, “real” means I never have to use a mop).  I have previously appeared as a lifeguard, a mailroom lackey, a part-time nanny, and a fudge chef, but the real reason I'm here today is because someone once told me I could write and I believed them. As a writer and publisher for BU’s online magazine, I wrote about politics and current events and wrote two series: Foxy Congressperson of the Week, which is exactly what it sounds like, and An American in Paris, detailing my misadventures abroad. 

Growing up in Southeastern Michigan means that love of cars is practically a birthright, and one I’ve always been proud of. I still drive my first car, a beloved orange Chevy HHR that has been through the war and keeps on chugging. After three years on the East Coast, I’m happy to be back in a place where the speed limit is treated more as a guideline than a rule.

pageElements.text:
The Car:

Price: $37,525 as tested (including destination charge)
Engine: 5.0-liter V-8, 420 horsepower
Transmission: Six-speed manual
Fuel economy: 15 mpg city/26 mpg highway
My favorite standard feature: LED sequential taillamps
Option I can’t live without: GT Track package ($2,495)
You might also be considering: Chevrolet Camaro, Dodge Challenger
See more specs on the Mustang in our Car Guide.

What I Think:

If you hang around long enough with people who like cars, you’ll eventually hear someone say, “It’s better to drive a slow car fast than a fast car slow!” to general nods of agreement. I’ve said it myself, and I never miss an opportunity to drive my slow car with reckless abandon. But after spending a weekend in a 2014 Ford Mustang GT, I can report with certainty that the best thing of all is to drive a fast car fast.

The Mustang GT may have four wheels and an engine, but, like all Mustangs, it’s more than just a car. It has fifty years of pony car heritage behind it. It’s the kind of car little kids imagine they’ll own some day, the kind of car people ask for rides in and take pictures of. And the 2014 Mustang GT deserves that respect. It’s not that there’s nothing to complain about—ask anyone who’s tried to squeeze into the back seat. It’s just that it’s so @#*%@ fun that you don’t care.

The 2014 Mustang comes in three flavors: V6, GT, and Shelby GT500. All three are available as coupes or convertibles, and the V6 and GT variants can come as base or Premium models. Premium Mustangs come equipped with a few more comfort features than the base models, including a power passenger’s seat, a Shaker sound system, Sync with AppLink, and a 4.2-inch LCD message center. Options on the Premium model include heated front seats (Comfort package, $650) and navigation (Electronics package, $2,340). The V6 models get their power from a 305-horsepower V-6 engine. All GT models use a 5.0-liter V-8, while the ultra-performance Shelby GT500 models use a 5.8-liter supercharged V-8 to make an astounding 662 horsepower.

The Mustang GT’s key feature is its V-8 engine, which makes 420 horsepower and 390 pound-feet of torque. The engine produces an intoxicating, burbling exhaust note that I liked so much that I often avoided shifting into the higher gears when cruising around town, just so I could hear the engine noise in the cabin.

Our test car came with the GT’s standard manual transmission, which was smooth and easy to operate. The GT is available with an automatic transmission, but I wouldn’t give up the control and engagement of a stick for anything, not even the three extra city mpg that drivers of automatic GTs get.

The manual Mustang GT is rated at 19 mpg combined, a figure I didn’t quite manage during my weekend. (I averaged 18.6 mpg with a mix of city and highway driving.) A more sedate driving style would likely solve that problem, but then you’d miss out on the full-throttle accelerations that make this car worth all the minor inconveniences. I didn’t get the chance to do much cornering in the Mustang, but I could tell that it would be a dream donut car with the traction control turned off.

Like most small sports cars, the Mustang GT is far from practical. It has a rear seat, but it’s really more of a luggage rack than anything else. The Mustang's rear-wheel-drive setup means it might not be a wise choice for drivers who have to weather snowy winters—although it's worth noting that I drove it through heavy rain completely without incident. The interior wouldn’t pass muster in any other $37,000 car; it’s a study in black plastic. The $1,595 Recaro sport seats may keep driver and passenger from sliding around on tight corners, but they’re not particularly comfortable or attractive. The radio and CD player look like something straight out of 2005. That might be a blessing in disguise, though: Ford’s MyFord Touch infotainment system has endured tough criticism since its introduction in 2011.

The Verdict:

So, should you buy it? No, probably not. It’s not practical, it’s not efficient, and it’s not comfortable. On the other hand, neither are any of its direct competitors. If you’re looking for practical, comfortable, and efficient, you’re already looking elsewhere. If you’re looking for fast, fun, and, yes, a little unrefined, look at the Mustang GT. If you love the way Mustangs look but can't quite get over the fuel economy ratings, the V6 model, with its 31 mpg highway, could be worth a look. As for the Shelby GT500: 662 horsepower seems gratuitous, but then again, that's kind of the point.

Peanut Gallery:

Molly: The Mustang made its debut the year after I was born. By the time I was in high school, 1960s muscle cars, especially Mustangs, gave their drivers a lot of street cred in my small rural hometown. In fact, I dated one guy specifically because he had a Mustang. (It was summer.) The interior of the 2014 Mustang GT has kept the candle burning for the original aesthetic, so much so that I think I can still smell smoke in the air. But, since the 2005 redesign, Ford has been honing this thoroughly modern Mustang. The choice of speedometer and rpm dials perfectly incorporates the design cues of the car's forefathers. I regret that I did not get to drive it at night to see them glow. The massive black dash seems sort of cheap in comparison with some modern materials that are available to designers, but I appreciate the nod to the old-school style. I believe that the choice of materials will help this car lend itself to being someone's collector Mustang.

Laura: My dad bought one of the first Mustangs in 1965. Because of the commercial that was everywhere at the time, in which people on the street corner shouted "Mmmustang!" as the lucky driver went past, I remember people actually doing that to us when we drove by in our white six-cylinder coupe. At the time, our family included three kids aged ten and under, so it was a stretch to fit everyone inside. (That's okay; our other family car was a Corvair.) This early experience and a life lived in southeastern Michigan make me like the Ford Mustang almost automatically. I appreciate the black-on-black styling of the one we tested, and I would definitely get the 5.0-liter GT or not get a Mustang at all. The sound it makes probably still says "Mmmustang!" to some people; I felt Mmmortified at the racket I was kicking up, but there's no doubt it sounds just as exciting as it feels. No false advertising here!

Jean: Until just a few years ago, Mustangs were old shoes with big motors. Rude, crude, and a laugh riot to drive. Now they are as hot to look at as they are to drive. Make mine a 5.0 GT or a Shelby. The Mustang logo ought to have a cartoon Road Runner cyclone around its hooves. Giddyup!

title: Werner Herzog's Anti-Texting Film

promoTeaser: The great documentarian shows exactly why we must all stop texting and driving. Watch it right here.
metaDescription: Werner Herzog's Texting Film - I am asking you to spend a half-hour watching the great documentarian's video, and then to consider very seriously never texting while  driving again. That's what I've done. It's on JeanKnowsCars.com.

contributors.bio:
Jean Knows Cars is not just the name of this website; it's a true fact. I have been writing about cars and the car business for more than 30 years, having learned about cars at the kitchen table from my late father, Robert Lienert, who was the editor of Automotive News. At age eighteen, I bought a used car, painted it yellow, installed a toplight and a meter, and joined the Yellow Cab Company in Ann Arbor, Michigan, as an owner/operator. Five years later, I got a job at Chrysler’s test track as a test driver, welder, and mechanic in the impact lab. In 1980, I was hired as a writer at Car and Driver magazine after getting laid off at Chrysler, and in 1985 I left to establish Automobile Magazine with David E. Davis, Jr. I was the magazine’s first Executive Editor, became Editor in Chief in 2000, and added the title of President of Automobile Magazine in 2006.

I’ve been profiled in The New Yorker and have been a guest on the Tonight Show with Jay Leno. I was a guest on the Oprah Winfrey Show, teaching Oprah and her studio audience how to change a tire and to jump a battery. I was Good Morning America’s automotive correspondent from 1994 to 2000 and then did the same thing for the Oxygen network.

 I have won awards for feature writing, car reviews, and my monthly Automobile Magazine column, “Vile Gossip,” including the 2007 Ken Purdy Award for Excellence in Automotive Journalism.  I’m a regular on-air contributor to Fox Business Network; CNBC’s Closing Bell, Squawk Box, Behind the Wheel, and Power Lunch; MSNBC; CBS This Morning and Evening News; and CNN’s American Morning and Headline News. In fact, I would almost call myself a TV slut, but I’m proud to say that I turned Geraldo down.

All of this has taken place in a male-dominated automotive space, where I’m all too frequently the only woman in the room. I know the secret handshake, but JeanKnowsCars.com is going to be a place where you don’t have to. 

I live in the Michigan countryside with my husband, Tim, and the entire food chain. You’re going to get to know my driveway and my dogs really, really well. Just keep reading.

pageElements.text: I have watched the telecom industry’s powerful It Can Wait texting-while-driving public service ad series several times. Each time, it moved me to tears. And then it gradually faded from memory. I know that the personal tragedies that occur at the rate of more than 100,000 each year from texting while driving never fade. That 100,000 number? It’s on the rise even as our driving skills diminish and we find it increasingly impossible to separate our hands from our cell phones.

Now, the famed documentary filmmaker Werner Herzog (Even Dwarves Started Small; Grizzly Man) is having a go at the message. He’s filmed a thirty-five-minute mini-documentary, using subjects from the spots, one of which he directed. (This documentary is co-sponsored by the four major cell phone providers: AT&T, Verizon, Sprint, and T-Mobile.)

I was loath to commit an entire thirty-five minutes online to watching the newest emotional onslaught against texting and driving, but this was Werner Herzog, and I was having my own battle with phone addiction, if not texting, then talking and glancing. And if you don’t think that was a hard sentence to write, read the mail I get every time I admit it. I’m hoping that you’ll admit it, too. And I’m asking you to watch this movie, as hard as I promise you it will be.

The film opens with a woman’s empty hand and dark, haunting music. “I had my brother in my hand, and all of a sudden my hand was empty,” says Aurie, beginning the story of how a young girl ran through a four-way stop while texting and smashed Aurie's little brother Xzavier from her grasp. He lived, but it is difficult to watch that diminished life.

It is equally awful to watch Chandler Gerber’s haunting and excruciatingly detailed description of the day he smashed through an Amish buggy while texting with his wife on his way to work. He was driving into the sun. He wasn’t speeding. He thinks he was reading a text. Watch him tell about what happened, and imagine how easily it could be any one of us.

“I felt like it was just a dream. For weeks, I thought, did I dream that accident?
I’m just a young guy. I got a wife and a daughter on the way. I’m just a guy. This couldn’t have happened to me. That can’t be real. I had to have just dreamed that."
Gerber hit the buggy from behind and ended up 430 feet past the impact.

“My head snapped up, when I…I saw…the windshield just…glass broke…and screeching...and my head. It happened in about a second. As I started coming to a stop, I saw a body come down from off the top of the van. And I thought, ‘Oh my gosh, what have I done?’

“It was totally silent outside the van. At that second in time, there was nobody else coming or going. I walked around back and looked in the ditch. There was bodies just laying there. It was just silent, just quiet. The only sound I heard, the only thing I saw moving was the horse. It was severely wounded, it was moving around on the ground a little bit. No one else was around. Just me and the family that was laying in the ditch, and the horse, and just silence.”
“I wish so bad I could go back to that day. Please don’t do it. Don’t ever text and drive. You get one chance and you live with the choices you make.”
I'm thinking very clearly about the choice I'm going to make.

title: Lincoln Dealership Gets a Make-Over
promoTeaserSmall: Can a beauty upgrade make a new generation of upscale buyers want to spend time in the showroom?
promoTeaser: Can a beauty upgrade make a new generation of upscale buyers want to spend time in the showroom?
metaTitle: Lincoln Dealership Gets a Make-Over - JeanKnowsCars.com
metaDescription: Lincoln Dealership Gets a Make-Over: Hines Lincoln dealership of Plymouth, Michigan, gets a remake to turn the showroom into a nice-smelling, upscale-looking place where it hopes upscale buyers will want to spend some time. Read about the make-over on JeanKnowsCars.com.

contributors.bio:
I am a recent graduate of Boston University thrilled to be working my first real job (in this case, “real” means I never have to use a mop).  I have previously appeared as a lifeguard, a mailroom lackey, a part-time nanny, and a fudge chef, but the real reason I'm here today is because someone once told me I could write and I believed them. As a writer and publisher for BU’s online magazine, I wrote about politics and current events and wrote two series: Foxy Congressperson of the Week, which is exactly what it sounds like, and An American in Paris, detailing my misadventures abroad. 

Growing up in Southeastern Michigan means that love of cars is practically a birthright, and one I’ve always been proud of. I still drive my first car, a beloved orange Chevy HHR that has been through the war and keeps on chugging. After three years on the East Coast, I’m happy to be back in a place where the speed limit is treated more as a guideline than a rule.

pageElements.text: It’s no secret that Lincoln, Ford’s nearly century-old luxury brand, has fallen on tough times. The entire marque is regularly outsold by single vehicles in the Ford brand, and Lincoln’s design chief, J Mays, was quoted in August by the Detroit News admitting that Lincoln isn’t “true luxury.”

But Ford is looking to change that. The automaker has rebranded Lincoln with a new logo and is in the process of overhauling the Lincoln product lineup; the all-new-for-2013 Lincoln MKZ is a sign of things to come. Lincoln is also working to overhaul the customer experience to attract new, younger luxury buyers. A new program for dealers, dubbed Lincoln Academy, aims to change the buying experience right down to the way a dealership smells.

So I paid a visit to Hines Park Lincoln in Plymouth, Michigan, right in the heart of Ford country and Lincoln’s “flagship” dealership. A walk through the showroom proved that the effort at change is no joke. Operations manager Ryan Kolb told me that the entire dealership has just been overhauled this spring. A new service desk is designed to recall the entrance of a boutique hotel. The interior layout is more open, and modern furniture, all in black and white, creates an upscale atmosphere.

Orchids and Earl Grey Tea

The new look comes with accessories. Tables are adorned with orchids and copies of the Wall Street Journal. There are private booths for people who need to work while waiting for a car to be serviced. A signature Lincoln smell, said to bear a hint of jasmine and Earl Grey tea, was undetectable, but I also couldn't pick up the usual dealership scents of motor oil and stale coffee, so we’ll call that a win.
Kolb says his customers love the new atmosphere. “People don’t feel like they’re in a car dealership. It’s just comfortable.”

Hospitality Upgrade Comes with a Greeter

It’s not just new furniture, either. Kolb and five other Hines Park employees traveled to Chicago this spring for a Lincoln Academy training session that focused on hospitality and the customer experience. Quarterly in-dealership visits are planned to bring that training to the rest of Hines Park’s staff. As a result of the training, Kolb brought in a new, full-time employee just to circulate around the dealership and make sure customers feel taken care of.

Will This Bring In a New Crop of Buyers?

All of this attention to the dealership experience is aimed at drawing a new kind of customer to the Lincoln brand. Kolb’s trade-in lot is full of aging domestics, many of them Ford products. He says that “probably 80 percent” of his customers are either A Plan or X Plan customers, meaning they either work for Ford, work for a Ford supplier, or are related to someone who does. Since the introduction of the MKZ, though, interest from other types of buyers has piqued. Kolb says, “We’re seeing people we never would have seen before,” including people who currently drive Lexuses and Audis. “It’s gotten us on the map.”

The revamp of this dealership was expensive. Kolb’s eyes get big and he nods vigorously when I suggest that the remodel was a big investment, but he doesn’t go into detail about money. And with Lincoln’s challenged sales numbers, it seems like a bit of a gamble.  But with the introduction of the small crossover MKC next year (which Kolb says he believes will be “huge” for his dealership), things might be looking up for Lincoln.

No one’s expecting that the scent of Early Grey tea will bring about a magical instant revival for the brand, though. J Mays said recently that Ford is looking at a ten-year investment to bring the Lincoln brand back up to par with its desired competitors. And Ryan Kolb knows his success will depend on continued support and new product development from Lincoln.
“It’s going to take a while,” he says, but he’s optimistic that his investment will pay off, and while he's waiting, his dealership is definitely a nicer place to spend time.

metaDescription: BMW's New Facebook Store: Everything from keychains to spoilers, available without leaving Facebook. Read about the new BMW Lifestyle & Accessories store on Facebook at JeanKnowsCars.com.

pageElements.text: The BMW USA Social Shop sounds like a place where you get an egg cream or a hot fudge sundae, but it’s even richer than that. Starting today, BMW’s Facebook page lets you shop right on the social media site for everything from BMW polo shirts to M performance parts. The BMW fan base is going to love the ability to shop for accessories and “lifestyle” items via a Facebook page.

Why is this any better than going to the regular Shop BMW USA website? Because you can share, Like, and create and view wish lists from your Facebook friends, that’s why. This is what’s known as creating a “social memory” about your love of the German sport/luxury brand. Think of the possibilities: Be reminded of friends’ birthdays, and go straight to their wish lists to order something without leaving Facebook. Comment and give feedback about products you’ve purchased through comment functionality for each individual product. Use PayPal, Google Checkout, or a credit card to close the sale on the site.

Concerned about privacy? You can opt out of sharing personal data, and you don't have to give the app permission to access friend lists, but that would probably spoil the fun of using this page in the first place.
Concerned about the world of marketing making these inroads into social media? Brace yourselves. This might be the first Facebook store you’ve read about, but it ain’t going to be the last.

title: What Are Millennials Thinking?
promoTeaserSmall: As a Millennial, I think I found the key to our reluctance to buy cars. What a new study showed me.
promoTeaser: As a Millennial, I think I found the key to our reluctance to buy cars. What a new study showed me.
metaDescription: What Are Millennials Thinking? New study says it's not true that young people are uninterested in cars. They're just looking at the experience of car ownership in different ways. Plus, they don't have the money right now. Read about the study on JeanKnowsCars.com.

contributors.bio:
I am a recent graduate of Boston University thrilled to be working my first real job (in this case, “real” means I never have to use a mop).  I have previously appeared as a lifeguard, a mailroom lackey, a part-time nanny, and a fudge chef, but the real reason I'm here today is because someone once told me I could write and I believed them. As a writer and publisher for BU’s online magazine, I wrote about politics and current events and wrote two series: Foxy Congressperson of the Week, which is exactly what it sounds like, and An American in Paris, detailing my misadventures abroad. 

Growing up in Southeastern Michigan means that love of cars is practically a birthright, and one I’ve always been proud of. I still drive my first car, a beloved orange Chevy HHR that has been through the war and keeps on chugging. After three years on the East Coast, I’m happy to be back in a place where the speed limit is treated more as a guideline than a rule.

pageElements.text: There’s a lot of talk these days about Millennials: what they want, what they do, why they love the Internet so much, why none of them have jobs. Automakers are particularly concerned about Millennials—loosely defined as people born between the early 1980s and the early 2000s—because they don’t seem to care about cars. Much has been written and said about how slowly kids these days are moving to get their driver’s licenses, and how they are even slower to buy cars.

As a Millennial myself, I was interested in a new study from the website AutoTrader, which was looking to find out if and how young people's thoughts on the automobile differ from those of Baby Boomers and Gen Xers.

I was not at all surprised to learn that it showed young people are interested in cars after all. While it’s true that today’s young people are more likely to delay earning a driver's license than our parents were, we still see cars as an important part of our lives, and we know what kind of cars we want.

Perhaps most important for carmakers, Millennials are much more wary of car dealers than older buyers are. When asked about their dealership experience, only 47 percent of Millennials who had recently bought a car considered their dealer to be trustworthy, compared with 64 percent of buyers thirty-five and older. Worse, 60 percent of the Millennials who had bought a car in the past three months said they felt their dealer had tried to sell them a service they did not want, and 56 percent said they wanted to avoid further interactions with their salesperson. That's interesting in light of the fact that Millennials went to more dealerships before buying (3.1, versus 1.9 for Baby Boomers), and 49 percent said they relied "heavily" on dealers for information, versus 38 percent of Baby Boomers.

This hesitation to trust dealerships could present a problem for automakers, but it’s not one they’re likely to ignore. Ford and Chevrolet are already working on new ways to engage young people. Speaking in a panel discussion on Millennials in Detroit, Amy Marentic, Ford's marketing manager for global cars and crossovers, said Millennials’ attitudes towards dealerships might force manufacturers to change the way they launch cars.

“Millennials want advice from friends and peers, not manufacturers,” she said. Ford is already using social media stars as brand ambassadors for the Fiesta through its Fiesta Movement campaign (right).

Dora Nowicki, marketing director for the Chevrolet Sonic, said in the same discussion that encouraging dealers to embrace technology—and not necessarily relying on face-to-face interactions to sell cars—could help bridge the gap to Millennials.

If you ask me (and why not? I am a smartphone-carrying member of the Millennial generation), the key to the whole puzzle lies in a single statistic: of the Millennials surveyed who had driver’s licenses, 52 percent didn't own a car, and 83 percent of those who didn’t own a car couldn’t afford one. Car companies can tweak the dealership experience all they want, but my guess is that Millennials will happily spend their paychecks on cars just as soon as the paychecks are big enough.

title: My Weekend with Maserati
promoTeaserSmall: What's it like to bid for and win a Quattroporte drive and a VIP day at the races? Let me tell you.
promoTeaser: What's it like to bid for and win a Quattroporte drive and a VIP day at the races? Let me tell you.
metaDescription: My Weekend with Maserati: I bid, and won, on a charity weekend that involved driving a Maserati Quattroporte and watching the Maserati Trofeo racing from the VIP area. Read the story of my adventure on JeanKnowsCars.com.

contributors.bio: I'm a trial attorney, car blogger, and motorsports enthusiast whose idea of fun is going to Detroit in January or watching a six-hour endurance race. A native Texan, I currently live and work in the Austin area. When I'm not in the courtroom, you can find me driving my red Mini John Cooper Works, wrangling my pets or enjoying some delightful Texas cuisine (Tex-Mex and barbecue!). In 2013, I started a blog, Motorista, to document my car adventures and opine on all things auto related. The courtroom is no longer a man's world, and the car world won't always be, either!

pageElements.text: If there’s a life lesson I learned this summer, I guess it is to pay attention to eBay (and JeanKnowsCars.com). You never know what exciting opportunity might be waiting!

My Maserati adventure began with this website. I read an article in early August about an upcoming eBay charity auction for a Maserati Trofeo weekend package. The package included the opportunity to drive a Maserati and attend two days of Maserati Trofeo races at Sonoma Raceway in Sonoma, California, with VIP access to the Maserati hospitality tent.

I live in Texas, where triple-digit temperatures are the norm in August. A weekend in wine country with Italian cars at a racetrack (pretty much my favorite place in the world) sounded like a no-brainer to me. Even better, 100 percent of the proceeds from the eBay auction would go to charity. In other words, I could have a spontaneous bucket-list-style adventure while helping others. Again, a no-brainer.
Much to my surprise, I actually won the auction and, on a Friday two weeks later, I was on a plane to wine country, blinking in disbelief at my extraordinary luck.

At 7:00 on Saturday morning, I arrived at Maserati of Walnut Creek, a brand-new dealership that donated the auction package. The dealership team, including owner Mario Biundo, marketing manager Massimo Cervelli, and service manager Trevor Thomas, instantly made me feel welcome as they gave me my track passes and introduced me to my car for the day, a Silk Black 2014 Maserati  Quattroporte GTS.

The Quattroporte is all new for the 2014 model year and, to my eyes, is even lovelier than its predecessor. I’m not generally a fan of long drives in traffic (particularly the gridlock for which California is famous), but I could have spent all day, and then some, in this car. The driver’s seat is a most excellent place to spend time, and the steering wheel felt just right in my hands.

As a Mini owner, I expected to have difficulty adjusting to a car as large as the Quattroporte, but I needn’t have worried.  Even at more than two tons, the QP is quite agile; while sure-footed and planted, it doesn’t feel ponderous. Maserati reports a 0-to-60-mph time of 4.6 seconds, and, while I never had the opportunity to test that assertion, I can report that the 3.8-liter V8 engine, which makes 523 horsepower, is eager to accelerate to whatever ungodly speed you prefer, without a hint of hesitation or turbo lag.  The new Quattroporte is an impressive achievement.

Our one-hour rally drive to Sonoma Raceway included another Quattroporte, a few Maserati Gran Turismos, and some Ferraris. We avoided the busy highway where possible, snaking through winding back roads, with beautiful lakes and rolling hills appearing in our windows.  The scenery was quite lovely, but our convoy of Italian sheetmetal was the true sight to behold.

Having arrived at the track in grand fashion, I was escorted to the Maserati VIP hospitality tent, which was overflowing with food, wine, chair massages, flat-screen TVs…oh yes, we were also less than fifty feet from Turn Two on the track. This turned out to be a bonus, since Turn Two, uphill and off-camber (meaning that the road slopes toward the outside of the turn), generated a fair amount of excitement, with spinouts and the occasional wall bump.  Two Maserati Trofeo races and one IndyCar qualifier later, I had grit in my teeth and brake dust up my nose.  In other words, I was perfectly happy.

Sunday’s drive to the racetrack was quite a bit less exciting in my rental Chevrolet Impala, but I would have gladly driven a Yugo as long as it got me to the track. Sunday’s races included another Maserati Trofeo race, the Pirelli World Challenge (my favorite racing series!) and IndyCar’s GoPro Grand Prix of Sonoma, which was a tough, physical race, particularly at Turn Two.  It was exhilarating.

title: 2014 Nissan Rogue
promoTeaserSmall: Popularly priced crossover will appeal to people moving up from a compact (or down from a minivan).
promoTeaser: Popularly priced crossover will appeal to people moving up from a compact (or down from a minivan).
metaDescription: 2014 Nissan Rogue: Should appeal to people moving up from a compact or down from a minivan. Great price, too! Read all the details on JeanKnowsCars.com.

pageElements.text: Here's the thing about the small-crossover segment of the auto market: those little vehicles can get expensive. That's why the best news about the all-new 2014 Nissan Rogue is that it is going to be priced starting at $23,350, including an $860 destination charge. Even the top-end model will come in at a starting price of $30,280. The second-best news is that it's going to get 18 percent better fuel economy on the highway than the outgoing Rogue, with a 33-mpg highway mileage figure that's very user-friendly. (Nissan says it expects to lead the class when the official numbers are posted.) And the third-best news is that the Rogue is built on a new common platform from the Renault-Nissan Alliance that will be the basis of up to 2.3 million vehicles worldwide (including the European version of the Rogue, the X-Trail). Plus, the new Rogue, formerly assembled in Japan, now will be built right here in the U.S.A.: Smyrna, Tennessee.

All of those bits of nice information almost (but not quite) cancel out the fact that Nissan Americas' vice-president for product planning,  Pierre Loing, called the Rogue's design a "sonic pulse." That's just weird. Everybody knows that Nissan has a fearless aesthetic: take a look at the Juke or the Quest sometime. And, to be sure, the Rogue's body, especially on the sides, has an aliveness to it that you don't see in a lot of small crossovers. But I would call it something prettier than "sonic pulse." Harmonious, maybe. Or just "good-looking."

So, if you're shopping for a small crossover, you could feel comfortable with the new Rogue looks-wise. More good news is that the completely redesigned 2014 Rogue has wider-opening doors, which is good news for people toting car seats. The new Rogue benefits from a slightly longer wheelbase, wider body, and taller overall height.

The front seats have an optional Quick Comfort seat heater, which does just what you'll be hoping it does on frosty mornings. Among the other options are LED headlights, a power liftgate, and a huge panoramic power-operated moonroof.

Looking at the body leads to the next bit of good news: There's an optional third row of seating. Now, it's really just occasional seating for kids, but it does make this smallish crossover into a seven-passenger vehicle in a pinch. Nissan marketing manager Scott Shirley said the company expects a lot of interest from customers who are moving up from a small car or moving down from a minivan, and the third row option is a value-added proposition for either of those groups. I had a good look at the new Rogue at its official rollout at Nissan Technical Center North America in suburban Detroit. Let's just say I would not want to go on a long drive sitting in the third row. But if I had two kids who sometimes wanted to bring friends along, it would be excellent for that. Plus: check out those adorable tall, skinny headrests the third row has! Love 'em.

Nissan is bringing out the new Rogue with a bang, setting up a microsite to take inquiries and pre-orders. pageElements.text:
Ann Arbor’s summertime cool-car fest.

From the October 2004 issue of Automobile Magazine.

One Friday in early July, the hippy-dippy city of Ann Arbor closes about ten blocks of downtown at noon, fills the streets with cool cars, and has a neighborhood car show till it gets dark at ten. Rolling Sculpture is no concours d’elegance, mind you. No blower Bentleys or Ferrari GTOs or Hispano-Suizas or Auburn boattail speedsters. More like lots of Mustangs, old GTOs and Chargers, and an Olds Vista Cruiser or two. And not all of the “sculptures” are old or historically important. But just the fact that the Earth Shoe capital of the world, home of the five-dollar pot fine and the Weather Underground, has a car show downtown is cool in itself.

We love it and are avid participants, roping off the half-block of East Liberty in front of Automobile Magazine for the family fleet. Our cool metal was somewhat blocked from view this year by the City of Ann Arbor’s new, not so cool-looking alternative-fuel garbage truck which was butted up to technical editor Don Sherman’s spectacular 1967 Corvette. But never mind. By six, the streets were jammed, and we had plenty of lookers. Sherman had brought along two friends to create a sort of Corvette corral, and we also had the gorgeously restored white 1957 Mercedes-Benz 190SL roadster belonging to Craig Layson, whose ownership of Stony Creek Collision, a spectacular body shop, makes him almost a member of the Automobile Magazine family. Ahem.

But never mind those Corvettes. Forget the M-B roadster. Could there have been a cooler car at the show than the Jennings family Fiat 500, parked daintily amid the big-block Chevys? Not on our block there wasn’t. Children flocked around it, pointing and pressing runny little noses against the glass. Old ladies pointed. Foreign visitors nodded and told stories about learning to drive in one. Even Elvis paid his respects.
I like that about the Fiat, and I let kids get in and check it out, much to the horror of my husband. Start them young, I say.

The Fiat is really Tim’s car, a present from me to him on his forty-ninth birthday. We keep it under a tarp in the barn all winter, then air it out in the spring and put it in service to show kids and old aunts and moms the trails through 100 acres of woods around our northern Michigan house. It’s faster and much more stylish than a golf cart.

This year, we hauled the Fiat down from north-woods tour-bus duty and washed it, and I was determined to enjoy driving it fifty miles to town. It went to town, all right. The very next one, eight miles away, before it lost forward motion. Luckily, I couldn’t convince an overnight guest that I was safe driving it alone, that my car was a solid little champ. She was right behind me in a sensible Toyota Sienna minivan when it crapped out. She swept me up from the side of the road, leaving the Fiat forlornly shouldered.

This had happened before to my husband, and I knew it was an easy fix. I just couldn’t remember what that fix was: a simple poking of the throttle linkage back into place. I called the husband away from his appointed rounds, and we went together to sort it out. It was so late by the time we arrived at the Fiat and popped its throttle back into place that we decided to trailer it the rest of the way. I proudly drove the Fiat exactly seven blocks from the trailer to its appointed curb. I was two hours late, but at least I was rolling under my own steam this year.

What is it about this event that causes our cars to crap out? Last year, Layson had buffed up my BMW 3.0CSi, fresh from its mechanical recovery, chronicled ad nauseam in these pages. Somewhere between his Ypsilanti shop and downtown Ann Arbor, out on the interstate, the beautiful blue BMW’s brakes seized up. Layson loaded it on a flatbed, trundled downtown to the car show, and rolled the BMW off into place. (Every old-car owner needs a friend with a flatbed.) The brakes released themselves sometime before the show ended but seized again on the way home. A new master cylinder made a significant difference.

The quirks of cool old cars take some getting used to, but in the case of the BMW (which now has an electrical gremlin), the situation could possibly be helped with regular driving. In the case of the Fiat 500, though, a big wad of gum on the end of that throttle linkage just might be all the fix it needs for a while.

When this year’s show was over, my husband and I jumped into the teensy Fiat and snuck down an alley leading to our car trailer. Tim was driving when, suddenly, we lost all forward motion. I jumped out, ran around to the back, and threw open the engine cover. A small crowd gathered on the sidewalk to watch. I plunged my hand in, grabbed the dangling throttle linkage, and popped it into place. “Try that!” I shouted. It was just like magic, and the crowd was suitably dazzled as he drove off. Ooh, aah. The lady fixed the car. I’m such a faker. If only I’d had a handy wad of gum to add to the show.

pageElements.text: Lately, my son, Cole (17), has been pointing to muscle cars and saying, “That’s what I want.” Part of me, the mom of a little boy who loved Hot Wheels, would like to buy him one. But another part is terrified. I’m not overprotective. I believe kids need to take risks. But nothing in my history with this child has panicked me more than handing him the keys to a car. Cars aren’t toys. And driving—especially for teens—is dangerous.
Even if Cole never drinks, texts, or lets his mind wander while driving—which is hard to believe—he is still an inexperienced driver.

“At this stage of their lives,” agrees Sharon Basel, GM’s safety communication manager, herself the mother of two teens, “teens are at their highest risk for accident, injury, and even death.” In fact, car crashes are the leading cause of death for teens in the U.S., taking the lives of more than 5,000 of them every year. “Teens will get into crashes,” agrees John Ulczycki, vice-president of strategic initiatives at the National Safety Council and DriveItHome.org. “On average, half of all teens get into some sort of crash before they graduate high school.”

Despite my involuntary panic on the topic, I have agreed to help Cole buy a car by matching, dollar for dollar, whatever he saves toward one. I’m not just being a kind and generous parent, though. I plan to use my dollars to buy the safety features that won’t interest him at all. So while Cole is scanning Craigslist for convertible Ford Mustangs in his price range (of which there are—thankfully—none) and saving every dollar, I’m studying car safety.

A lot has changed since the last time I shopped for a car. I recently toured the technology built into a new Infiniti Q50. On that car, you can get a Technology package that includes Distance Control to make the car slow down if Cole drives too close to the car in front of him. It has Intelligent Brake Assist with Forward Collision Warning, so it will warn him if it senses danger ahead and, if he fails to respond to the warning, apply the brakes to reduce the severity of the crash. It will keep an eye on his blind spot and alert him to impending crashes—and, through its Blind Spot Intervention System, bring the car back into his lane if he is about to make a dangerous mistake. Which means that safety systems are number one on my list.

I want all of that technology keeping an eye on him and correcting his mistakes as he learns to drive. But a $40,000 luxury car for a teen’s first car? Out of the question. So how much safety can I buy without slipping into absurd helicopter parent territory? José Alberto Uclés of the National Highway Traffic Safety Administration assures me I’m not likely to go overboard: “Safety should be a parent’s main concern when buying a car for a teen.” And he suggested I research any car Cole wants at Safercar.gov, which rates car safety by model with a star system. Forward collision warning systems, blind spot alerts, lane keeping assistance, and active technologies that brake or control the steering wheel when something is about to go terribly wrong are also on Ulczycki’s wish list for a teen car.
“They are absolutely good safety devices,” he says. “And I am optimistic we will have these features in more vehicles in the near future.” So let's make the list of must-haves, starting with that:

1. As much modern safety tech as we can afford. GM’s Sharon Basel says many warning systems—if not those that take active control of the vehicle—are available in affordable cars now. “There are cars at all price points equipped with forward collision sensing systems, lane departure warning, and blind zone alerts,” she says. “They have been out for a couple of years. So you might even find [these technologies] in a used car.” And if those are too expensive, there are simpler items, such as mirrors that amplify the blind spot, available in the aftermarket.

2. A big-enough car. Technology is not the only criterion. “Safety starts with the size of the vehicle,” says Ulczycki. “Bigger cars withstand impact better. Some small cars do withstand crashes well but I would not start a teen out in a compact or subcompact.”
3. The right amount of power. That muscle car Cole is shopping for? A bad idea. “Avoid horsepower,” says Ulczycki. “If he has a car that can go fast, he will probably drive it fast.”

4. A newer model. At the moment, Cole is driving our 1996 minivan. It’s big and gutless. So I wondered, would he be safer if I withdrew my offer to match his savings for a newer car? “Not when it comes to safety,” says Ulczycki. “Forty years ago, there wasn’t much difference in safety between old cars and new ones. But today, you have only to go back five years to find a huge difference.”

Okay. So I have to somehow convince my Hot Wheels shopping teen to buy something big, slow, and built within the past five years. And, while I’m at it, Ulczycki offered a sub-list of must-have features for that car:
5. Airbags for the driver and side curtain airbags for the passengers. “Even though teens aren’t supposed to carry passengers, they often do,” says Ulczycki. “So keep them safe, too.”

6. Electronic stability control. Kids swerve to pass a vehicle, take sharp turns around corners, and overcorrect. Electronic stability control helps minimize the loss of control. “I believe it prevents crashes and the seriousness of crashes,” he says.

7. A teen harassment system. “Teens don’t wear seatbelts,” he says. (Well, at least not all the time.) “So any device that encourages him to wear the seatbelt is good.” Ford’s MyKey system addresses this by refusing to play the radio until the seatbelt is fastened.
“Teens need to be annoyed into doing the right thing,” agrees Ulczycki.

That last feature is one that usually goes by the name of Mom. So that advice about teens needing to be harassed is one I will keep in mind while redirecting my son’s first-car wish list away from something that will bring his childish Hot Wheels games to life and toward one that will help him keep on living his own.

Is My Seventeen-Year-Old Ready for a Car? August 27, 2013

pageElements.text: I could probably start every Monday with the sentence, “Never a dull moment!” Okay, that’s out of the way. And so were my husband and all four dogs, who’d decamped to the north country for bird-hunting season on Thursday. Seemed like a dream come true! It wasn’t. I was immediately and unrelentingly lonely for the little barking beggars, and the constant cacophony of chainsaw and tractor.

I brought home a gorgeous Dolomite brown 2014 Mercedes-Benz E550 Cabriolet to keep me company, beginning Thursday night with a workout, then dinner on the street in downtown Ann Arbor with my twenty-three-year-old girlfriend Jacqueline. “Don’t take this wrong,” she began. I started to laugh because she does say whatever comes to her mind. “But this is like a hot-mom-mobile.”

Hot car for a hot, rich mom, maybe. Hot because it looks killer—especially with the top down—and rich because it includes flashy options like that special exterior color ($720); custom leather interior ($1,370); wood/leather steering wheel ($590); rear deck spoiler ($350); a package of options that encompasses sound system, nav, satellite radio, rearview camera, and heated headrests ($3,270); and a sport version of the steering wheel and multicontour front seats ($870). And then there’s a full suite of parking aids ($1,290) and enough driver assistance safety nannies to almost make the car autonomous ($2,800).
You decide what you can’t live without, but I can see losing more than $6,000 of un-necessities, bringing the final bill in closer to $75,000.

On Sunday, I drove the twin-turbo V-8 cabrio with the top down to Saint Louis Center in Chelsea, to see its first annual car show, a fundraiser to build a center for the senior residents of the residential and educational facility, which cares for kids and adults with intellectual and developmental disabilities. I had a brother with profound disabilities who lived in a state institution because there were too many children at home for my mom to manage. He died in his twenties, and I wish there had a been a place like Saint Louis for him.

It is run by a Catholic order of priests called the Servants of Charity, started by Father Louis Guanella, who died in 1915 and was canonized a saint in 2011.  There was a lot of blessing going on by the affable Italian priests at St. Louis. They blessed the more than 100 cars that filled the sylvan grounds of the center. They blessed the people who brought the cars, the people who came out to see the cars, the judges, the raffle, and the fifty-fifty drawing, and they blessed everyone’s drive home at the end of the day. I’ve never been blessed so much in one day in my life. All of that and the Mercedes cabrio, too!  If you’re waxing nostalgic about that special Catholic school experience of being stripped daily of your pocket change by the nuns, get your checkbook out and send a fat donation to the very worthy Saint Louis Center.

The week ahead is full, including taping Jean’s Driveway reviews on Tuesday, my husband Tim’s birthday on Wednesday, writing and delivering a speech in northern Michigan, and then flying to Santa Fe, New Mexico, for the weekend for the fourth annual Santa Fe Concorso. It’s the Southwest's premier classic automotive event, taking place September 27-29 at The Club at Las Campanas. In addition to a record field of more than 140 classic and exotic cars, motorcycles, bicycles, and even children's pedal cars, the Concorso leadership has invited artist Dale Chihuly to do something he has never done: place an installation, Red Reeds, on the ninth fairway at Las Campanas, a first at any automotive event. Chihuly will also display his personal 1956 Austin Healey sports car at the Concorso, help judge the Jaguar group, and present the winner of that group with his Midnight Blue Piccolo Venetian with Red Feather Studio Edition.
I love Chihuly, but I’ll be there to honor our heroine: Denise McCluggage. If you are so inclined, come to Santa Fe next weekend. A lot of your friends will be there. - Jean

contributors.bio: I am a freelance writer in North Carolina, and I have been covering technology --including the technology in automobiles--since before Bill met Melinda or any of us met Google. I also write about education, parenting, family travel, and gardening. I currently write the Family Tech column in Family Circle magazine and Family Tech with Christina at FamilyCircle.com, and I blog on the Geek Girlfriends site. pageElements.text: Every time my son gets in the car and drives away, I worry. This isn’t the everyday variety of worry, even though it happens every day. I know driving is dangerous for teens because I’ve seen the numbers: Thirty-five percent of all teenage deaths happen behind the wheel. I also know my son: He is a very distracted teen. Even without a smartphone, earbuds, friends texting him, hilarious YouTube videos, and mobile games in the palm of his hand, he’s always been a bit of a “lost in thought” space case. And eleven percent of all drivers under the age of twenty involved in fatal crashes were distracted at the time. So he and I have talked at length about distracted (and drunk) driving.
Funny thing: I haven't been worried when he walks away.

It turns out I should worry more about his distracted walking, which has more than once caused him to walk into furniture at home. Safekids.org recently published a study detailing how dangerous this common behavior is. According to this report, one in five high school students and one in eight middle school students were observed crossing the street while distracted by technology. I guess it’s not that surprising that pedestrian injuries are the fifth leading cause of injury-related death in the United States for children ages five to nineteen. And given how many teenagers have a smartphone, they are at greatest risk. According to SafeKids.org, “Teens have a death rate twice that of younger children and account for half of all child pedestrian deaths.”

1. Talk to Your Daughters and Sons

As a parent, I obviously need to talk to my son (and my not-yet-driving daughter) about this very dangerous habit right along with all the other risky teen behaviors, like alcohol, sex, drugs, guns, and driving, because statistically this is more dangerous than teen pregnancy or gun violence. But what about when I get behind the wheel? If the kids are all walking around distracted, what should I do to keep from running them over?

2. Realize That Anyone Could Be Walking while Distracted

This study focused on teens. But, according to John Ulczycki, vice-president of strategic initiatives at the National Safety Council: “This could just as easily apply to adults because they are just as distracted. Teens tend to text and play games while walking, but adults are talking on the phone. And the difference in how distracted people are by those activities is negligible.” Ulczycki explains that you can do some things (chew gum, for example) while walking and still focus on walking. But anything that presents a “cognitive distraction"—and all these activities do—means you will not see what is right in front of you. So I guess I have to start driving as if I’m living in a zombie apocalypse--one, that is, where I desperately don’t want to hurt any of the zombies?

3. Don’t Assume They Can See You

Yes. And I can't begin to overstate the zombies’ lack of awareness of the world around them. There may have been a time when I could assume that if someone looked right at my car, they saw it and were likely to do their best to avoid being hit by it. But—in the zombie apocalypse—you can’t make that assumption. A person who is “cognitively distracted,” as Ulczycki describes it, might look right at you and not see you at all. “Their mind is occupied by something else,” he explains. “They are looking but not seeing. Psychologists call this ‘inattention blindness.’ ”

4. And Know That They Might Be Jaywalking

According to the Highway Safety Research Center, jaywalking is also a huge problem. So I can’t assume that distracted pedestrians are planning to stay safely on the sidewalk. If I’m in a school zone or a residential area, I have to assume that pedestrians can’t hear my vehicle because they might be wearing earbuds, and they can’t see me because they are cognitively distracted. It's also important to assume they have no intention of obeying the rules. Better to be pleasantly surprised.

5. As for You: Don’t Drive Distracted

All this is challenging enough for a driver. But if that driver is also distracted by a phone call, a text, or the phone’s navigation software, it’s a perfect storm in which someone is very likely to get hurt. I may not be able to stop those teenagers from walking distracted, but I can put my own phone down when I’m behind the wheel and pay careful attention to the zombie apocalypse that’s happening outside my vehicle. And so can you.

metaDescription: Save Your Car from the Kids: 5 Tips. Step away from the French fries and bent crayons! Here are tips to keep your car clean even though you have active kids on board. Read them on JeanKnowsCars.com.

pageElements.text: Once you have children in your life, so many once-cherished habits go out the window. Your standards change because you have placed needy, messy, and utterly irreplaceable people in the center of your world. So many things that you once thought were indispensable to your happiness—like white tablecloths and immaculate floors—are tossed out like so much used Kleenex.

So let’s talk about that used Kleenex. Does being a parent mean that you can’t have a clean car ever again? Do you need to bow to the smushed French fries and the discarded Happy Meal boxes, and let the old homework sheets and the issues of Time for Kids take over the back seat?

Actually, no. I am as relaxed about cleanliness as just about anyone who isn’t out-and-out gross, but even I have some standards. So here are my five tips for making your car a reasonable environment that you could even invite a childless relative to share with you (without spending ten minutes hauling trash first).

1. Always have a place for trash disposal.

I have observed that children are willing to be tidy if there is an easy, simply understandable way of cleaning up. You can’t expect little kids to fold their disposable trash into neat quarters and carry it in to the house. Big kids, maybe (but probably not). You can expect them to stuff gum wrappers and junk into the fabric map pockets on the back of the seats, where you'll find it a month later, if you don't have a better option that's just as easy.

So have a trash bag, such as one of those thin plastic store bags with handles, right at hand. I often put one on the front passenger's-side armrest, where it won’t fall or spill and it’s under the driver’s control. I definitely dump it every time I stop for gas, and it’s my goal to take it out of the car every day. No trash on the floor or seats = 90 percent of the way to “clean.”

2. Make a place for things that need to stay in the car.

Have a closed plastic storage crate in the trunk or back hatch, where you keep changes of clothes, clean towels, extra shoes, sports equipment, or whatever else you want to leave in the car. This will prevent seeing the soccer shorts lolling around on the back seat for someone to wipe his or her nose on. This isn’t where you put dirty clothes; that’s in item 3.

3. Have a plan for wet/dirty storage.

When my kids were really small—toddler and young elementary age—many were the times I drove them home in only their diapers or underwear because they had jumped straight into the frog pond or totally covered themselves with mud on a hike. You spare yourself hours of interior detailing if you have a wet storage container that separates the muddy socks and the damp bathing suits. Make it one you can easily remove and take straight to the laundry room when you get home.

4. Have rules about food.

Don’t kid yourself that you’ll never let your kids eat in the car. If you spend any amount of time with them, whether taking road trips or just going to after-school music lessons and then soccer practice, they will at least snack in the car. But there are ways to reduce the mess. I always have small kitchen towels on board, and I hand out one per person for their laps and to use as napkins. The towels go into my wet/dirty storage once used, and they have saved the upholstery and my kids’ clothes many times. I also attempt to have everyone eat and then dispose of the trash all in one stop. When (not if) that fails on a longer trip, I go back to rule no. 1 and each person tossing his or her trash into the bag I have cleverly made sure to have on board.

5. Turn car care into “me” time.

Here, I am going against the grain of most well-intentioned advice about child rearing. (It won’t be the first time.) Yes, you can assign your children to take turns cleaning out the car, or stand over them while they remove all their stuff each day. And you should. But to really get that clean-car feeling, the most workable solution I have found over many years is to make it an activity I do for myself, alone. I go off on a Saturday or Sunday, without any kids, and I go through a car wash, vacuum out the car, and get out the Windex and Mr. Clean wipes to freshen the surfaces and get the finger marks off the side windows. It's kind of an enjoyable indulgence, especially when I go out for cappuccino afterward.

Let’s face it: kids are going to be messy, if they’re doing childhood right. Changing the way I react to it has made all the difference in everybody’s life in my family. And I don’t even care if you wouldn’t mistake my minivan for the vehicle of a tidy person.

pageElements.text: Happy anniversary to JeanKnowsCars.com! The actual anniversary was October 5, but we started partying on Friday. We went to a restaurant on the University of Michigan campus for a jolly little lunch, minus alcohol of course. We were blessed because there was a parking space right on State Street in front of the restaurant. We were all piled in a 2013 Lexus LS460 F Sport, riding in style.

The Lexus would not have been beyond the means of the students we saw dining inside with their large Louis Vuitton handbags and designer sunglasses, and all with phones smacked against their ears. It was a lot different scene than when I went to school. My typical dress would have been an India Import maxi dress to the ground, bare feet, no makeup, no underwear of any kind, but always with a very nice nail job. It’s all backward now. I’m looking down at my chipped nails, but everything else is solidly in place, including my shoes.

I was very happy to have this Lexus as a test car because, at a total price of $88,029.00, it is welllllll beyond my means. It’s pretty much the equivalent of my entire personal fleet. It costs so much money that it should have driven me up north. Yes, it was such a long week I was ready for an autonomous experience. Well, at least it was fast and fabulous with its 4.6-liter V8 engine making 360 horsepower. It also had full-time all-wheel drive with a limited-slip center diff, so the pouring rain never fazed it or me.

I was roaring up north, where my husband was at our cabin with all four dogs and a very bad head cold which prevented him from stalking the wily grouse as is his wont this time of year. I was looking forward to the fall color show. It’s so magnificent everywhere in northern Michigan this time of year. We have so many maple trees and so many beautiful pines and cedars that everywhere you look is worthy of a photo.

On Saturday, I ran my errands surrounded by these majestic woods. I stopped by the bank of the Au Sable River so I could see everything reflected in the water. The sun wasn’t out, so my photos are a little bit overcast.

After the stop at the river, I went directly to my favorite Amish bakery on Camp Ten Road, right in the heart of Amish country near Mio, Michigan. There are a couple of bakeries, but the one on Camp Ten is by far the best. It’s called “Bakery.” This is what it looks like. I loaded up on bread hot from the oven, and fresh eggs that were sitting on the counter, but passed all the diabetic-killer desserts like pies, cinnamon buns, cookies, jams, and jellies, but left a donation for Habitat for Humanity.

There is nothing else to report, other than that my one-mile dirt driveway had a half dozen major-league puddles that made me very grateful for the all-wheel drive of the Lexus, and it handled all of them perfectly. I was sad to see my big perennial flower garden put away for the winter. This is what it looked like two months ago. See why I love to come up here?

Just a little calm before the storm that is the week ahead: three days, thirty hot cars, Gingerman Raceway, and nearly the entire staff of Automobile Magazine (those who aren’t working on automobilemag.com and the 2014 Ultimate Buyers’ Guide) gathered to pick the 2014 Automobile of the Year and our short list for the 2014 All-Stars.

Have a great week!
—Jean

title: 2014 Honda Accord Hybrid
promoTeaserSmall: Looking for a car with a mainstream look and feel that gets 50 mpg in the city?
promoTeaser: Looking for a car with a mainstream look and feel that gets 50 mpg in the city?
metaDescription: 2014 Honda Accord Hybrid: The newest Accord posts some impressive numbers: 50 mpg in the city, and 673 miles between fillups. I drove it in San Antonio, and here's my report. It's on JeanKnowsCars.com.

contributors.bio:
I am a recent graduate of Boston University thrilled to be working my first real job (in this case, “real” means I never have to use a mop).  I have previously appeared as a lifeguard, a mailroom lackey, a part-time nanny, and a fudge chef, but the real reason I'm here today is because someone once told me I could write and I believed them. As a writer and publisher for BU’s online magazine, I wrote about politics and current events and wrote two series: Foxy Congressperson of the Week, which is exactly what it sounds like, and An American in Paris, detailing my misadventures abroad. 

Growing up in Southeastern Michigan means that love of cars is practically a birthright, and one I’ve always been proud of. I still drive my first car, a beloved orange Chevy HHR that has been through the war and keeps on chugging. After three years on the East Coast, I’m happy to be back in a place where the speed limit is treated more as a guideline than a rule.

pageElements.text: Does San Antonio, Texas, seem like the right place to launch a hybrid car to you? Texas is land of the pickup truck, land of the cattle ranch, land of the oil wells, with gasoline prices often as much as thirty cents lower than the national average. It’s hard to imagine a hybrid becoming trendy here. But Honda says it makes perfect sense as the place to launch its 2014 Honda Accord Hybrid, so that's where I went.

As old as the cliché is, everything’s still bigger in Texas. To Honda, the Accord Hybrid is big. It may not have a big engine or a lot of cargo space (three cubic feet less trunk space than the gasoline model), but it does have something that no other four-door sedan has: a 50-mpg city EPA rating. Honda thinks that number is a game changer. And here's another one: 673 miles. That's the combined gas-electric driving range of the new Accord Hybrid. Those are big, all right.

A Honda Accord Hybrid makes so much sense, you might be surprised to learn that there isn’t already one on the market. In fact, there was one on the market in the early 2000s, but that model mated an electric motor to a V-6 engine, and it was focused more on providing power than avoiding high fuel costs. Now, Honda is unveiling its 2014 Accord Hybrid, and it's come back with a bang. The new system has not one but two electric motors, to give it that all-important 50 mpg in the city, making it the most fuel efficient four-door sedan in production today.

Honda accomplished this feat with a combination of several fuel-efficient technologies. Its Atkinson cycle engine has slightly different valve timing than other gasoline engines, which helps make it more efficient. It has regenerative braking technology allows the Accord Hybrid’s generator to recapture energy when the car is coasting or coming to a stop, which can help extend its battery-only range.
Honda’s biggest innovation, though, is its two-motor hybrid system, also seen in the 2014 Honda Accord Plug-in.

Honda is at pains to emphasize how seamless this process is. Here's a summary of how it works: The first motor, called the drive motor, propels the wheels. The second one, the generator motor, is connected to the engine and supplies electrical energy to the drive motor and the car’s battery. In this setup, the engine is only rarely connected to the wheels, when cruising at medium to high speeds, for instance. Otherwise, the car will roll along in Hybrid mode (the default mode) or EV mode. EV mode, where the Accord Hybrid runs on power from the battery alone, can last up to a couple of miles in city driving, and once the battery is depleted the car will automatically switch back to Hybrid mode, where the electric motors get a boost from the Accord Hybrid’s 141-horsepower 2.0-liter engine.
With all its various technologies, talk of the Accord Hybrid can get a little academic. So what’s it like to actually drive the thing?

Composed on the Road, Communicative Inside

The Accord Hybrid may not be the kind of car you’d drive around the winding roads of Texas hill country if you could pick anything, but it was stable and sure-footed, and it handled the bends in the road with the composure of a much sportier car. It was also comfortable and not burdened by the cheesy eco-friendly interiors some hybrid cars insist on. No, here you can have comfortable leather seats (standard in EX-L and Touring trim levels) and sleek piano black accents on the dashboard and steering wheel. An eight-inch driver information display comes standard and will show you real-time fuel economy numbers.
A rearview camera is also standard. Instead of feeling self-consciously green, the Accord Hybrid just feels like a regular car: one with slightly decreased trunk space and terrific fuel economy.

So back to that 50-mpg rating: how real is it? Honda is so proud of its class-leading efficiency rating that practically every room the journalists were shepherded into during the two-day trip had a giant “50 MPG ACCORD!” banner hanging in it. The social media hashtag for the drive was #50mpgaccord, and as we stepped into our cars for the morning jaunt, Honda PR reps were on hand to remind us that the cars were rated at, you guessed it, 50 mpg in the city.

Real-World Numbers up to 80 MPG

With all that hype, I almost expected the Accord Hybrid to fall short, kind of a too-good-to-be-true situation. But on my two-hour morning drive I matched the 47 mpg combined rating (our drive was mostly on country roads with 55-mph speed limits), and on an afternoon city driving loop I saw indicated fuel economy numbers in the mid-60s. Some other journalists got 70 or 80 mpg on the same loop.

The 2014 Honda Accord Hybrid may be every bit as good as Honda says it is, but that still doesn’t necessarily mean it’s the only logical choice for hybrid buyers. It drives better than most of its competitors and has better EPA ratings than all of them. But it’s also a little on the pricey end of the sedans-turned-green segment (the Hyundai Sonata, Ford Fusion, and Toyota Camry hybrid models all start in the mid-$26,000 range) and suffers from slightly boring styling. Even with those marks against it, the 2014 Honda Accord Hybrid seems poised to take the hybrid market by storm.

2014 Honda Accord Hybrid

Base price: $29,845
Engine: 2.0-liter Atkinson-cycle DOHC I-4, 141 horsepower, 122 pound-feet of torque;
Total hybrid system power 196 hp
Transmission: Electric continuously variable (E-CVT)
Fuel economy: 50 mpg city/45 mpg highway
My favorite standard feature: Eight-inch driver information display with fuel efficiency data
Option I can’t live without: Leather-trimmed seats (standard in EX-L and Touring models)
You might also be considering: Ford Fusion Hybrid, Hyundai Sonata Hybrid, Toyota Camry Hybrid

pageElements.text: On Wednesday and Thursday of last week, I drove a Porsche Cayman S, and then I drove twenty-six other cars.

I was at Gingerman Raceway on the west side of the state, working out what car would be Automobile Magazine’s 2014 Automobile of the Year. I was exhausted by Friday, climbed into a $113,000 Mercedes-Benz S550, and...wow! I was suddenly ready to drive another 500 miles.

This Mercedes-Benz is brand-new from the ground up for 2014 and highly anticipated because it’s the flagship. And now that there is no uber-luxurious Maybach as part of the Mercedes-Benz family, this would be its replacement as the limo-like sedan, the car that is not only fun to drive but exquisite to ride in.

I never in a million years expected it would look the way it did when I opened the door. It was absolutely and completely silver. Except for the outside, which is Anthracite Blue, a color I mistook for black all weekend. In my defense, anthracite does mean coal, after all.

The first thing you see when you open the door is a mesmerizing amount of silver wood trim. The steering wheel, the doors, the dash—all Metallized Ash wood trim. I couldn’t believe it was only an $800 option. It looked like a million bucks, and it suddenly made the wall-to-wall Crystal Gray/Seashell Gray nappa leather option ($2,290) look kind of normal by comparison.

To bring it all together, every switch, every button, plus the stereo speakers on the doors, was wildly beautifully designed of satin-finish silver metal. Everything you see, including the wheel you’re holding in your hand, is silver. And it is all delicately bathed in an atmospheric blue light. The only thing that was missing was a chandelier to complete the whole LIberace vibe.

Not that the Liberace vibe is a bad thing. And with 449 horsepower and 516 lb-ft of torque, there’s a goodly amount of power backed by a wallop of thrust. Translation: it was an absolute joy to drive. It has a torque vectoring brake system, which in practice means that when you go into a turn, the inside rear brake applies itself just enough to smooth your trajectory. Translation: you can go a lot faster in turns. For such a big car, the new S-class is incredibly agile.
You can also switch between Comfort and Sport mode, which changes the steering and suspension from cushy to boy racer.

Speaking of cushy, let me help you choose your options: the Premium 1 package ($4,500) is where you will find heated and active ventilated front seats, active multicontour seats with massage function (heated massage seat, better than your nail salon’s pedicure chair; it has active seat bolsters that bulk up and hold you firmly as you turn left and right; weird but comforting) and Seat Heating Plus (which heats the seats at warp speed) in the front, among other things. You also want the Warmth Comfort package ($2,600), where you will find a heated steering wheel and the new bar in cold climate luxury, heated armrests. You’ll also find the most amazing rear-seat functions, including hot and cold power-adjustable rear seats, the fast-acting Seat Heating Plus, and rear heated armrests. You can probably skip the Air Balance package that you see here ($350), which is perfume filtration and ionization by way of a diffuser bottle that sits on a little metal pad inside the glove box, delicately perfuming your interior surroundings. Kinda creepy.
And just in case you were worried at all about your back-seat passengers, they have fat, squishy suede pillows on top of the headrests like the pillow top on a high-end mattress.

I didn’t want to stray far from the television due to the opening games of the American League Championship playoffs. We went to dinner, we played golf, we saw Captain Phillips, I cried. We walked the dogs, ate apples, and ran Ray the Stray through the fields. I swapped my winter clothes for my summer clothes and hats. A very tedious thing that we in Michigan do this time of year.

The payoff? The Tigers beat the Red Sox in Game 1. Let’s not talk about Game 2. Let’s just say that if you, the Tigers fan, went to bed early on Sunday night, smirking about our 5-1 lead, you woke up Monday morning to a horrible, horrible surprise.
But I resumed my Monday morning in the Liberace limo, knowing the Tigers were going to win the next one.

Love,
Jean

pageElements.text:
photo at top courtesy of Indian Motorcycles

Hello! I'm the auto and motorcycle critic for the Orange County Register. Previously, I was a staff writer at the Los Angeles Times for fourteen years, writing about motorcycles, cars, green living, and anything else that caught my fancy. If you read my previous article, Falling in Love with Motorcycles, you know that I have logged a few hundred thousand motorcycle miles around the world, have owned seven motorcycles, and have formally tested 200 others as a motorcycle critic.

If you're interested in starting out with motorcycles, congratulations! But first, read my list of Five Things Every Woman Should Know before you get started.

Five Things Every Woman Should Know before Starting to Ride a Motorcycle


1.You need formal safety training. Ninety-two percent of motorcycle riders who end up involved in accidents either taught themselves or learned from family or friends. Motorcycle rider training not only reduces your chances of getting into an accident, it's correlated with reduced injuries in the event of an accident, according to the Hurt Report, the classic major motorcycle safety study. Motorcycles account for twelve percent of U.S. road fatalities, even though they make up less than one percent of vehicle miles travelled overall. Don't let yourself become a statistic.

2. Take the training before you buy your bike. I used to teach the Motorcycle Safety Foundation Basic Rider Course, and I can't tell you how many times students in the class decided they didn't actually enjoy riding or recognized they shouldn't be riding simply from taking the class.

3. Don't feel pressured to buy a first bike that's too large. It's tempting, when first starting on a bike, to buy the dream bike that inspired you to want to ride in the first place. Resist that temptation. More than half of the motorcyclists who have accidents have owned the bike on which they had that accident less than five months, so buy a beater bike instead. Start with a used 250- or 300-cc machine, and ride it for six months first. Doing so will build your confidence and your skills and will also save you money that's easily recouped by selling that bike when you've reached your six-month milestone. And it's likely to save you costly repair bills from dumping your dream bike early on. It might even save your life.
4. Never drink and ride. Not even a single beer. Almost half of the deaths that take place on motorcycles involve alcohol.

5. Wear proper riding gear. Fifty percent of motorcycle injuries are to the ankle/foot, lower leg, knee, and thigh/upper leg, but those injuries are less likely simply by wearing proper gear. Women make up about twelve percent of U.S. ridership and have been demanding higher-quality and better-looking gear that doesn't make them resemble brutish football players.

Whether it's motorcycle boots with slip-resistant soles, armored ankles and leather that won't burn when it comes in contact with a hot tailpipe, or pants and jackets with reinforced joints, be sure to buy it. And make sure you love what you buy, because protective gear can only do its job when it's worn.

contributors.bio: I have spent a lot of time on the road. I started touring with a band along with my older brother, Ryan, when I was still in high school, and in all I have put in a little over ten years of touring. Eventually we were in a band named Thunderbirds Are Now! We played many festivals including SXSW, CMJ, and Pitchfork, toured all over the country and all over Europe, went to Australia, were in a lot of magazines, and had an exciting time. We spent thousands of hours inside a 15-passenger red Ford Econoline van we bought that we called Old Magent. That was where we had our down time. We spent more time in the van than we did playing the shows. When we toured outside the country, we had drivers. My strongest memory of that is being picked up in a Mercedes Sprinter van by someone we had never seen before and being driven through deep snow from Germany to Sweden—a 15-hour drive—through the mountains at high speed. Everyone in the band wrote final messages to our families and put them in our pockets just in case. Touring with a band is very scary but also very fun. A lot of weird and new things happened in my life, but they are great memories I'll never forget, and it was time well spent living a dream that came true. But all good things come to an end. You're up every night, and it just gets hard. I was lucky that my father was a musician and built a recording studio in our basement, and he also shot a lot of videos. I have been recording my own music and making stop-animation video since I was a young kid. After leaving the band, I went to Washtenaw Community College to study videography and won a couple of awards—Most Creative two years in a row, and Best in Show. I was doing freelance post-production video editing when I met Jean Jennings, and we instantly clicked. She likes music, I like music, and we just "get" each other. I've had a very, very strange route to where I am now. I'm happy that I can settle in with Jean Knows Cars and live a normal life but still with a creative outlook.
