Five years later, I got a job at Chrysler’s test track as a test driver, welder, and mechanic in the impact lab. In 1980, I was hired as a writer at Car and Driver magazine after getting laid off at Chrysler, and in 1985 I left to establish Automobile Magazine with David E. Davis, Jr. I was the magazine’s first Executive Editor, became Editor in Chief in 2000, and added the title of President of Automobile Magazine in 2006.

I’ve been profiled in The New Yorker and have been a guest on the Tonight Show with Jay Leno. I was a guest on the Oprah Winfrey Show, teaching Oprah and her studio audience how to change a tire and to jump a battery. I was Good Morning America’s automotive correspondent from 1994 to 2000 and then did the same thing for the Oxygen network.

 I have won awards for feature writing, car reviews, and my monthly Automobile Magazine column, “Vile Gossip,” including the 2007 Ken Purdy Award for Excellence in Automotive Journalism.  I’m a regular on-air contributor to Fox Business Network; CNBC’s Closing Bell, Squawk Box, Behind the Wheel, and Power Lunch; MSNBC; CBS This Morning and Evening News; and CNN’s American Morning and Headline News. In fact, I would almost call myself a TV slut, but I’m proud to say that I turned Geraldo down.

All of this has taken place in a male-dominated automotive space, where I’m all too frequently the only woman in the room. I know the secret handshake, but JeanKnowsCars.com is going to be a place where you don’t have to. 

I live in the Michigan countryside with my husband, Tim, and the entire food chain. You’re going to get to know my driveway and my dogs really, really well. Just keep reading.

Key Points

• There are at least twenty-one other “affordable” mid-size SUV/crossovers on the market that compete in this category, and the Santa Fe is a solid competitor.

• In 2012, the Hyundai Santa Fe was only available with five seats. This year, the five-seat model has been renamed the Santa Fe Sport, and the Santa Fe name is reserved for a stretched-wheelbase, seven-seat model.
• The two-part Santa Fe strategy is part of Hyundai’s lineup plan as it killed off the Hyundai Veracruz.

• This is a very well-heeled version of the Santa Fe with solid safety features, lots of comfort features, including second-row captain’s chairs, which means it only seats six and not seven. Yet it still offers the industry-leading ten-year/10,000-mile warranty.

pageElements.text: I took the 2014 Honda Ridgeline pickup truck home for the weekend mainly because I had a lot of errands to run, and also, who doesn't like to drive a pickup? I’ve owned three full-size pickups in my lifetime, one Ford F150 and two Dodge Power Wagons, all three with big gas-sucking V-8s. The last one—a Power Wagon—I customized under the hood with cherry bomb headers and a distributor I personally recurved for more power, which ensured that a) it would suck even more gas, and b) it would never run right again. But it did make a lot of noise.

If you have a pickup, you know you are everyone's best friend a couple of times a year. So I was my own best friend for the weekend, and I got a lot of errands taken care of in a tidy little truck that I have always loved, ever since it was first introduced in 2005 as a 2006 model.

Not everyone loved it as much as I. It was priced too high (a consideration pretty far down the list of an automotive journalist with free test cars and gasoline), it had a clunky front end to many (which was redesigned for the 2009 model year), and it was wimpy to others, who felt that it lacked all the important Big Truck stats, like towing, bed length, and the all-important V-8. Not that this 3.5-liter V-6 is all that economical at 17 city/21 highway mpg. (This Ridgeline, the RTL model with navigation, comes in at $38,335, including destination.)

pageElements.text: One man’s faults are another woman’s treasures. The Ridgeline wasn’t built for contractors. It is more ute than truck (built on the Acura RDX platform). Its hybrid mix of old-school ladder-frame truck construction and unibody makes it tight, tough, and capable of carrying 1,500 pounds in the short bed. Front-wheel drive makes it pretty easy to wheel around, and the Ridgeline stops a lot quicker than your average full-size pickup.

Honda has never made a V-8 for any of its production cars, don’t you know. And this truck's front-wheel drive automatically switches into all-wheel drive if the situation calls for it. The Ridgeline’s usefulness goes much, much deeper.
Once I spent Sunday morning licking my wounds after the Tigers lost to Boston, I recovered and got up and got about my business, exploiting almost every special features of the Ridgeline.

Job number one: Bring the winter hats home. Yes, I have so many hats that I have to store the off-season collection in a spare closet at work. It’s easy to pack the second row because the 60/40 seats release with the pull of a latch, then flip up with one hand and click in place.
Job number two: Take a couple of bags of clothes and shoes to the Salvation Army.

Job number three: Take toiletries to the women's shelter. I will admit right now that I bring everything home from hotel bathrooms. Everything but the towels and robes. I've been doing it for thirty years. I can't help myself, so now I'm channeling my Polish hoarding instinct. Everything goes into a bag, and when the bag is filled, it goes to the battered women's shelter.
Job number four: Fill the bird feeders at work in between ferrying hats from the closet to the truck.

Job number five: Visit Costco (holy crap, it’s a madhouse!) for storage boxes, specifically for one rather large box to hold my vast collection of the Tiger fan-girl gear, which I am putting away but only until next year.

I call Costco the $300 store, but apparently if you bring a truck it becomes something closer to the $500 store. Ahem. That little foray filled the Ridgeline’s hidden bed trunk and emptied my checking account.

The downside of most pickups is that all your stuff is exposed to the elements. The Ridgeline’s claim to fame is a commodious locking trunk within the cargo bed. Almost everything from Costco fit in the trunk. It’s easy to get to, because the tailgate can be opened like a door as well as in the traditional flop-down mode. The trunk is also perfect for tailgating. You can be the life of the party, fill it with ice and beverages, and empty the aftermath later via a handy drain plug.

Job number six: Grocery shop at the Produce Station on South State Street in Ann Arbor. It’s a hidden gem. I loaded up on heirloom apples and a bunch of other great-looking local fall produce, stowing the bags in the Ridgeline’s front seat.
Job number seven: Pick up the dry cleaning at Elite Cleaners II, on Stone School and Ellsworth, a rare example of an organic dry cleaner.

At this point, I have every single thing in the Ridgeline—the bags of clothes, the bag of toiletries, the dry cleaning, everything from Costco and the Produce Station, and all of the hats in their boxes.
And my purse.

I still had the entire bed free except for a large storage box for the garage—perfect conditions to get a flat tire, as the spare is accessed through the trunk.
The Ridgeline was as useful as I remembered it, not surprising since it’s remained virtually unchanged over its lifetime. The bigger surprise is that it has soldiered on, despite being a tiny blip on Honda’s sales chart. The best year was 2006 (50,193), and Honda never sold more than 20,000 Ridgelines after 2008.
So this is it. The Ridgeline now goes on hiatus for a year, returning completely reimagined from top to bottom. Fingers crossed it’s as clever as this one.

contributors.bio: When I turned sixteen, my dad brought home the very first-generation Ford Escort wagon, and it just so happened to have a manual transmission. Since—like every other sixteen-year-old—I knew everything, I was sure that I would just get behind the wheel and effortlessly shift gears. Visions of screeching into the school parking lot with my shiny red "world car" and impressing all the burnouts who hung out near their Detroit muscle cars danced in my head. All of those dreams were quickly extinguished in the first fifteen minutes of my driving lesson from my dad. Although he has a teaching certificate, patience is not his strongest skill. The subtle foot-hand coordination escaped me, and we were jerking around the subdivision like the contestants in a game of Red Light Green Light. I blamed my dad, and he blamed me. To my astonishment, he decided it was best to abandon ship and allow me to figure out how to get home. Somehow I managed to limp home without needing therapy for whiplash. After our wounds had healed I did end up learning to drive a manual on that trusty steed. I ended up driving my Escort to Northern Michigan University in Marquette, in Michigan’s frigid Upper Peninsula, where I obtained a BFA, with a concentration in Graphic Design, and a future husband. I joined Automobile Magazine at the tender age of twenty-eight and fell in love with the energy and passion for automobiles and the way they enhance our lives. Later, I took a five-year hiatus and boned up my design and web skills and am now turbocharged to be a part of the Jean Knows Cars team. Many years have passed, and now my sixteen-year-old only child is poised to learn to drive a manual, and I can’t help but be transported back to my teens. Unlike my parents, I am a helicopter mom. Riding in the passenger's seat with her behind the wheel is like waterboarding. I want to order her to pull over and allow me to drive and throw her in the back seat with airbags strapped directly on her. Many of her peers will not learn to drive a manual, but I believe that it is the building block for a good safe driver. It is a perfect synergy watching my daughter learn to drive and helping Jean Knows Cars celebrate and embrace the automobile and how it is woven into our lives.

pageElements.text:
Seventy-four times. That’s about how many times I drove the 600-mile round trip between Ann Arbor, Michigan, and Bloomington, Indiana, between 2010 and 2013. Each time, I was piloting my silver 2004 Mercury Monterey, and each time, my teenage daughter was with me in the front passenger’s seat. But today, time seventy-five, I would be driving the 2014 Chrysler Town & Country you see here, evaluating how much the original minivan has matured now that it's turning thirty.

Rose, an aspiring violinist, joined a pre-college music program at Indiana University early in her high school career. It required her to be present all day every Saturday during the school year, plus a month every summer. No trains run between Ann Arbor and Bloomington, and there were no flights that got her close enough—especially considering the expense of flying. So drive it was. Maybe this sounds familiar to you travel soccer parents out there, only in our case, the adventure had a Brahms soundtrack.

You might ask, how in the world could anyone stand to drive 300 miles on Friday night, followed by 300 more miles on Saturday night to get home, seventy-four times over three years? There were only two ingredients I needed: belief in my daughter and her goals, and a minivan.

Say what you will about minivans; you can really get comfortable in one. No, it’s not a fun-to-drive sports car. It’s more like the house your sports car gets parked next to. The basic idea is that it’s your own personal surrogate home on wheels. And I drove the wheels off that Monterey. With Rose’s violin securely packed between the first and second seats, our overnight bags in the back, and frequently a gown in a dry-cleaning bag hanging from the side hook in the second row, we had a routine going.

We liked to stop in Jackson, Michigan, for snacks. The first exit at Fort Wayne, Indiana, was halfway. When we got to the giant bunny outside the Nestle factory in Anderson, we knew we were ninety minutes from Bloomington. More than once, I cursed the state of Indiana for its reluctance to salt the highways in winter. More than once, I found myself unable to make it the whole way, because of bad road conditions or just simple fatigue, and stopped at a motel, which then meant getting up at 6 a.m. and back on the highway to get Rose to the school on time.

We would take turns going in to the gas station for snacks or the bathroom at McDonald's, since we couldn’t leave the violin unattended in the car and she didn’t want to cart it in with her. We'd spend the night with the helpful parents of local kids from the music program, then I'd spend my Saturday hanging out in a cafe, waiting for it to be time to pick up Rose at the end of the day.

But then, the rides home! Luxuriating in Rose’s euphoria when her lessons and rehearsals had gone well; convincing her to recline her seat and nap under a fleece blanket on the times she was disappointed or frustrated in her day. And always, we would listen together to a peculiar blend that only the parents of young classical musicians must know: half Top Forty pop music, half sonatas and concertos.

How many moms get to spend as many hours with their teenage daughters as I did, one on one, with no interruptions? Even though I was mostly watching the road and she was mostly reading, sleeping, or in her own world, Rose and I will always have those seventy-four drives—even if I did use up that Monterey. I’ve replaced it with a sedan, now that half my kids are away from home, but reluctantly.

image.altText: Id 431448 chrysler town and country to college

pageElements.text: Rose is in the middle of her freshman year now, studying violin performance at IU, and on one hand, I am thrilled that I don’t have to make that long drive anymore. On the other hand, I am not used to two months going by without seeing my child, and it was high time I went for a visit. What better way to go than in a newer, fresher variant of the silver van that took us all that way for all those years?

image.altText: Id 431448 chrysler town and country to college

pageElements.text: I climbed in to this attractive silver 2014 Chrysler Town & Country, then, as no minivan virgin. I greeted the ticking of the analog clock on the vertical dash, the high and wide seating, the bus driver grip on the wheel, and all that delicious, nutritious visibility like I was seeing an old friend. I was home again.

Immediately, I started up the shiny refrigerator on wheels and headed off on the familiar route. Aside from the much improved, much cleaner interior, the other thing that changed was that I was alone in the Town & Country.

I only wish I had more people to transport or stuff to carry, but it’s frequently the lot of the minivan driver to fall short of filling up all that glorious capacity. So off I went, happy to reconnect with the easy-to-use Uconnect Chrysler telematics, the tall seating position, and the feeling of being at home in my own living room while cruising down the freeway.
The best part was just going down the road in a minivan with my daughter again. What can make you feel more like a mom than that?

image.altText: Id 431448 chrysler town and country to college

pageElements.text: The safety features on this minivan, appropriately, are first-rate. The blind spot and cross-path detection systems are part of the SafetyTec option package ($1,695), which in practice means little triangles that light up on the side-view mirrors when a vehicle is approaching on either side. I have already established that I am easily addicted to the latest driver alert features like rearview cameras. That’s standard on this car. So, not only are blind spots a thing of the past; you also don’t need to worry you’re going to back over a shovel or a kid.

The comfort features are equally first-rate. The Town & Country has always seemed a little less hip, a little less plush, than the Toyota Sienna or the Honda Odyssey, but hipness and plushness are not what I’m looking for in a van, anyway. And Chrysler has long been ahead of the pack in kid-friendly interiors. Case in point: the Stow 'n Go seats that make the already spacious center row into a yawning cavern of spaciousness. You’ll get no argument from me about the general awesomeness of Stow 'n Go seats. However, when you flip that handle on the side of the seats, you’d better jump back—you, and any grocery bags, purses, or heaven forbid small children who might be standing in the way of that seat leaping to attention and flinging itself closed. It’s shockingly fast and efficient. Also, shockingly easy to use, so that makes it all okay.

The Town & Country S I drove is number two in a lineup of four trim levels. The Touring is the base model, and there’s a Touring-L and an ultraluxe Limited model of the Town & Country above the S. But, even on the S, you’ll find seventeen-inch black-painted wheels, an entertainment system featuring Blu-Ray for the second and third rows, with one fold-down screen per row, and cloth and leather seats. Bonus: S lettering on the front seats. Gracious living by minivan!

This year, there's also a 30th Anniversary special edition. Thirty years seems like a long time, but I clearly remember when the first ones came out, in 1983. I was at a Chrysler dealership, a young, broke single woman looking for a cheap car, and the salesman tried to get me interested in the just-released Dodge Caravan. "This will hold seven people!" he enthused. "Well, I don't have seven people," was my very reasonable response. I got that it was groundbreaking, but I didn't realize how soon I actually would have a family of six and be glad minivans had been invented. In fact, before I had the Mercury, I owned a 1996 Town & Country, and I drove it for almost a decade.

The Town & Country was pretty refined by the mid-1990s, but the very first minivans of the Eighties were a little, well, underpowered. I think it was Tom and Ray Magliocci of Car Talk who used to joke that you needed to take seven people so six of them could get out and help push it up hills. The Chrysler minivans have come a long, long way since then, selling more than 13 million and adding power, amenities, and luxury as market appetites have evolved.

Cruising along I-69 heading south through Fort Wayne and Indianapolis, I appreciated the perfectly adequate power of the V-6 with its 283 horsepower. I am pretty sure I used it all as I passed dozens of trucks on the unremarkable flat roads of the northern Indiana landscape. But Chrysler is thinking about fuel economy, too, fitting the Town & Country with a fuel economizer function; just push the Econ control, and the engine adjusts to operate at lower speeds while the transmission shift pattern is changed, garnering 25 mpg on the highway.

image.altText: Id 431448 chrysler town and country to college

pageElements.text: Eventually, I arrived on IU's leafy campus. Nearly all the buildings are made of the justly famous local limestone (fun fact: the area around Bloomington is called the Stone Belt, home of one of the world's largest limestone deposits). It's also a Big Ten school, with all of the football and basketball craziness that entails, but, more important to my family, it's the home of the Jacobs School of Music. The other kids on campus may be partying it up, but Rose is totally geeked to go to a school with a 55,000-square-foot music library and five orchestras.

image.altText: Id 431448 chrysler town and country to college

pageElements.text: I had business to handle: a trip to Target to replenish dorm supplies, and a recital to attend. I was reminded that, dang, teenage girls use a lot of personal-care products. Those add up at the cash register. I also realized that it was unbelievably great to hear Rose perform after two months away from the sounds of her daily practice. But the best part was just going down the road in a minivan with my daughter again. What can make you feel more like a mom than that?

You just don’t know what you have—whether the sound of violin music or just the sound of your child’s voice—until it’s gone. And that goes for minivan ownership, too. I already miss owning one. It gave me my own private comfort zone that could take whatever, or whoever, wherever we needed to go.
Minivan ownership is a lot like parenting in general: most of the time, it’s not about your fun or your needs. But that doesn’t mean it won’t give you some of the happiest times of your life anyway.

contributors.bio:
I am a recent graduate of Boston University thrilled to be working my first real job (in this case, “real” means I never have to use a mop).  I have previously appeared as a lifeguard, a mailroom lackey, a part-time nanny, and a fudge chef, but the real reason I'm here today is because someone once told me I could write and I believed them. As a writer and publisher for BU’s online magazine, I wrote about politics and current events and wrote two series: Foxy Congressperson of the Week, which is exactly what it sounds like, and An American in Paris, detailing my misadventures abroad. 

Growing up in Southeastern Michigan means that love of cars is practically a birthright, and one I’ve always been proud of. I still drive my first car, a beloved orange Chevy HHR that has been through the war and keeps on chugging. After three years on the East Coast, I’m happy to be back in a place where the speed limit is treated more as a guideline than a rule.

pageElements.text: There are still green leaves on some of the trees in Ann Arbor, and it has barely even dipped below freezing here (yet). But Halloween was almost two weeks ago, so green leaves or no, it’s holiday shopping season. And that means luxury carmakers are clamoring for the attention of high-end shoppers. To this end, Aston Martin and Cadillac have teamed up with retailers Neiman Marcus and Saks Fifth Avenue, respectively, to showcase their wares to their target audiences.

2014 Aston Martin Vanquish Volante, Neiman Marcus Style

Aston Martin is using a spot in Neiman Marcus’s famous Christmas Book to entice shoppers. They’re offering an extremely exclusive Neiman Marcus edition of the 2014 Aston Martin Vanquish Volante, as shown above. Only ten will be made, and they’ll feature a unique exterior color: NM Exclusive Seychelles Blue. It’s also got all the normal (if you can call them that) benefits of driving a Vanquish Volante: a 100 percent carbon fiber shell, a normally aspirated 6.0-liter V-12 engine making 565 horsepower and 457 pound-feet of torque, a 180-mph top speed, and, of course, the satisfaction of owning an Aston Martin.
All this could be yours (or your loved one's) for just $344,500. The department store will donate $3,000 to the Heart of Neiman Marcus Foundation for every Neiman Marcus Aston Martin sold.

2014 Cadillac ELR, Courtesy of Saks Fifth Avenue

Cadillac is getting in on the holiday shopping game with a window display at Saks Fifth Avenue’s flagship store in New York City featuring the 2015 Cadillac Escalade, and a spot in the Saks Holiday Catalog for the brand-new 2014 Cadillac ELR. The window display will be unveiled on November 25, featuring a 2015 Escalade in the act of breaking through a wall of faux ice.

Drivers looking for something a little more eco-friendly should check out the Saks Fifth Avenue catalog, where you can find a Cadillac ELR for $89,500. The ELR is a plug-in extended-range coupe; its drivetrain is similar to that of the Chevrolet Volt. These ELRs will be available exclusively in White Diamond.

Buyers can choose between a Light Cashmere or Jet Black interior and will have access to their own concierge service. Only 100 will be sold. Purchase of this limited-run package – also includes installation of an upgraded 240-volt charging station for the ELR’s 16.5 kWh battery pack. The battery can provide about thirty-five miles of all-electric range.

Luxury cars may not be in the cards for all of us this holiday season, but it’s still fun to see the lengths carmakers will go to to snag the coveted upscale shopper. Are you more tempted by the sultry Vanquish Volante or the slightly more practical (but still gorgeous) ELR? Let us know in the comments below.

title: 2013 Subaru Impreza 2.0i Premium
promoTeaserSmall: Does love, plus a fresh Top Safety Pick Plus designation, make this all-wheel-drive car a must-have?
promoTeaser: Does love, plus a fresh Top Safety Pick Plus designation, make this all-wheel-drive car a must-have?
metaDescription: 2013 Subaru Impreza 2.0i Premium: A lot of people love this car, but is love enough to make you want to buy this Subaru? Read about it on JeanKnowsCars.com.

pageElements.text:
Price: $21,065 base, $22,637 as tested (including destination charge)
Engine: 2.0-liter horizontally opposed four-cylinder, 148 horsepower
Transmission: Five-speed manual
Fuel economy: 25 mpg city/33 mpg highway
My favorite standard feature: All-wheel drive
Option I can’t live without: Leather-wrapped steering wheel and shift knob
You might also be considering: Honda Civic, Hyundai Elantra, Mazda 3, Toyota Corolla, Volkswagen Jetta

See more specs on the Subaru Impreza lineup in our Car Guide.

What I Think:

Lots of automotive brands have their adherents. You probably know Honda people, BMW stalwarts, and people who would only buy a Ford. (Some of those are in my own family.) But perhaps nobody is quite as unwaveringly loyal as the Subaru person. We could go into some stereotypes about Birkenstocks and recycling and the state of Vermont, or we could just accept that there are many perfectly wonderful people who want a timeless, reliable all-wheel-drive vehicle that will not surprise them or let them down, and Subaru does it for them. That “Love. It’s what makes a Subaru a Subaru” campaign is no joke. I have known dozens of people who swear by these hardy perennials and wouldn’t dream of driving anything else.

Timeless was indeed the first thing I thought of when stepping inside this 2013 Impreza 2.0i in Premium trim. “Timeless” as in, time has stood still. Every bit of the interior, from the waiting-room seat fabric to the throwback single-CD screenless radio, felt like 1999, or older. Where other small sedans in the Impreza’s class are making great strides in modernizing and adding technology, this car is holding fast to the good old days. Having said that, it doesn’t only look fifteen years old, it looks like it will last fifteen years into the future without showing a lot of wear and tear, and that could be a good thing.

And it’s not all old school: there’s Bluetooth hands-free phone connectivity and a USB port for your iPod. The uplevel Limited (which starts at $23,265) has a 4.3-inch LCD display screen and HD radio. Premium and Sport Limited models can also have voice-activated navigation, bundled with a moonroof ($2,200), which gets you a 6.1-inch touchscreen. The 2014 model is little changed from the 2013 we tested; it adds a standard rearview camera on the Limited, plus Aha infotainment and smartphone integration added on to the still-optional navigation package.

But the technology a Subaru shopper is interested in goes deeper under the skin. Subaru has been selling a full lineup of vehicles with its Symmetrical All-Wheel-Drive system since 1972, and every Subaru it sells in the U.S. market has had it since 1997—with a single exception at the moment, the sporty little rear-wheel-drive BRZ. A lot of today’s hard-core Subaru loyalists were created in snowy climates at a time when all-wheel-drive vehicles were rare and those you could get were trucklike (or trucks).

It is also an almost lovable trait of Subarus that they have horizontally opposed, or boxer, engines. This engine type, which has a lower center of gravity and is supposedly both more efficient and more durable, is a Subaru hallmark. Paired with a continuously variable transmission or, in the case of the car we tested, a five-speed manual, the Subaru Impreza’s mechanics are just not quite like other compact cars in its class.

In practice, this car doesn’t just have a different type of engine; it really sounds and feels different to drive down the road. The first few times I accelerated up to around-town speeds in the lower gears, I was afraid something was wrong with the car; that’s how much racket it kicked up. What Jean called a sewing-machine-like sound (below) was not at all like a "normal" inline four-cylinder engine sounds like, let me put it that way. On the other hand, get the Impreza onto the highway, and it’s surprisingly peppy and able for a four-cylinder engine that makes 148 horsepower. It took only a few drives until I was used to its eccentric sound quality and could tune it out to appreciate how sturdy and no-nonsense the Impreza really is.

I didn’t tune out the price, though: who else makes an all-wheel-drive sedan that goes out the door for under $23,000—one that gets 33 mpg on the highway? One that got five stars in the NHTSA rollover test, and the 2014 model of which was just named an Insurance Institute for Highway Safety Top Safety Pick Plus? Kind of makes me want to drive to Vermont. When there’s snow in the forecast.

The Verdict:

There are a few vehicles with all-wheel drive that come in under $25,000: the Nissan Juke and the Kia Sportage, for example. But if you want an all-wheel-drive car in a traditional four- or five-door body style, a Subaru Impreza is a very rational choice. Despite its conventional compact-car appearance, though, it’s not a very average choice. You’d want to buy one of these if you really need (or just want) all-wheel drive, if you buy into the Subaru brand identity, and if you are a highly practical car buyer looking for something with a value price that you can drive for years and years. You wouldn’t want to buy one if you’re looking for a buttery-soft, whispery-quiet driving experience, or if you have to have the latest gadgetry and goodies on board.
Like oysters, vacations in the Arctic, and the music of Schoenberg, the Subaru is an acquired taste, but if it’s to your taste, nothing else might do.

Peanut Gallery:

Annie White: One of my first attempts at driving a stick shift was on my father's Subaru Impreza WRX. The clutch was much twitchier than the one on the Saab 9-5 I'd tried earlier in the week, and the lesson ended in disaster. I've been wary of Imprezas ever since, even though I've now mastered the art of shifting. This Impreza still has a rough quality to shifts—especially in low gears—that I don't mind in a sporty car, but feels out of place in something with fewer than 150 hp. I just couldn't quite figure this car out.

Molly Jean: The curtains don't match the rug. On the outside the Impreza looks modern, but once you get inside it just feels old. That being said, it is classically old. Everything makes perfect sense, and the choice of materials seems built to last. I am confident that if you buy this car today your grandchildren can drive it to college—and everything would still work. If you want a car that you can drive the wheels off buy an Impreza today, but if you love technology and a modern interior you will need to keep looking.

Jean Jennings: The Impreza is old school—nothing sexy— but I’m pleased to note an interesting curvy rear and a strong grille that is most noticeable without following the latest bigger-is-better design trend.

It’s also not sexy inside, all black on black on black with hard plastic relieved only slightly by a small amount of soft surface on the doors and the tiniest bits of chrome and satin metal trims. There’s not a lot of extra padding anywhere, allowing the steady, sewing-machine-like ticking of the engine to filter through to the interior, which is graced with large buttons and rotary switches and little cubbies everywhere.

Here’s what’s important. You will love driving the Impreza, the impeccable foundation for the mighty Impreza WRX. The five-speed manual is so creamy, you can teach shifting lessons with it. Steering is responsive, totally connected, with crisp turn-in. The seats are simple and supportive with well-bolstered bottom and sides. This basic Impreza is good; it makes perfect sense that the WRX is so hot to drive.
One last consideration: The Insurance Institute for Highway Safety just awarded the 2014 Subaru Impreza its rare Top Safety Pick Plus.

title: iPhone Is My Co-Pilot
promoTeaserSmall: Four smartphone mapping apps that are easier to use than an in-dash navigation system.
promoTeaser: Four smartphone mapping apps that are easier to use than an in-dash navigation system.
metaDescription: iPhone Is My Co-Pilot: Four smartphone mapping apps easier to use than an in-dash navigation system. Read about it on JeanKnowsCars.com.

contributors.bio: Liane Yvkoff dipped her toe in the pool of automotive writing five years ago and fell directly into the deep end. Since then, she has written about cars for CNET.com, AutoUSA.com, Babble.com, and, oddly enough, Hustler. Residing in the Seattle area, she obviously drives a Subaru Outback.

pages.metaDescription: Four smartphone mapping apps easier to use than an in-dash navigation system.
pages.metaTitle: My iPhone is my co-pilot: 4 mapping apps better than in-dash navigation systems
pages.name: index

pageElements.text: The steering wheel is my car’s only factory-installed navigation system, and NPR is as close as my aging Subaru Outback comes to offering “infotainment.” But that doesn’t mean that I don’t have state-of-the-art software routing me around traffic backups or helping me find that trendy new pop-up restaurant. Smartphones, with their sophisticated mapping applications, have filled the gap for vehicles not equipped with navigation systems. In many cases, mobile navigation apps provide an easier-to-use interface with more accurate data, making in-dash navigation systems about as cutting edge as a toaster oven. If you’re wondering how to get turn-by-turn directions in your old car without buying a new one, consider these options:

1. Apple/Google Maps/Bing Maps

Your mobile phone is equipped as standard with one of the best navigation systems on the market, and the best part is that it’s free. These days, native maps apps offer turn-by-turn directions that can stream through some vehicle stereo systems. Instead of memorizing a slow, complex menu tree, drivers can easily dial up directions using spoken, natural language voice commands and search intuitively within the map for nearby addresses.  Another upside is that map information is up to date, and you don’t have to pay to upgrade. The downside is that if you don’t have great cell phone reception, well, you had best hope there’s an open gas station nearby.

Apple Maps
Google Maps for Apple at App Store
Google Maps on Google Play
Bing Maps 3D for Windows Phone

2. Inrix Traffic Maps, Routes, and Alerts

This traffic-centric app the leading choice for commuters with tight drop-off schedules because it offers the most detailed en route traffic reports. Inrix uses current and historical data to predict travel time for a list of saved destinations, and advises the best time to depart to get there. Setting apart Inrix from other apps are real-time fuel prices (for premium customers), live traffic cams, and push notifications alerting you of police radars in the area. Plus, it's free.

Inrix App for Apple at App Store
Inrix App on Google Play
Inrix App for BlackBerry
Inrix App for Windows Phone
Inrix App for Windows

3. TomTom

Since TomTom licensed its maps data to power Apple’s Maps, it’s hard to justify buying or subscribing to this spendy app. But unlike the free product, TomTom stores the map data on your mobile device, so you don’t need a data connection to get where you’re going, which is ideal for drivers in remote locations. Another feature available only with TomTom: the ability to purchase voices for the navigation prompts.

TomTom U.S.A. for Apple on the App Store ($49)
TomTom Places on Google Play ($45.99)

4. Waze

Powering the free Waze app is a dedicated community of road warriors committed to letting others know when streets close, when accidents happen, and when traffic just generally sucks. Community-supported mapping means that Waze offers a level of detail, such as known speed traps or red light cameras, and up-to-the-minute accuracy other apps miss. Further separating it from the competition is the ability to connect with other Waze-using friends on Facebook so you can know where and when everyone will arrive. The downside is that if you don’t live in a area with a lot of Waze users, you may experience stale content.

Waze Social GPS for Apple on the App Store
Waze Social GPS on Google Play
Waze Social GPS for Windows Phone

title: Certified Pre-Owned Cars: 5 Tips
subTitle: Interested in a Certified Pre-Owned used car? So are lots of people. How to be a smart CPO shopper.
promoTeaserSmall: Interested in a Certified Pre-Owned used car? So are lots of people. How to be a smart CPO shopper.
promoTeaser: Interested in a Certified Pre-Owned used car? So are lots of people. How to be a smart CPO shopper.
metaKeywords: shopping for a Certified Pre-Owned Car
metaDescription: Certified Pre-Owned Cars: 5 Tips. Interested in a Certified Pre-Owned used car? So are lots of people. How to be a smart CPO shopper. Read about it on JeanKnowsCars.com.

pageElements.text: If you've shopped for a car in the past several years, you've surely heard about Certified Pre-Owned cars. Starting as a way to market higher-end used cars, the Certified Pre-Owned designation has now become commonplace at car dealerships. A Certified Pre-Owned (CPO) car is generally a car with a clean history, few past users, of relatively recent vintage, and with less than about 80,000 miles on the odometer. It undergoes an extensive pre-sale inspection, and problems are fixed before it's offered for sale. What's not to like? Of course, all of this means that your average CPO car is sold at a premium, but for the peace of mind you get, it is often well worth the cost.
If you are interested in a used-car purchase, here are five things to know about CPO.

1. Used cars aren't just for those who can’t afford new anymore. CPOs are increasingly popular among premium brands. For example, CPO sales of Audis have just set a seventh straight monthly record, with 3,161 certified used Audis sold in January 2014, compared with 2,843 one year earlier. Brands such as Mercedes-Benz, Jaguar, and Cadillac all have firmly established CPO programs, and even Porsche sold more than 800 CPOs in January 2014. If you want a high-end car but don't want to pay a high-end price, a Certified Pre-Owned car might be the ticket for you.

2. Don’t think of Certified Pre-Owned as simply a marketing gimmick. CPO sales were up fifteen percent last year, and the Manheim Used Car Market Report projects they’ll double by 2019 or even sooner. In January alone, more than 166,000 were sold in the U.S. market, while new-car sales dropped three percent. Clearly the concept is finding buyers, and with so many people leasing cars, dealers find themselves with an increasing quantity of reasonably “young” vehicles with one owner that are good candidates for a CPO sale. You could get a great deal on a low-mileage used car by taking advantage of that.

3. Understand all the benefits of a Certified Pre-Owned program. A benefit of CPO programs is that the car you're looking at will come with an extensive inspection report (more than 150 points are checked out under most CPO programs), and you’ll get a Carfax (or similar) report on the vehicle’s history. Read them!

You can often finance a CPO purchase at or close to the same low interest rates you'd get on a new-car purchase. Other perks: the power to take a car back within a specified time limit if you're not happy with it, and sometimes, a free loaner vehicle if your CPO purchase comes in for repairs at the dealership. And find out details about the roadside assistance that is usually offered. So much better than trusting someone you met on Craigslist.

4. Know that all CPO programs aren't alike. You need to understand where the Certified Pre-Owned designation is coming from. There are CPO programs that are run through the manufacturer, but dealerships sometimes offer their own, which are not as desirable: If the CPO program is through the manufacturer, not just the local dealership, any warranty repairs you do need can be performed anywhere around the country. That's a strong argument in favor of the automaker's program.

There are also CPO programs run by other entities. The Motor Trend Certified program, from our brother publication Motor Trend, is one. It partners with a limited number of dealerships around the country, offers Carfax reports for vehicle history, and throws in such goodies as key replacement and paint-shop blemish removal and six months' mechanical repair coverage. There are also CPO programs through the Enterprise car rental company, the National Independent Automobile Dealers Association (NIADA), and others.

5. Know the warranty details and potential hidden costs. A Certified Pre-Owned car often comes with two kinds of warranties: the powertrain limited warranty that the car had as new, which is continued for the new owner; and a warranty on problems that come up elsewhere on the car, which may or may not cost extra. The "certified" in the Certified Pre-Owned title can mean different things in different programs.

For example, a CPO from Ford comes with a twelve-month, 12,000-mile comprehensive warranty on a long list of components—the kind that older cars might tend to need replaced, such as the alternator, ball joints, air conditioning compressor, and power door locks. All good news! However, there’s a $100 warranty deductible for each visit to the shop.  For Toyota, the deductible on similar warranty coverage is $50; for Mercedes-Benz, it’s $0.

Dealerships and other CPO providers may also offer an extended warranty that you have to buy separately, which could be a substantial extra cost. Make sure you understand the terms, including the deductible, for repairs under the warranty, and whether any of the warranties are transferable should you sell the CPO car down the road.

title: 2014 Ford Edge
promoTeaserSmall: A sport-utility vehicle, but one that loves technology.
promoTeaser: A sport-utility vehicle, but one that loves technology.
metaDescription: 2014 Ford Edge is a sport-utility vehicle that loves technology. Read our review of the new model on JeanKnowsCars.com.

pageElements.text: The Edge is a place where you find balance. This SUV crossover is not too big, not too small. Not too rich. Not too poor. It’s roomy, capable of hauling your family and your stuff—the rear seats and the front passenger seat lie down to accommodate more gear—yet the 2.0-liter EcoBoost engine is rated at up to 30 mpg. It’s an affordable mid-size SUV that comes in four series: SE, SEL, Limited, and Sport, each with a choice of engines. Yet some models come standard with rich luxuries like heated seats. One area where the Edge can boast about going  overboard, though, is technology. It sports blind-spot-aware mirrors that light up if something is in your path. Sync  with MyFord Touch has Wi-Fi capability, text-to-voice, HD Radio, and voice-activated Navigation—on an eight-inch screen—so you don’t have to disconnect from your peeps or your tunes to hit the road. Speak to place a call, control the atmosphere, or choose some music, and play it all through the standard Sony stereo system. A rearview camera lets you see behind when you put the car in reverse. There is plenty of technology here to keep you safe, as well, from the MyKey system that will harass your teen into wearing a seatbelt when he or she drives to the post-crash alert system that will dial 911 if the car senses an accident.

title: Secrets of Crash Testing
promoTeaserSmall: You've heard of IIHS Top Safety Picks. Want to see how the insurance group preps cars? Video here.
promoTeaser: You've heard of IIHS Top Safety Picks. Want to see how the insurance group preps cars? Video here.
metaDescription: Secrets of Crash Testing: What the Insurance Institute for Highway Safety does to cars before it puts them to the test, with video. See it on JeanKnowsCars.com.

pageElements.text: Every savvy shopper knows to look at crash test and safety ratings from IIHS and NHTSA when shopping for a new car these days. Cars are far safer now than at any time in the past, and don’t overlook crash test ratings as one reason for that. The Insurance Institute for Highway Safety (IIHS) is one of the big two crash testers. It’s a nonprofit organization backed by the insurance industry. The other is the National Highway Traffic Safety Administration (NHTSA), a federal government agency.

Have you ever wondered how the cars that are being crash tested are set up so that they’re being compared with other cars on a level playing field? I know I have, and IIHS has just released this interesting video that explains how.
<iframe width="480" height="270" src="http://www.youtube.com/embed/mHhSizn8hMM?feature=player_embedded" frameborder="0" allowfullscreen></iframe>

Wow. Raise your hand if you thought they just chucked a crash test dummy in there and let ‘er rip? I kind of did. Well, actually, it makes sense to me that, before testing, they have to position the seats exactly the same in every car and set up the cameras and lights in the same way each time. But it wouldn’t have occurred to me that IIHS has to drain all fluids from the car and replace gasoline with a purple solvent to detect leaks. It’s like an automotive angiogram!

• Related stories:

    Understanding the New Crash Tests October 1, 2013
    Crash Tests for Dummies August 14, 2013

The IIHS puts cars through five kinds of crashes: moderate overlap front, small overlap front, side, roof strength, and head restraints. Grades are good, acceptable, marginal, or poor on each test. IIHS’s Top Safety Pick and Top Safety Pick + awards are highly sought after, and to get the + designation, a car has to earn a Good rating on four of the five tests and no lower than Acceptable in the fifth. Automakers care deeply about these ratings, and so should you.
If you aren’t checking out your next car’s IIHS safety ratings here, you should. Has a safety rating directly affected your choice of car? Comment below!

title: 2015 Chevrolet Colorado: L.A. Show
promoTeaserSmall: This good-looking pickup should juice up the mid-size truck market. A diesel's coming, too.
promoTeaser: This good-looking pickup should juice up the mid-size truck market. A diesel's coming, too.
metaDescription: 2015 Chevrolet Colorado: L.A. Show

contributors.bio: I am a car geek dating back to my childhood, when I took notice of the various sizes, shapes, and designs of cars. I named all of our family cars and cried when they reached the end of their useful life. I’ve been mentally composing automotive reviews for years, but it wasn’t until some years ago, when I read one of Jean Jennings's columns while waiting for an appointment, that I realized that it was possible. And here I am… grateful and enjoying every second. My next goal in life is to learn to drive a manual.

pageElements.text: At the Los Angeles Auto Show this morning, the debut of the 2015  Colorado was announced with a booming country-rock soundtrack and a light show worthy of the Los Angeles setting. This tough little truck isn't Hollywood fluff, however. It's a solid contender that can be asked to do most of what a bigger truck can do while giving truck buyers a choice in the mid-size segment.

The 2015 Chevy Colorado promises to deliver refinement and versatility, and slotting in below the all-new Silverado in size, it should be perfect for those looking for manageable size in a truck that pairs comfort with muscle. A cargo management system in back for recreational gear was one accessory touted at the introduction. I was also impressed by the estimate of 20 mpg, although these numbers, like the price, won't be out till later. Two engine options will be offered: a 2.5-liter four-cylinder making 193 horsepower and a 3.6-liter, 302-horsepower V-6. Both are paired with a six-speed automatic transmission. A year after its fall 2014 launch, a 2.8-liter Duramax four-cylinder turbo-diesel engine will be added.

Of course, this Chevy is made in the USA: in Saint Louis for the four-cylinder, and Flint, Michigan, for the V-6. With its sporty looks, slim profile, and all the tech that Chevy can muster, the 2015 Chevy Colorado is a Tonka truck come to life. This is one truck I'd gladly have in my driveway.—Elaine Nadalin, Correspondent

title: 50 States of Online Shopping
promoTeaserSmall: Beauty, taste, tradition, and the frankly tacky from all over the U.S.A. Part 1.
promoTeaser: Beauty, taste, tradition, and the frankly tacky from all over the U.S.A. Part 1.
metaDescription: 50 States of Online Shopping: Don't get into a state over holiday shopping. Here's a guide to fun things from all over the country. See it on JeanKnowsCars.com.

pageElements.text: There's a reason USA Today has a summary of the daily news headlines from every state: people move around, and they want to catch a glimpse of places they used to call home. That's the rationale behind this guide. What's the most interesting stuff you can get from various parts of the country without actually going there? Here are a few things we dug up that would make good gifts for the Wisconsin expatriate or regretful ex-Mississippian on your list. The other twenty-five states will be in part 2.

Alaska:

The University of Alaska's Musem of the North store offers Alaska-made crafts (soapstone polar bears, anybody?) and a selection of Alaska-themed books and publications. The "Eskimo Yo-Yo" shown here might not pass muster with PETA, since it's made from seal fur ("colors may vary") but could fascinate the right kind of kid or teenager.

Arizona:

If you want to share Arizona beauty, start with Arizona Highways magazine, for subscriptions, calendars, and prints of the breathtaking photography found in the magazine. Or spend $39.99, and get this coffee-table book with the amazing mountain view and the nearly as amazing split infinitive in the title. There's also the Navajo Nation's Arts and Crafts Enterprise for online turquoise jewelry and the like.

Arkansas:

The state of Arkansas wants kids to appreciate what's made at home, so it offers up (for all ages, really), this list of Arkansas producers with links.

California:

The California State Parks online store has a variety of park-specific shirts, caps, and posters to remember a previous road trip, or inspire your next one. From now until December 17, the site is offering 25 to 50 percent off to holiday shoppers.

Colorado:

The nonprofit Colorado Ski & Snowboard Museum Hall of Fame's glass ski gondola and ski boot ornaments ($8 to $14) might belong on your tree (or a friend's). More tasteful (and with a longer display life) are the dozens of vintage ski poster reproductions (starting at $20).

Connecticut:

It's not what you'd call historic (having been founded by Swedes, in 1995), but Bridgewater Chocolate is a Connecticut original and very popular. They're sold at five locations around Connecticut, including the factory store in Bridgewater, plus Dean & DeLuca in New York City. Or, order them here.

Delaware:

The Visit Delaware Store is small, like the state, but it does include a 2014 tourism calendar and souvenirs from the small but mighty Wine and Ale Trail.

Florida:

You can go beyond the bag of oranges or the citrus-themed ashtray with Viva Florida, a website celebrating th state's 150th anniversary in 2013. Viva Florida perfume (for Him or Her, $145 and up), a Ponce de Leon necktie ($75), and a Guy Harvey commemorative T-shirt ($25) are on offer. For a fuller listing of goods, try Florida's History Shop, where you can find all kinds of products bearing the state seal.

Georgia:

This state is paying a great deal of attention to the 150th anniversary of the Civil War, and this store has patches, books, and memorabilia for all ages and levels of interest.

Hawaii:

Forget leis and macadamia nuts, at least for a moment. The best thing out of Hawaii has got to be Lion Coffee, plus the well-designed packaging and related merchandise you can order online.

Idaho:

The First Lady of Idaho has a website offering children’s books and china in the official state of Idaho pattern. Live like an Idaho governor at $315 per place setting! I'm not even going to dignify your question with an answer as to whether there are potatoes in the design.
For Idaho fans on a budget, try the Idaho State Capitol Gift Shop for this year's official state capitol ornament. It's $21.95 postpaid, dated, in a gift box, with a pine bough inside.

Illinois:

Hey, Route 66 fans! The Route 66 Store in Pontiac, Illinois, has this kind of cool stuff.

Iowa:

The Heart of Iowa Marketplace offers "Keepin' It Rural" T-shirts in John Deere green, plus gift baskets that are heavy on the jam and other sweets, pig and cow novelties, and more.

Kansas:

The Kansas Historical Society has high prairie goods at low prairie prices, such as this Soul of Kansas essay compilation for $12.95, or a very wide range of refrigerator magnets and bracelet charms for under $5 each. Some have Carrie Nation on them.

Kentucky:

You can spend a happy hour touring the Louisville Slugger bat factory downtown, or an equally happy online hour perusing the Louisville Slugger Museum Gift Shop. A personalized bat in various colors, with your own (or your kid's) autograph on it, is $64.99.

Louisiana:

Storyville Apparel sells T-shirts and hoodies with New Orleans and Cajun themes. If you prefer to eat your Louisiana souvenirs, try Cajun Grocer ("Over 1,000 Authentic Cajun Food Products"). And Louisiana Travel has eight more Louisiana-themed websites on its Top Ten list.

Mississippi:

The Mississippi Musicians’ Hall of Fame shop has such treasures as these cigar-box guitars ($225-$385) that really play. There's also a Mississippi Blues Musicians Map, suitable for framing, that shows names, stage names, and places of birth of some 300 blues musicians from this state ($25 postpaid).

New Hampshire:

Goat-milk soap. "Live Free or Die" refrigerator magnets. This, and more, from the NH Made store.

North Dakota:

The North Dakota Tourism Gift Shop sells hoodies, neckties, T-shirts, and other apparel with a North Dakota script logo. Plus some nice ceramic mugs, as shown at the top of this page.

Ohio:

The state of Ohio has been important in some recent election nailbiters. So it's fitting that some of the most interesting Ohio memorabilia is politically related. Try the State House Shop for such things as Votes for Women mugs, Dogs Playing Cards style political art like the great Democratic Presidents poster shown here (there's a Republican Presidents equivalent), plus a range of Donkey and Elephant jewelry.

Oregon:

For official Pendleton woolens for which the state is famous, visit the Made in Oregon store. The Pendleton saddle blanket shown here measures 68 by 39 inches and costs $136. For another way to keep warm, order some Oregon wines, craft beers, and hard ciders from the same site.

South Dakota:

There used to be a sign by the Amsterdam train station stating that it was some number in the thousands of kilometers to Wall Drug. (Who knows if that billboard still exists in this post-ironic age?) But back here in the U.S.A., if you've driven cross country by the northern route, you couldn't miss the succession of signs telling you how many miles you were from the monolithic Wall Drug complex in the otherwise unremarkable burg of Wall, South Dakota. You can order a custom sign stating how many miles your home (or your gift recipient's) is from Wall Drug. It's on sale for the holiday season at $26.25, but delivery is four to six weeks, so hurry.
On a less commercial note, the South Dakota Historical Society Foundation shop has more serious items for sale such as pottery, glassware, and books, with proceeds benefiting the organization.

Texas:

I fondly remember a postcard I once bought during a trip: "The sun has riz/the sun has set; And here we iz/in Texas yet." That is no joke, as anybody who has driven the breadth of the massive state can attest. Visit the Texas HIghways website for bluebonnet, lone star, "Don't Mess with Texas," and other iconic Texas items, plus a calendar and an interesting shelf of Texas-themed books.

Virginia:

Take your pick between Virginia Is for Lovers merchandise that veers toward the mildly tacky, or a burlap bag of Whitley's peanuts for which the state is well known.

Wisconsin:

Discover Wisconsin is a TV show, and on its website, you can shop for solid middle American stoneware, coasters, and the odd Vince Lombardi themed item.

contributors.bio:
Sheer serendipity.  That’s how I became a contributor to Jean Knows Cars.  Well into a lovely dinner party, I received a most unlikely suggestion:  “You should write about cars from your perspective – a 4’11” single mother with a ten-year-old minivan who drives around three overactive children and a Bernese Mountain Dog.  Theatre, swimming, hockey, lacrosse, figure skating, field hockey… You love to tell stories. Tell them about cars.”  I suggested that my background possibly lacked necessary expertise – B.A. from Duke in art history and medieval/Renaissance studies; Fellow of the American Academy in Rome; Ph.D. from the University of Michigan in medieval architecture --  nothing about cars there!  My friend persisted, “You may be an art historian, but you are also a hockey mother who can whistle like a trucker, a runner, and a lover of good food, wine and the written word.”

I pondered.  The auto industry and I did have a long, if tangential, history.  I did a stint as an executive secretary to the president of a car dealership and spent fifteen years negotiating a dual identity as an academic and as auto company spouse.  I have always suffered from car envy, particularly acutely when I lived in Europe.  (As envy and lust are amongst the seven deadly sins, I’m in trouble.) Automobiles, functional objects that often shape image, are fundamental elements of today’s society.  This would be another mode of cultural analysis and critique.  Couched in that light, it made perfect sense!

(And, I really can whistle like a trucker, but louder. I may be an art historian, but don’t sit next to me at a hockey rink.)

pages.metaTitle: Rosie the Riveter Reunion
pages.name: index

pageElements.text: Military Appreciation Night at the USA Hockey game: this was not going to be a typical game. My daughter Sarah, USA Hockey’s vocalist, was singing the National Anthem with a full ROTC color guard, and the Ann Arbor Ice Cube, Ann Arbor’s main rink and home to USA Hockey’s National Development Team program, was packed. It must have been an off night for the NHL, for the place was crawling with scouts, and not of the Eagle kind. You can always tell NHL scouts: neatly coiffed and dressed in black with nice shoes, the scout uniform.
Through the sea of men in black, I suddenly caught a glimpse of a red and white polka-dot bandana, the signature of a different type of uniform.  Scouts are not uncommon at USA games, but a Rosie?

“Rosie the Riveter,” the alter ego of Jane Vass, was there to drop the puck for the game, in honor of the women who shored up manufacturing during World War II and to raise awareness of the Save the Bomber Plant campaign. You never know who you’ll run into at the Cube.

Jane was just as surprised to see me, having met me, in my guise as art historian and reporter, at the Willow Run Bomber Plant closing. “This must be fate! Tomorrow, I am having a luncheon for some original Rosies. Can you come?”

Lunch with History

As soon as lunch began, I realized that I was recording history as six remarkable women in their late eighties and early nineties recalled, as best they could, seventy-year-old memories of working during World War II. Toni Hunter was a “Wendy the Welder,” from the Philadelphia shipyard. Frances Masters, Lela Talbott Detrich, Ruth Webb, and Rachel Mae Perry spent their days “poppin’ rivets” at Willow Run, and Vivian Litchard (center in this photo) worked in the sewing department. Three were local girls; the others moved to the area for the work. Mrs. Perry (right), the daughter of sharecroppers and eldest of eight, came from Kentucky. Her paychecks went home for support. Mrs. Webb (left) said her whole family moved to the area from rural Indiana. She remembers the journey vividly: all twenty family members, including two babies, on the back of a flatbed truck. Her father refused to stop, so the only way to provide for the babes was to milk the goat they had in tow.

Through the individual stories, general themes emerged. They loved to work, and some of them continued in manufacturing after the war. They remember the visitors, such as when President Roosevelt or Marilyn Monroe, who herself started as a riveter, came to the plant. They were all barely eighteen then, so many of their memories revolved around gender relations. The male employees fell into two groups: “4-Fs,” ineligible for service for physical reasons (and, it seems, ineligible for dating), and supervisors, men beyond draftable age. Mrs. Litchard, who at eighty-eight is still striking, recalls her boss, twelve years her senior, asking her to dinner, but he didn’t want to pick her up in front of the other girls in the village—to "avoid appearances of favoritism."  She later met his wife.

At this revelation, they all had such stories to share. And, without bitterness but in recognition of injustice, they noted the inequities. They were paid five cents less an hour than the men in comparable jobs. When the war ended, the men received pensions, while they were simply laid off.

These women established the presence of women in manufacturing. Thinking of these six remarkable women, I can’t help feeling such admiration for the “Rosie the Riveters” who paved a path for the generations of women who followed.

metaDescription: Volvo's Child Safety Manual is basic, but its message is compelling. Plus, it's free. Read about it and find out where to download it on JeanKnowsCars.com.

pageElements.text: Volvo has done really well in branding itself as the "safety company." Of course, all cars, not just Volvos, are safer today than they have ever been, and certainly children are riding more safely than they were, say, during my childhood, when my baby sister would lie in the back seat with her head on my lap and her feet on my older sister's lap. None of us wore seatbelts for the first several years of my life; nobody did. By comparison, kids today are very well protected.

But there's always more to know, and to do, no matter what brand of car you drive. That's why the Volvo Car Group puts out a guidebook called Children & Cars: A Safety Manual, which you can download here.

Facing Backward until Age Three?

The biggest take-away from this beautifully designed, globally aimed manual is that children need to be in a rear-facing child seat until the advanced age of three years old. Until a few years ago, it was accepted wisdom in the United States that children needed to ride in a rear-facing seat until twenty pounds or age one, whichever came first. Around 2011, that all changed, and we are now told that age two is much safer for children. But Volvo is no latecomer to the rear-facing mandate: It made its first rear-facing child seat concept in 1967. The reason? Because children's heads are heavy relative to their young bodies, and their necks and vertebrae are not fully developed, so they can be injured more easily when facing forward in the event of a crash.

Fun facts: Volvo thinks everyone riding in a car would be safer if they faced backward. (Not that it would be practical, of course.) And the Swedish scientist who made the first rear-facing seat was inspired by the way the Gemini astronauts of the Sixties were seated during takeoff and landing.

The Volvo manual has been praised in its two previous editions and even won a publishing award in Sweden in 2007. It's free; get into a Volvo frame of mind and download it, if you have children (or child passengers in your car on a regular basis). And comment below on the rear-facing question: did you keep your children facing backward for any length of time? How long? Was it a relief to turn those seats around?

contributors.bio:
Jean Knows Cars is not just the name of this website; it's a true fact. I have been writing about cars and the car business for more than 30 years, having learned about cars at the kitchen table from my late father, Robert Lienert, who was the editor of Automotive News. At age eighteen, I bought a used car, painted it yellow, installed a toplight and a meter, and joined the Yellow Cab Company in Ann Arbor, Michigan, as an owner/operator. Five years later, I got a job at Chrysler’s test track as a test driver, welder, and mechanic in the impact lab. In 1980, I was hired as a writer at Car and Driver magazine after getting laid off at Chrysler, and in 1985 I left to establish Automobile Magazine with David E. Davis, Jr. I was the magazine’s first Executive Editor, became Editor in Chief in 2000, and added the title of President of Automobile Magazine in 2006.

I’ve been profiled in The New Yorker and have been a guest on the Tonight Show with Jay Leno. I was a guest on the Oprah Winfrey Show, teaching Oprah and her studio audience how to change a tire and to jump a battery. I was Good Morning America’s automotive correspondent from 1994 to 2000 and then did the same thing for the Oxygen network.

 I have won awards for feature writing, car reviews, and my monthly Automobile Magazine column, “Vile Gossip,” including the 2007 Ken Purdy Award for Excellence in Automotive Journalism.  I’m a regular on-air contributor to Fox Business Network; CNBC’s Closing Bell, Squawk Box, Behind the Wheel, and Power Lunch; MSNBC; CBS This Morning and Evening News; and CNN’s American Morning and Headline News. In fact, I would almost call myself a TV slut, but I’m proud to say that I turned Geraldo down.

All of this has taken place in a male-dominated automotive space, where I’m all too frequently the only woman in the room. I know the secret handshake, but JeanKnowsCars.com is going to be a place where you don’t have to. 

I live in the Michigan countryside with my husband, Tim, and the entire food chain. You’re going to get to know my driveway and my dogs really, really well. Just keep reading.

pageElements.text:
In Which I Put in Play Virtually Every Vehicle in the Driveway

What happened to the weather in Michigan while I was at the Los Angeles Auto Show?!? Tornadoes, high winds, and power outages across the Midwest in the middle of November. Basically, Armageddon. Luckily, I left winter clothes back in Detroit at airport parking in Automobile Magazine’s Mercedes-Benz GLK long-term test car. It was waiting with heated seats beckoning and lots of room for the luggage, for my husband, Tim, to go fetch it while I hauled our bags from the carousel out to the curb. I will admit to being rigidly OCD about stacking bags on a pushcart and then packing them perfectly into the back of the car, ergo the division of labor. (Note: The GL has a split-screen rearview camera that includes an overhead shot, making it virtually impossible to screw up backing perfectly into a spot.)

Having Tim be the one to drive home, though, offers only a brief respite. I’m the one who will have to go the next fifty miles to get the dogs. They are big, they are insane from being at the kennel for a week, and I have to figure out how to lift sixty-two pounds of squirming old dog Louie up and into the back of the Chevrolet Suburban. Bob and Stella leap into cages in a single bound. And then there’s Ray the Stray. The young lad is totally capable of the jump, but no. Tim convinced him early on that it’s much better to be swept up in Dad’s big, strong arms and then be placed neatly into his cage. I use one good arm and a knee, and I throw a dog treat in the back of the cage. It’s still like handling an octopus.

Saturday was a day for Words with Friends in front of the fire, while snow swirled on and off outside and Tim stalked the wily buck in vain. There was a quick trip to our veterinarian in the family Volkswagen Jetta TDI wagon with Louie for her acupuncture treatment, which has been working very well in soothing her crippled rear legs. Our super vet, Dr. Tim, places pins along her bladder and gall bladder “yang” meridians for about twenty minutes. The longer the pins are in, the more pain relief she gets. This is also how a vet can completely drain a dog’s life force in the case of euthanasia, so we have to be very careful in this process. Watching the old girl bound up the steps when we get home assures me that there’s a whole lotta chi left in her old fuzzy brown body. (Tiny sob.)
I was running late and had to really give the Suburban the boot. At 95 mph, it was like driving the QE2 at warp speed into the wind.

That evening, I had to announce a fashion show in Ypsilanti at the quirky boutique Mix, so I hauled out the Suburban because the GL was too small for The Hat, by which I mean The Hat at the top of this website, The Hat shot against the red barn, a Mr. Song couture event of a hat. Its box is huge in every dimension.

I was running late and had to really give the Suburban the boot. At 95 mph, it was like driving the QE2 at warp speed into the wind. I swear I could see the needle on the gas gauge actually moving. It was the perfect week for local fuel prices to be under $3 a gallon.

The snow was really coming down by the time I got to Ypsi, but a parking spot was waiting right in front of Mix. Once on my head, the hat must go sideways to get in the door, so I sidled into the scene amid great excitement. Models were mingling and chattering in the back room, and the chairs were filling up, on their way to a packed house.

As usual, people approached The Hat, ignored the rigid wall of shaved ostrich feathers marking the border of my personal space, and came under and in for the kiss. I’ve been to runway shows at Mercedes-Benz Fashion Week in New York City, but this was so much more fun, my own little Chevrolet Fashion Show at Mix, where you could see all the potential outfits off their hangers and arranged on a variety of heights and shapes of women, making everything look so much more desirable! As my husband would say, I’m not a shopper, I’m a buyer. (Love my new bracelet!)
Sunday was cold, colder, coldest. My remaining four brothers and I converged from all corners of Michigan on my mother’s nursing home for an early family Thanksgiving celebration.
Happy Thanksgiving everyone!

Love,
Jean

contributors.bio: When I turned sixteen, my dad brought home the very first-generation Ford Escort wagon, and it just so happened to have a manual transmission. Since—like every other sixteen-year-old—I knew everything, I was sure that I would just get behind the wheel and effortlessly shift gears. Visions of screeching into the school parking lot with my shiny red "world car" and impressing all the burnouts who hung out near their Detroit muscle cars danced in my head. All of those dreams were quickly extinguished in the first fifteen minutes of my driving lesson from my dad. Although he has a teaching certificate, patience is not his strongest skill. The subtle foot-hand coordination escaped me, and we were jerking around the subdivision like the contestants in a game of Red Light Green Light. I blamed my dad, and he blamed me. To my astonishment, he decided it was best to abandon ship and allow me to figure out how to get home. Somehow I managed to limp home without needing therapy for whiplash. After our wounds had healed I did end up learning to drive a manual on that trusty steed. I ended up driving my Escort to Northern Michigan University in Marquette, in Michigan’s frigid Upper Peninsula, where I obtained a BFA, with a concentration in Graphic Design, and a future husband. I joined Automobile Magazine at the tender age of twenty-eight and fell in love with the energy and passion for automobiles and the way they enhance our lives. Later, I took a five-year hiatus and boned up my design and web skills and am now turbocharged to be a part of the Jean Knows Cars team. Many years have passed, and now my sixteen-year-old only child is poised to learn to drive a manual, and I can’t help but be transported back to my teens. Unlike my parents, I am a helicopter mom. Riding in the passenger's seat with her behind the wheel is like waterboarding. I want to order her to pull over and allow me to drive and throw her in the back seat with airbags strapped directly on her. Many of her peers will not learn to drive a manual, but I believe that it is the building block for a good safe driver. It is a perfect synergy watching my daughter learn to drive and helping Jean Knows Cars celebrate and embrace the automobile and how it is woven into our lives.
