title: 50 States of Online Shopping Part 2
promoTeaserSmall: Beauty, taste, tradition, and the frankly tacky from all over the U.S.A. Part 2: The other 25.
promoTeaser: Beauty, taste, tradition, and the frankly tacky from all over the U.S.A. Part 2: The other 25.
metaTitle: 50 States of Online Shopping Part 2 - JeanKnowsCars.com
metaDescription: 50 States of Online Shopping, Part 2: Don't get into a state over holiday shopping. Here's a guide to fun things from all over the country. See it on JeanKnowsCars.com.

pageElements.text: There's a reason USA Today has a summary of the daily news headlines from every state: people move around, and they want to catch a glimpse of places they used to call home. That's the rationale behind this guide. What's the most interesting stuff you can get from various parts of the country without actually going there? Here are a few things we dug up that would make good gifts for the Indiana expatriate or regretful ex-Wyomingite on your list. The other twenty-five states are back in Part 1.

Alabama:

Alabama's civil rights app will help you take a trip through a historic time for this state. Points for trying to overcome the past. Likewise, check out this Road Trips website to plan an exploring trip of the beautiful state of Alabama. If you're looking for dishes or bakers, how about Earthborn Pottery's, made from Alabama clay?

Indiana:

This central state has a centralized website guide to things Made in Indiana with links to a number of sources.

Maine:

Find all kinds of Maine stuff, not all of which is made of driftwood, at the Maine Made site. As for food, there’s no shortage of mail-order lobster companies. The Hancock Gourmet Lobster company sells to Saks and has been name-checked on the Food Network, plus: it's headquartered in a charmingly small village, Cundys Harbor.

Maryland:

The DNR has a Forest Fire Truck ($50) and a selection of seafood cookbooks, or if your gift recipient lives in Maryland, you can order trees to be planted in a public space in their home county, and they get a certificate to commemorate the gift. $40 a tree, and if you order ten for $400, you can choose the public location of their planting.

Massachusetts:

The Kennedy obsession continues, and at the JFK Library, you can buy everything from the secret White House recordings of JFK’s conversations, on CDs ($40) to reproductions of presidential china from a dozen administrations. Plus, books and memorabilia for Robert, Teddy, and others in the dynasty.

Michigan:

Michigan does a state tourism slogan better than anybody, from the old Say Yes to Michigan! to the current “Pure Michigan” campaign. Get Pure Michigan stuff here.

Minnesota:

The Minnesota Historical Society is where you can skip the state’s Mall of America and get gifts centered around Fraser fir scents, cedar, and loons. Or how about a cribbage set ($46.95) in the shape of the state?

Missouri:

The governor launched a “100 Missouri Miles” initiative back in June, challenging everyone to do 100 miles’ worth of outdoor activity during the year, inviting them to get it done in the vaunted state parks system of trails. The state parks gift shop sells related clothes and badges. People of Missouri have logged 1,084,498 miles to date. Not a bad idea no matter what state you're in. The shop also has Lewis & Clark merchandise and other Missouri-themed goods.

Montana:

The Montana State Government store sells items such as Christmastime in Montana ($15.95), a paperback history book with “reminiscences of early prospectors, ranchers, and homesteaders,” among other stories. Scenic calendars and cookbooks (which are heavy on meat-cooking recipes) are also on display. Any of these items could get someone thinking about going off the grid in high country.

Nevada:

This state does “official tourism shop” right, with a Nevada Historical Society online shop that sells “Nevada passports” and finger puppets of Nevada animals but also serious literature and memorabilia related to Reno history, the Donner party, and native Americans. A Pony Express route map is only $5.

New Jersey:

Just say no to Jersey Shore trashy garments by visiting Jetty, a South Jersey “surf/skate/lifestyle” brand. Beach-themed, but tasteful, clothes and gear, plus browsing new musical artists and surf stars on the site. Women’s “Raglan Fish” hoodies are $47. Be Of the Shore, not a Shore fashion victim.

New Mexico:

The Land of Enchantment boasts three museum stores with one central online shop: wood art, turquoise jewelry, and posters of art by New Mexico artists.

New York:

Let’s just skip over the copious numbers of I Love New York souvenir shops you can find online and go over to the delightfully hyphenated New-York Historical Society or upstate to the Adirondacks, which have an online museum shop.

North Carolina:

The Carolina Travel Planner lists things to do and places to shop in the winter. Or have an Outer Banks Christmas with a wide variety of those ubiquitous OBX items, books, and art from the rustic, beautiful, storm-prone edge of the East Coast.

Oklahoma:

The official Cherokee Nation Gift Shop has perhaps the coolest license plate out there, a Cherokee Nation plate ($6.95) written in Cherokee. Plus the expected textiles, pottery, and Cherokee Nation seal items.

Pennsylvania:

Customized road trips courtesy of the state of Pennsylvania at Visit PA; on one of them, you might run across some Civil War re-enactors. If not, here’s the Civil War 150th anniversary store.

Rhode Island:

Newport Style has architecture books that let you ogle grand mansions from the comfort of your own coffee table. Or check out the quirky arts and crafts online shop Craftland, which has a Constellations over Rhode Island print that would look great on an office wall ($22).

South Carolina:

Here’s where to buy Certified SC Products online, including praline pecans in a Hilton Head Lighthouse tin ($16).

Tennessee

Regional food is not dead. That’s if you call Moon Pies “food.” Whether you are interested ironically or because they’re good, here’s the official Moon Pie online shop. Or buy music or poster prints from the Country Music Hall of Fame.

Utah

The Utah Store has the maps and guidebooks you need to visit the state, plus the Utah Official Scenic Calendar ($12.95), and when they say “scenic,” they are not joking around. Or try the gift shop for Utah’s Bonneville Salt Flats, where the World Land Speed Record is contested. Tiny boxes of mints with Land Speed Record vehicle images on top ($6) would make nice stocking stuffers.

Vermont

Vermont’s reputation as a hippie haven means it has great crafts to buy. The Vermont Crafts Council will get you to the felted wool garments and the woodblock prints.

Washington

Discover Northwest is a Seattle-based nonprofit dedicated to preserving public lands. Its maps, trail guides, and historic poster prints would make great dream material for future trip planning.

West Virginia

A lot of simple yet elegant crafts, and mountain music on CDs, come out of West Virginia, and here’s where to buy it online. Allegheny Mountain Radio is the place for CDs and books about mountain music, including the late Sen. Robert Byrd’s Mountain Fiddler recording.

Wyoming

Continental Divide gifts (such as an aluminum water bottle with Continental Divide Trail logo for $11), plus resources that will make you want to get in the car and take a driving trip, at the Continental Divide Trail Store online.

contributors.bio: I have spent a lot of time on the road. pageElements.text: My husband and I were invited by Jaguar to go to the contemporary-art event known as Art Basel in Miami and South Beach, which I've always wanted to do. It was the art world equivalent of going to Pebble Beach. When you get there, you discover there are numerous events spread across a wide area that take a car to get to, only everyone else is also in their cars, so it's a constant massive traffic jam. It's an offshoot of the original event, which is in Basel, Switzerland.
<iframe width="560" height="315" src="//www.youtube.com/embed/f0eBZx5llak" frameborder="0" allowfullscreen></iframe>
The real selling points were these. Miami: eighty-five degrees and sunny skies for the whole weekend.  Detroit: snow, single-digit temperatures, winds all weekend. Jaguar F-Type convertible.
This was an easy decision.

There were a lot of "lifestyle press" there: food writers, art people, a very eclectic group. Jaguar put us up at the Mondrian South Beach Hotel, another in an increasing number of avant-garde hotels in all the world's hot spots. L.A. and Miami are very similar places, with all these uber-hip hotels that are puzzling and disconcerting and inundated with techno versions of jazz, techno versions of folk, techno rock and roll, and techno techno. You can't escape it: it's in the pool, it's in the elevator, it's in the lobby, and it's crazy.
The decor of the room was intriguing. It had this blue Delft-like porcelain-tiled kitchen area, and upon closer inspection, the tiles were old beach scenes.

The room was vast, although there wasn't a lot of closet space. There were a lot of long horizontal shelves lining the room. In the bathroom, the shelf was like a long trough that ended under a faucet, so you put your stuff on the far left of the trough/shelf and wondered, when you turned on the faucet, if the water was going to run up and get your stuff wet, but it didn't. There was a chandelier in the shower surrounding the shower head, and when you woke up in the morning you were staring at an orange wall mirror on your left and a giant disembodied Barbie head with Miley Cyrus hair staring at you. These Barbie heads were also in the lobby on the walls. This was the beginning of me not understanding the art I was about to see, but at least it was eighty-five degrees.

Every space in the Mondrian was bigger than life. The portico had giant gold lampshade-shaped structures hanging over it, with chandeliers inside of them. You can't stop looking. The buildings were very white, and there was a lot of Moroccan-patterned grillework and wallpapers.

I was undoubtedly the least hip person staying there this weekend and the most normal person there, other than the fact that I did bring some hats. Frequently you'd get on the elevator next to an impossibly tall model, meaning 6'4", with a Russian accent.

The next morning, we met at 9:30 a.m. in the chandeliered portico, and there was a lineup of Jag F-Type convertibles, which was really why I was there. There were two garish F-Types done in the Union Jack motif with F-Type written on the doors. The head of PR told me, "This is one of the ones you're going to drive," and I started laughing, and he said,  "No, seriously," and I kept laughing. I have enough trouble with my driving record without driving one of these down to the Keys with the top down. Instead I was given an incredibly gorgeous orange F-Type that looked fantastic.

Once I slid behind the wheel of this 2014 Jaguar F-Type S V8 convertible in Firesand orange, the most hilarious thing to me was to listen to the description for the obviously non-automotive journalists around me about how to turn the car on and practice putting its automatic transmission shift lever in and out of gear. You can understand the very careful instruction by Jag. The car I was in had a total suggested retail price of $100,370 (including destination charge). Now you can imagine sliding some art critic from New York City behind the wheel of one of those cars. It was hilarious listening to them all around me under the portico revving the engine over and over again like they'd never enjoyed the noise of a big V-8 before.

What was even funnier was when, while one food critic from L.A. was revving and revving and obviously enjoying it, my husband slid into the seat next to him and pressed a button on the console, the one I call the Harmonic Maximizer, but which is actually called Active Sport Exhaust. It has the icon of an exhaust system, and it funnels more noise into the cabin. When my husband pressed it and suddenly the roar magnified, the guy lifted a foot off his seat in response to the gigantic blast of noise. He looked absolutely terrified and then burst out laughing. Exactly right, dude. The sound of the test drive at stoplights, at red lights, and in parking lots was the lifestyle press around me revving and revving and revving their engines like ten-year-olds. Like me, the first time I got my finger on that button.

The F-Type already starts out with a really great 495-horsepower 5.0-liter supercharged V-8. Not only that, it's one of the most beautiful convertibles on the planet, with a top that opens and/or closes in twelve seconds flat and looks sleek in either position.

What a great way to settle into the weekend. I wasn't sure where I was going or how to get there. I didn't quite understand the lay of the land. What I did understand was getting into this hot convertible, putting the top down, and blasting into the Florida Keys. The water is so beautiful. The sky was fantastic. Did I mention that it was eighty-five  degrees? Am I tan yet?

We went down to Isla Morada, stopped at the Cheeca Lodge and Resort, and had a spectacular lunch al fresco. The sugar sand stopped at the edge of the cement we were sitting on while we had lunch. I never wanted to leave. We probably stayed about thirty minutes too long, though, because, as we re-emerged from Key Largo, heading north to Miami, the traffic got thicker and thicker and the navigation system kept adjusting our arrival time until it was an hour later than it had started at Isla Morada.
Let's make no mistake and think that a drive down a straight road into the Florida Keys is going to exercise this car at all.

Even stop-and-go traffic is bearable when it's eighty-five degrees and you're in an equally hot car. A half-dozen times in the traffic jam, people who were slowly inching past shouted out, "I love your car!" I yelled back: "So do I, only it's not mine. I wish I owned it."

Let's make no mistake and think that a drive down a straight road into the Florida Keys is going to exercise this car at all. The only thing that got exercised was the Active Sport Exhaust button and the convertible top.
In the end, it was just a fine little road trip, said the girl from Michigan.

That evening, we hit the art scene at  an event called Wallpaper* Handmade with Jaguar in Miami. The premise was that everything in the exhibit was an object—luggage, an outdoor barbecue grill, a giant box of tools, an armagnac tasting cabinet with crystal decanters—made by artists, with manufacturing sponsorship. In the middle of it was the Jaguar C-X17 crossover. This is a handmade one-off concept car that was totally appropriate to the art exhibit.
We wandered through, then back out, off to dinner, and then to bed.

On Friday, I had to temporarily abandon Miami and fly in to Atlanta, joining the crowd of people pouring in for the Auburn-Alabama game. I was there to appear on CNN, which by the way was right next to the stadium, to talk about American car quality with the effervescent Poppy Harlow. It was forty-two degrees; who would think? I had left my coat in Miami, thinking I was down south. I got back to Miami in time to see Piston Head, an exhibit that our contributor Tamara Warren was totally tuned in to. She arranged for me to meet the curator, Adam Lindemann, who owns the gallery Venus Over Manhattan in New York City. The venue was an upper floor of an incredible parking structure, designed by the famous Swiss architecture firm Herzog & de Meuron of Basel, Switzerland. The guy who bought the space tore down the existing building and hired the Swiss firm to build the parking structure with a penthouse on the top floor.

Curator Lindemann loves cars, and he decided to find artists who also love cars. It took some time, wrangling, and a bit of corporate sponsorship from Ferrari to bring all of these cars to Miami Beach. The day couldn't have been more perfect to walk around high above the street with the breeze blowing and a great view of Miami and palms and blue sky backing the wild cars displayed around me. Yes, there were a few cars I didn't understand, but that's art for you. Below is a gallery of some of the photos I took during the weekend. You will also be able to see Tamara Warren's writing about Art Basel soon, here on JeanKnowsCars.com and in Automobile Magazine.

It was all perfect. Sadly, the weather at home this December is more like the weather we're supposed to get in January: howling winds, swirling snow, and single-digit temperatures. But I'm a Michigander, and the reality is, that's my home, and that's where I had to return. Sniff.

pages.metaDescription: What is the FXI, and what does it mean to car buyers and manufacturers?
pages.metaTitle: Honda and Mercedes hit a high note in customer satisfaction
pages.name: index

pageElements.text:
If you're the sort of person who doesn't pay much attention to surveys and analytics report, this one might change your mind: a new report by analytics company ForeSee ranks how people feel about brands, not individual products. As the company describes it, the report measures satisfaction at "the customer relationship level." The top two car brands this year: Mercedes-Benz and Honda, based on satisfaction levels of recent car buyers.

It's a little different from the better-known J.D. Power and Associates reports, which rank consumer experience with specific models. This is the first time the Ann Arbor, Michigan, company has issued The ForeSee Experience Index (FXI), which uses a set of complex data gathered from over 25,000 surveys across the top 100 brands in seven industries, including the automotive industry, as a way to quantify how customers feel about those brands.

ForeSee questioned panels of 200 to 250 recent auto buyers, grouped together by the vehicle brand they own. Larry S. Freed, President and CEO of ForeSee, explains, “We look at a model of customer satisfaction that includes price, product, and service: Is the cost fair? Does the product meet expectations? Is service at a high level, meaning, are companies keeping their promises?”

Mercedes and Honda scored highest in satisfaction with a rating of 85; Ford and Toyota followed with 83, while Hyundai, BMW, Chevrolet, and Audi each scored 82 points. Trailing a few points behind were Nissan and Volkswagen at 79 and Kia with a 78.

ForeSee also listed the top priorities for auto brands. For many manufacturers, price has the biggest impact on customer satisfaction: "the products provide value and are worth the price." Among those are top-scoring Honda, but also low-scoring Kia and Volkswagen. Service ("the company keeps its promises...the employees are friendly") had the biggest impact on satisfaction at BMW and Nissan, among others. For the high-scoring Mercedes-Benz, having "desirable, unique" products was the essential element in customer satisfaction.

“Satisfaction is a lot about expectations” is Freed’s message to automakers. “Expectations of a BMW are going to be very different than a Kia.” When tabulating the FXI score, ForeSee takes these perceptions into account, acknowledging that buyers assess a product's value according how they view the brand.

This is all very interesting, but it's also good news for us. We as consumers stand to benefit when auto companies have a deeper and more nuanced understanding of what drives our buying habits.
Photos courtesy of Rick Case Honda and Hoehn Mercedes

title: Dog-Friendly Hotels You'll Like

pageElements.text: Often, when it comes to hotels that allow pets, you're settling for a place that is, shall we say, not as luxurious as you might otherwise choose.
Instead, you might want to have a look at the Affinia Hotels website, which specifically targets dog owners with its VIPaws Pet program.
Does this look like the kind of place you might imagine when you hear of a pet-friendly hotel?
I didn't think so. This is actually a pretty luxurious hotel chain, and it makes a point of inviting people to bring their pets.

What's the catch? The hotels are mainly in New York and Washington, D.C., but other than that, they seem to have the pet thing figured out. For an added $25 pet fee ($50 in a few top-end hotels), your pet gets "select" food and water bowls, an oversize pet bed from the upscale New York City shop Jax and Bones, and rope toys for dogs or other, unnamed toys for cats. Even dog stairs if your pet needs them, and a special door hanger that lets staff know there's a dog in your room. Discounts on local pet products and services, plus a map of dog-friendly destinations nearby—and a leash-mounted waste bag dispenser, so you can take your dog there on foot—complete the package. Last but not least, $10 of the fee is donated to the Humane Society.

If you're traveling farther afield, the website Pet Friendly Accommodations Worldwide lists only hotels that are rated at least three stars. Such cushy spots as the Fairmont in Chicago, the Eliot in Boston, and the Milestone in London (right) are represented, with details on surcharges (ranging from $25 to $75), pet size limitations, and whether there's a treat or welcome gift for your pet on arrival. It's good one-stop shopping if you are planning a trip somewhere with a pet and don't want to stoop to a questionable room at a low-end motel just because you've got your dog with you.

The Ford Edge has been out on the market since 2006. It was really cool, although never "Edge-y," when it first came out, but it quickly got old.

It was very much overdue for a redesign, and I think this concept was quite nicely done by Kevin George and his team. I asked him to explain how they approached it in this walkaround video at the Los Angeles Auto Show. When he finished, you can be sure I mocked him for referring to the interior color as having a "forte position." What the what? You know, all these designers talk like that. Next time, I'm going to butt in to the video and demand an immediate translation when they start speaking that foreign language of theirs.

pageElements.text: Every now and then—not often—the professional automotive journalist is faced with the horror of renting a car. This is my story.

Bob the Reluctant Show Dog had decamped for Florida for the AKC/Eukanuba National Championship in Orlando, Florida. My husband, the ever optimistic Tim, had packed Bob in his crate in the back of one of Automobile Magazine’s long-term test vehicles for the 2,400-mile round trip. I was flying around on business, so I veered south to join them. Only they were leaving immediately after the show, and I planned an extra day to go up to Saint Augustine and visit Hurley Haywood's new house.

So I needed to get a rental car. When I arrived, I went to Hertz, and they upgraded my basic rental to a Chevrolet Cruze LT. First of all, it was a gorgeous brown color that looked really nice. You never know what to expect; I’ve had some pretty crappy rental cars in my day. This car had 29,000 miles on it, and it smelled perfectly fine and looked brand-new. There was not a dent, it was super clean, and it was loaded (heated seats!). I can’t tell you how surprising it was to me how well the car drove and braked. There wasn’t a rattle; there was no road noise, no wind noise. It was solid and could have been a test car dropped here at Jean Knows Cars by Chevy PR; that’s how good it was.

I threw my luggage in the huge trunk, which had plenty of room to spare, and I drove from the airport past Sea World to a two-bedroom condo that my husband had arranged for us to share with Bob’s show handler. My husband is notoriously cheap. He is tighter than the bark on a log. I have gone with him to dog shows where he’s put me in a Motel 6, including one that the police cruised by every ten minutes because it was such a bad neighborhood, in Louisville, Kentucky. The floors were damp, the toilet ran, and the sheets were see-through. It was so bad that at midnight I sat up in bed and said, "We're leaving in the morning. I have been traveling for thirty-three years, and I no longer need to get a $39 hotel room.” He was smart enough to pack up everything right then, in the middle of the night, and take me to a Holiday Inn, which by the way had dog biscuits in a bowl on the front desk when we checked in. I looked at him and said “See? See what I’m talking about here?” No more Motel 6s.

So this place I was going was called Floridays Resort. Tim insisted it looked really good in the pictures online, which brought to mind another hotel we once got based on the pictures online, in Chicago. We were going to see the impossible-to-get-into Monet exhibit at the Art Institute of Chicago, so we chose a beautiful old hotel with a great name like Blackstone or something like that. When we arrived, it looked grand outside and incredibly tatty inside. We were handed the key, and the fob was a fluorescent green plastic with the number written on it in ink. I looked around the vast lobby, and about 25 percent of the tiles were missing. We got into the room, and paint was blistering on the ceiling and the bedspread was worn-out chenille. I burst into tears. We could have been at the Drake instead! But no. He tried to jolly me, and I was inconsolable until I woke up the next morning and he said: “The funniest thing happened last night. I woke up in the middle of the night to go to the bathroom, and I made my usual two left turns, opened the door, and stepped out, and instead of being in our bathroom, I was in front of the elevator, stark naked. So I turned around, and I couldn’t remember what room I was in.” While he was talking, I was just sitting there, dumbfounded. He went on: “I was trying doors, and luckily, I left our door slightly open.” The funniest thing is how nonchalant he was, completely unaffected by it, but it sure brightened my day.

Back to the Floridays Resort. It turned out to be a complex of six high-rise buildings surrounding a really big pool, and the condo inside was fantastic, beautiful, and super clean. The units are all privately owned, and it cost less than $150 a night for two bedrooms and two full baths, one with shower and Jacuzzi. There was a living room, a dining table, and a full kitchen. We cooked a big chicken dinner for Dr. Robert Garcia de Padua and his wife, Cindy, who drove down from Jacksonville to see GCH Irish’s Robert Garcia de Padua, a.k.a. Bob, compete in the nationals.

Sadly, Bob did nothing at the event, but dinner was great, and they drove back to Jacksonville. We laughed at the fact that, once Bob got his championship title, Bob the dog pushed Bob the doctor off the front page of Google search.
Five years on, Dr. Bob frequently has new clients who ask him if that’s his dog. Who would name his dog after himself? Certainly not Dr. Bob. He gets a big laugh, though.
The only thing central Florida has going for it, other than the weather (which, by the way, was 42 degrees when I got up), is palm trees.

It was a pretty quick trip. Tim loaded up the car and left at 1:45 in the morning for Michigan, and I drove up to Saint Augustine to visit my old friend, endurance-racing legend Hurley Haywood, at his new house. We had a great afternoon. I met his new English cocker spaniel, Watkins, who joined his other English cocker spaniel, Indy. (Typical racing-car-guy names.) These two little cuties join his three gorgeous cats. I was there just long enough to have a boat ride and walk the dogs in old Saint Augustine. Then I left the next morning and went back to Orlando and flew home.

But on my way back to Orlando, it occurred to me that the only thing central Florida  has going for it, other than the weather (which, by the way, was 42 degrees when I got up), is palm trees. My favorite overpass on the way back to Orlando is LPGA Boulevard, right around Daytona Beach, which is lined on both sides by varying heights of palm trees. You could see it from a mile away against the blue morning sky. The weather, the blue sky, the palm trees.
When I took my car back to Hertz, I was greeted by a very cheery lady named Donna who said, “You write for a car magazine.” I took this picture of her with the car, and we had a great conversation.
Even the parking structure is lushly landscaped with palm trees. Oh, call me a farmer from Michigan, but I took a picture.
Before I could get home, I was getting dispatches from the front, where my husband had arrived to sub-zero temperatures and multiple inches of snow.

Postscript: The sad news here is that Annie White is leaving us to go to the Big Apple, but she'll still be contributing. We've loved having her this past year.

One last thing: If you're in Ann Arbor for the rest of December, go to Cafe Zola, where our fantastic videographer Scott Allen's paintings are on the walls. He's a major talent, and we're glad we have him with us. You might have another look at our videos with new appreciation.

title: Ford F-150 to Brooklyn
promoTeaserSmall: Big trucks may be best out on the range, but they are also ideal for a major cross-country move.
promoTeaser: Big trucks may be best out on the range, but they are also ideal for a major cross-country move.
metaKeywords: Road trip to New York City
metaDescription: Ford F-150 to Brooklyn: My road trip to what was soon to become my new home, in a vehicle that could handle all my stuff. Read about the road trip on JeanKnowsCars.com.

contributors.bio:
I am a recent graduate of Boston University thrilled to be working my first real job (in this case, “real” means I never have to use a mop).  I have previously appeared as a lifeguard, a mailroom lackey, a part-time nanny, and a fudge chef, but the real reason I'm here today is because someone once told me I could write and I believed them. As a writer and publisher for BU’s online magazine, I wrote about politics and current events and wrote two series: Foxy Congressperson of the Week, which is exactly what it sounds like, and An American in Paris, detailing my misadventures abroad. 

Growing up in Southeastern Michigan means that love of cars is practically a birthright, and one I’ve always been proud of. I still drive my first car, a beloved orange Chevy HHR that has been through the war and keeps on chugging. After three years on the East Coast, I’m happy to be back in a place where the speed limit is treated more as a guideline than a rule.

pageElements.text:
2013 Ford F-150 4x4 Supercrew

Price: $53,635 as tested (including destination)
Engine: 3.5-liter turbocharged V-6, 365 horsepower
Transmission: Six-speed automatic
Fuel economy: 15 mpg city/21 mpg highway
My favorite standard feature: Heated and cooled driver's and passenger's seats
Option I can’t live without: King Ranch luxury package ($2,665) includes navigation, power moonroof, King Ranch interior accents, HID headlights
You might also be considering: Chevrolet Silverado, Ram 1500, Toyota Tundra

In the tradition of countless twentysomethings before me, in the eighteen months since I left college I have moved from place to place, house to house, like a rolling stone. I’ve moved four times since last September, and I’m about to add another location to my list: next stop, Brooklyn!

Moving is easier said than done, though. How am I going to get all my stuff across the country and into a tiny apartment in the most densely populated city in the United States? Luckily, I’m a big believer in a minimalist lifestyle. In college, I lived for nine months with only the clothes I could carry in my sixty-five-liter backpack (and my laptop, of course). I’m prepared to do it again. But what about my bed?

With access to test cars that could theoretically transport a mattress cross-country, I couldn’t justify buying a new bed or spending my limited cash on a moving truck. So instead, I got hold of a 2013 Ford F-150 King Ranch over Thanksgiving weekend and started planning for a two-day there-and-back dash from Fort Wayne, Indiana, to Brooklyn and back again in time for a good night’s sleep in Ann Arbor before work Monday morning. Total miles driven during the long weekend would eventually top 1,700.

It all started with a Friday night trip to my ancestral home in Plymouth, where my dad helped me haul my mattress into the back of the F-150. I’d assumed that any truck bed would be large enough for my full-size bed, but this was a Supercrew model with a short bed. That was great news for any hypothetical back-seat passengers, who would enjoy 43.5 inches of legroom. But not great news for my mattress, which was six feet long and had to fit in a five-and-a-half-foot truck bed. The F-150 came with an optional bed extender, which cost $250 and allowed me to drive with the tailgate down and my cargo secured with a locking gate.

With the bed extender in place, my mattress just fit in the truck bed. I filled the back seat with a couple of laundry baskets full of bedding and clothes and went home to Ann Arbor for a night of rest before my drive the next day.

My first destination of the day was a bridal shower in Fort Wayne, just a few blocks from the house my mom grew up in. I wasn’t quite sure of the way, so I used voice commands to enter the address into the standard MyFord Touch infotainment system. The system immediately launched into route guidance. At first, all was well. But then, the navigation system started getting confused about my location. Although I never left the highway, it showed me traveling down a side road parallel to the freeway and issued repeated voice commands urging me to return to I-94 West at the earliest possible convenience. This continued for over an hour, until I got annoyed and turned it off.

This F-150 was a King Ranch model, one of the F-150’s top trim levels. It’s named for a working ranch in southern Texas, and it has the real King Ranch’s swoopy cattle brand logo throughout. The King Ranch package costs $2,665 and comes with HID headlights, a power moonroof, and brown leather seating in both the front and back rows, as well as a leather-wrapped steering wheel and center console. The seats were attractive and comfortable, and I felt like I was sitting in a nice armchair as I went down the road.

The rest of the F-150’s interior wasn’t nearly as cushy. The door and dashboard trim were made of hard, black plastic, which would make perfect sense in a more utilitarian model. But in a $53,000 car, an interior that could be hosed down feels out of place. I found myself dreaming of the 2014 Chevrolet Silverado I’d driven a few months earlier. It had leather seats, soft-touch materials on all the interior surfaces, an intuitive infotainment system; now that’s a truck interior. I’m hoping Ford has something similar in store for the all-new 2015 F-150, out next year.

After a morning of pre-wedding festivities (I passed on the mimosas, mindful of the long drive ahead), I set out for Brooklyn. I was pleasantly surprised to find that the F-150 was a comfortable highway cruiser. I didn’t hear any rattling or rumbling from my cargo, which stayed firmly in place behind the bed extender. The F-150 didn’t get fantastic fuel mileage – my average hovered just above 15 mpg for most of my trip, though its V-6 EcoBoost engine is rated at 21 mpg on the highway, but the thirty-six-gallon fuel tank meant that pesky fuel stops were limited. That’s not to say those stops were painless, though. Each thirty-gallon plus fill-up cost in the neighborhood of $100.

I’d been worried that my big truck would be a fish out of water in New York City, but the F-150 handled the Big Apple with grace. The navigation system that had faltered earlier guided me to my final destination without error. The truck felt big in the narrow lanes, but I kept my wits about me and never had trouble. Once in Brooklyn, I found a free parking space right across the street from my apartment, unloaded the truck, and went to bed, preparing to do it all over again the next day.

From the very start of my drive on Sunday, I was battling post-Thanksgiving traffic. The first ten miles or so (from Brooklyn through Manhattan and onto the New Jersey Turnpike) took more than an hour. Just outside New Jersey, I hit another log jam leading up to a tollbooth, and listened to two entire discs of my Harry Potter book on tape while waiting to escape it. Two hours later, I was snagged again. In those hours inching west, I was happy to have the F-150 King Ranch. Tacky door trim aside, the truck was comfortable, and I was glad for my high seating position and armchair seats as I made my way home.

I’ve never been convinced that pickup trucks make sense outside of construction zones or working farms, and I’m still not. The F-150 gets decent fuel economy for a truck, but you’ll spend $830 more in fuel every year compared with the driver of an average new car, and parking and maneuvering this beast (even with a rearview camera) will make you wish you were driving a Smart Fortwo. Still, for a move across the country with large cargo, the F-150 King Ranch was just what the doctor ordered.

contributors.bio: When I turned sixteen, my dad brought home the very first-generation Ford Escort wagon, and it just so happened to have a manual transmission. Since—like every other sixteen-year-old—I knew everything, I was sure that I would just get behind the wheel and effortlessly shift gears. Visions of screeching into the school parking lot with my shiny red "world car" and impressing all the burnouts who hung out near their Detroit muscle cars danced in my head. All of those dreams were quickly extinguished in the first fifteen minutes of my driving lesson from my dad. Although he has a teaching certificate, patience is not his strongest skill. The subtle foot-hand coordination escaped me, and we were jerking around the subdivision like the contestants in a game of Red Light Green Light. I blamed my dad, and he blamed me. To my astonishment, he decided it was best to abandon ship and allow me to figure out how to get home. Somehow I managed to limp home without needing therapy for whiplash. After our wounds had healed I did end up learning to drive a manual on that trusty steed. I ended up driving my Escort to Northern Michigan University in Marquette, in Michigan’s frigid Upper Peninsula, where I obtained a BFA, with a concentration in Graphic Design, and a future husband. I joined Automobile Magazine at the tender age of twenty-eight and fell in love with the energy and passion for automobiles and the way they enhance our lives. Later, I took a five-year hiatus and boned up my design and web skills and am now turbocharged to be a part of the Jean Knows Cars team. Many years have passed, and now my sixteen-year-old only child is poised to learn to drive a manual, and I can’t help but be transported back to my teens. Unlike my parents, I am a helicopter mom. Riding in the passenger's seat with her behind the wheel is like waterboarding. I want to order her to pull over and allow me to drive and throw her in the back seat with airbags strapped directly on her. Many of her peers will not learn to drive a manual, but I believe that it is the building block for a good safe driver. It is a perfect synergy watching my daughter learn to drive and helping Jean Knows Cars celebrate and embrace the automobile and how it is woven into our lives.

contributors.bio: I have spent a lot of time on the road. I started touring with a band along with my older brother, Ryan, when I was still in high school, and in all I have put in a little over ten years of touring. Eventually we were in a band named Thunderbirds Are Now! We played many festivals including SXSW, CMJ, and Pitchfork, toured all over the country and all over Europe, went to Australia, were in a lot of magazines, and had an exciting time. We spent thousands of hours inside a 15-passenger red Ford Econoline van we bought that we called Old Magent. That was where we had our down time. We spent more time in the van than we did playing the shows. When we toured outside the country, we had drivers. My strongest memory of that is being picked up in a Mercedes Sprinter van by someone we had never seen before and being driven through deep snow from Germany to Sweden—a 15-hour drive—through the mountains at high speed. Everyone in the band wrote final messages to our families and put them in our pockets just in case. Touring with a band is very scary but also very fun. A lot of weird and new things happened in my life, but they are great memories I'll never forget, and it was time well spent living a dream that came true. But all good things come to an end. You're up every night, and it just gets hard. I was lucky that my father was a musician and built a recording studio in our basement, and he also shot a lot of videos. I have been recording my own music and making stop-animation video since I was a young kid. After leaving the band, I went to Washtenaw Community College to study videography and won a couple of awards—Most Creative two years in a row, and Best in Show. I was doing freelance post-production video editing when I met Jean Jennings, and we instantly clicked. She likes music, I like music, and we just "get" each other. I've had a very, very strange route to where I am now. I'm happy that I can settle in with Jean Knows Cars and live a normal life but still with a creative outlook. pageElements.text: One of the best venues to see works of art at Art Basel Miami in December was not at the art fair, but on an entire floor of the Herzog & de Meuron parking garage-turned-art- car-gallery on 1111 Lincoln Road. “Piston Head: Artists Engage the Automobile" was an exhibition timed to Art Basel that explored the power, refuse, and imagination induced by car culture.

pageElements.text: The New York gallery Venus Over Manhattan showed fifteen art cars and one 1965 Harley motorcycle, all as imagined by serious contemporary artists. Ron Arad’s disfigured Fiat 600, Virginia Overton’s humble 1993 Dodge Ram, and several virulent American models drew spectators to the far corners of the open-air garage overlooking the Miami skyline. High-profile works included a polka-dotted Mini Cooper produced by Damien Hirst, Richard Prince’s red and black 2012 Dodge Challenger R/T in the style of Vanishing Point, and Keith Haring’s playful 1963 Buick Special. The brand-new Playboy-commissioned 1972 Dodge Charger made by Richard Phillips made its debut at the show. “This car was a raw chassis when I started,” said Phillips at the opening, as he pointed out the #43 Richard Petty-inspired design cues. “Now you have a hybrid of a Cup car.” Then he climbed into the driver’s seat, opting to let the growl of the engine drown out the clink of champagne glasses and the clamor of conversation.

The show ranges from functioning cars to highly conceptual works. Artist Salvatore Scarpitta raced his single-seater Ernie Triplett Special dirt racer in Pennsylvania and was sponsored by the legendary art dealer Leo Castelli. Whereas the French sculptor César's compressed crushed car sculptures have deliberate impact, real-world cars like sculptor Franz West’s coy 1970 Rolls-Royce Silver Shadow were contrasted by think pieces like the rusted-out, shot-up Ford pickup truck repurposed by Lucien Smith. Then there is the catastrophic humor of two whimsical white Volkswagen Beetles engaged in an intimate crash, as footage played out on the windshield, courtesy of the collective Bruce High Quality Foundation.

Adam Lindemann, who curated the show and owns the gallery, is also a car collector. He favors vintage Ferraris and those of classic British pedigree. “What was nice about the show was that we somehow struck this intersection between art, cars, artist cars, and Miami, and we found collectors for the cars, which is so amazing, because people come to Miami to buy paintings, not cars,” he said.

Ferrari, a sponsor of the five-day exhibition, once used the garage to show a parade of its fine exotics during Art Basel. This year, a LaFerrari was on exhibition on opening night to accompany the only two-dimensional work, by California artist Joshua Callaghan, who made a rubbing of the car. “I spent the last three days in the basement at the Ferrari dealership,” said Callaghan. “It’s a future archaeology.” The piece was auctioned off to benefit the Art Production Fund.

contributors.bio:
I am a recent graduate of Boston University thrilled to be working my first real job (in this case, “real” means I never have to use a mop).  I have previously appeared as a lifeguard, a mailroom lackey, a part-time nanny, and a fudge chef, but the real reason I'm here today is because someone once told me I could write and I believed them. As a writer and publisher for BU’s online magazine, I wrote about politics and current events and wrote two series: Foxy Congressperson of the Week, which is exactly what it sounds like, and An American in Paris, detailing my misadventures abroad. 

Growing up in Southeastern Michigan means that love of cars is practically a birthright, and one I’ve always been proud of. I still drive my first car, a beloved orange Chevy HHR that has been through the war and keeps on chugging. After three years on the East Coast, I’m happy to be back in a place where the speed limit is treated more as a guideline than a rule.

pageElements.text:
Price: $20,405 as tested (including destination)
Engine: 1.4-liter turbocharged four-cylinder, 138 horsepower
Transmission: Six-speed manual
Fuel economy: 29 mpg city/40 mpg highway
My favorite standard feature: Heated, power-adjustable side mirrors
Option I can’t live without: Chevrolet MyLink with voice recognition for phone and Bluetooth streaming audio ($200)
You might also be considering: Ford Fiesta, Hyundai Accent, Nissan Versa

What I Think:

I first became acquainted with the Chevrolet Sonic when my mother bought one last year, passing her four-year-old Saturn Astra down to me. Before the Saturn, she drove a Saab 9-5 wagon. My dad joked when she bought the Sonic that it was an omen of bad times ahead for Chevy; thankfully, he has been proven wrong. She’s had the Sonic for a year now, but I’ve never spent much time in it, so when we took delivery of a 2014 Sonic LT hatchback for a week, I didn’t know exactly what to expect.

I did know that this subcompact hatch aims to strike just the right balance among utility, affordability, and efficiency. With a 40-mpg highway EPA rating,  it’s off to a good start. The cargo area doesn’t have acres of space, but it’s more than adequate for the average single person. As for affordability, our near-base model comes with a satisfying array of options and tips the scales at just over the magic $20,000 mark after delivery charges. A very promising start.

My time with the Sonic coincided with the first big snowstorm of the winter, so I spent a day slipping and sliding all over town before the snow stopped, the roads cleared, and I was able to actually drive the thing. Our test car came with the optional 1.4-liter turbocharged four-cylinder engine making 138 horsepower, which adds $700 to the price. The upgraded engine also got us a six-speed manual transmission instead of the standard five-speed manual. The Sonic LT comes standard with a 1.8-liter normally aspirated engine that makes less torque and earns five fewer highway mpg.
The manual transmission was slick and easy to drive, exactly the kind of manual I wish I’d learned on.

I found our upgraded powertrain to be well matched to this little hatch. It can accelerate reasonably quickly when pushed, but it doesn’t feel souped up or overdone. The manual transmission was slick and easy to drive, exactly the kind of manual I wish I’d learned on. The turbo model’s 33-mpg fuel economy rating will help pocketbooks almost as much as the low price; it’ll save you $3,500 in gas over five years, according to the EPA’s calculations, no small matter for penny pinchers.

The Sonic’s design is quirkier and more unusual than Chevrolet’s larger offerings—like the Cruze or the Malibu, for instance—but not quite as odd as the even tinier Spark. I thought it struck a nice balance between looking distinctive and looking like a toy, which is exactly what I think small car design should do. You’d never feel embarrassed driving this car, but you also wouldn’t feel like a mid-level manager at Dunder Mifflin.

On that cold weekend, I wished my Sonic had heated seats instead of the base, unheated cloth ones, but I enjoyed Chevrolet’s MyLink system as I have every time I’ve used it in any car. It’s simple and intuitive, and it won’t distract you from the task at hand. If you do get a little wrapped up in changing the radio station, though, the available forward collision alert and lane departure warning systems (in the advanced safety package, $395) could save you. Those warning lights are oddly placed, positioned atop the center stack right above the infotainment system. They’d be more useful in the dash or a head-up display so you didn’t have to rely on peripheral vision to catch the warnings, but in a car at this price, it’s impressive to have those systems at all.

The Verdict:

I, of course, could never buy a Sonic, because my mother drives one. But forgetting that detail, I couldn’t help being impressed by the Sonic LT. It’s not packed with technology, but it has most everything you could hope for in a $20,000 car and a little more. It’s neither large nor tiny but operates in a comfortable middle ground. It can be driven aggressively if the mood strikes, but sedate driving will return excellent fuel economy. And if you’ve really got your heart set on heated seats or a sportier ride, the Sonic’s upper trim levels have plenty to keep you happy. Call this one a winner.

Peanut Gallery:

Laura Sky Brown: As long as I stay inside the Sonic, I am having a good time. The somewhat cartoonish visuals on the controls are actually kind of fun, and despite the low price point on this little car, there's a surprising amount of content, from a rearview camera to complete telematics and the most intuitive Bluetooth hookup I've found to date (which went ahead and paired my phone without being asked). Shifting with the six-speed manual transmission is smooth and enjoyable, and it's ridiculously fun to call on the turbo for a sudden burst of speed. The seats are comfortable, the back hatch has a good amount of space, and the interior, while not upscale or luxurious, has decent quality. But then you get out of the car. I am very forgiving of various body styles, but I'm sorry, this is just ugly.

Molly Jean: The turbocharged Chevrolet Sonic may not be supersonic, but for $20,405 it is super. Unlike Laura, I actually like the exterior design; it is unique enough that it is easily identifiable as it zips down the road. The unique style continues on the inside with the motorcycle-style gauges and the patterns on the seats. There is a lot of hard plastic, but it looks not only well designed but also capable of holding up for many years without showing wear. The best part of this particular package is the manual transmission. Coupled with the turbo, it makes this economy car a great choice for both new drivers and price-conscious shoppers who want a little sportiness in their whip.

contributors.bio: I have spent a lot of time on the road. I started touring with a band along with my older brother, Ryan, when I was still in high school, and in all I have put in a little over ten years of touring. Eventually we were in a band named Thunderbirds Are Now! We played many festivals including SXSW, CMJ, and Pitchfork, toured all over the country and all over Europe, went to Australia, were in a lot of magazines, and had an exciting time. We spent thousands of hours inside a 15-passenger red Ford Econoline van we bought that we called Old Magent. That was where we had our down time. We spent more time in the van than we did playing the shows. When we toured outside the country, we had drivers. My strongest memory of that is being picked up in a Mercedes Sprinter van by someone we had never seen before and being driven through deep snow from Germany to Sweden—a 15-hour drive—through the mountains at high speed. Everyone in the band wrote final messages to our families and put them in our pockets just in case. Touring with a band is very scary but also very fun. A lot of weird and new things happened in my life, but they are great memories I'll never forget, and it was time well spent living a dream that came true. But all good things come to an end. You're up every night, and it just gets hard. I was lucky that my father was a musician and built a recording studio in our basement, and he also shot a lot of videos. I have been recording my own music and making stop-animation video since I was a young kid. After leaving the band, I went to Washtenaw Community College to study videography and won a couple of awards—Most Creative two years in a row, and Best in Show. I was doing freelance post-production video editing when I met Jean Jennings, and we instantly clicked. She likes music, I like music, and we just "get" each other. I've had a very, very strange route to where I am now. I'm happy that I can settle in with Jean Knows Cars and live a normal life but still with a creative outlook. pageElements.text: Q. "Alphabet" questions: What is the effect of ABS, ASC, AWD, RWD and FWD in the snow?
Ancient Motorbiker asked me this question on our Jean Knows Cars Facebook page. Thanks for the inspiration!

A. First off, Ancient One, my motorcycling days came to a rapid close after a few years of riding, mostly because I was acutely (and constantly) aware that my lack of experience on a bike left me empty handed in an emergency. On the other hand, I have spent more than three decades driving very fast on closed courses, including time spent practicing emergency avoidance techniques and drills to sharpen my skills for when the shit inevitably hits the fan.
So my experience applies only to four-wheeled vehicles. And I would add that my answers don’t apply to driving on ice, where the only things that work are ice skates and hockey pucks.

ABS

Anti-lock Braking Systems help prevent your wheels from locking up in a skid by automatically pumping the brakes way faster than your puny little legs can do it. All you have to do is slam your foot on the brake pedal and hold it there. The real beauty (and point) is that you can still steer the car, so even if you are skidding to an eventual ABS stop, you have some maneuverability.

Warning: Your ABS stopping distance can be longer in the snow than an old-fashioned two-feet-on-the-brake-pedal skid, because a skid builds up snow in front of your four wheels, eventually helping to stop your car. The most modern four-wheel ABS works by sensing wheel lockup and unlocking that wheel until all four wheels are stopped. No skid, no little snow wedgies.
Lesson: Keep your distance, slow down for stop signs and curves, and practice your braking in an empty parking lot or with plenty of room to stop before you really need them.

ESC

Electronic Stability Control (sometimes known as automatic stability control, or ASC) is a fantastic system, which the federal government says reduces single-vehicle car crashes by 35 percent and single-vehicle SUV crashes by 67 percent. ESC senses when you’ve gotten in over your head in a turn—typically, you’re going too fast, causing oversteer or understeer—and applies brakes at individual wheels as needed to settle the car down. You can see how this could be helpful in the snow. It’s when you’re stopped in the deep snow (or stuck) that ESC can work against you. That’s when you’ll want to find the switch that turns it off, allowing you to spin your wheels and rock your way out of deeper snow.
Warning: Just don’t forget to turn it back on.
Nothing helps a rear-wheel-drive car more in snowy conditions than a good set of real snow tires.

RWD

Rear-wheel-drive vehicles can be the most difficult to manage in snow, but when I was growing up, that’s all we had. (I’m an excellent drifter, by the way!) When your rear drive wheels are the ones that lose traction, they tend to slide out, and when that happens, a spin is not far behind. It helps to get weight over those rear wheels to improve traction. Use big bags of kitty litter in the trunk, not sandbags. Sand freezes; kitty litter doesn’t. When you’re stuck on glare ice, you can pack the litter around the wheel to give your tires something to grab on to.
Nothing helps a rear-wheel-drive car more in snowy conditions than a good set of real snow tires.
Lesson: In a rear-wheel-drive car, drive into the slide. That is, if the rear slides out to the right, steer into the right. Practice this in an empty parking lot.

FWD

Front-wheel-drive cars are famously good in the snow, especially in hilly areas. With the engine sitting over the drive wheels—and let’s say those wheels are shod with real snow tires—you’ve got weight and traction up front, pulling everything along behind it. You’ve almost got yourself a little tractor. In fact, are you sure you need four-wheel drive?
Warning: All that weight causes wear and tear on front brakes and tires.

AWD

All-wheel drive is the kind of vehicle to own in the Snow Belt (and where the rain can be heavy) if you’re not a hard-core off-roader. It offers traction at all four wheels, but it apportions the amount of traction to the wheels without your input. So you don’t have to slow to a crawl and flip levers; you don’t have to get out and lock wheel hubs. Very civilized. And it’s easier on your wallet at the gas pumps, too.
Some all-wheel-drive systems also allow you to lock in four-wheel drive, making them more useful in snowier climes and off-road.

contributors.bio: I am a freelance writer in North Carolina, and I have been covering technology --including the technology in automobiles--since before Bill met Melinda or any of us met Google. pageElements.text:
1. The Tesla of the Future

The slickest piece of car technology I saw at the Consumer Electronics Show was this future-looking prototype Tesla in the Delphi booth. There was a lot of talk this year about autonomous driving. But this was a hands-on demonstration of the future. Once cars are tricked out with sensors and autonomous driving features, the driver will be free to focus on other things. How will that change the interior of the car? This gorgeous design feat is an imagining of the interior of that car of the future. With cameras to detect if the driver is paying attention, a huge in-dash screen, the ability to change the appearance of the dash with a 3D NVIDIA display that renders a stunning new look digitally, a projector capable of displaying movies on the interior of the windshield, and a complete gaming system in the back seat, it is a future I want to see.
Once cars are tricked out with sensors and autonomous driving features, the driver will be free to focus on other things. How will that change the interior of the car?

Since everyone in the car might be entertained in different ways, the sound system is personalized. Speakers in the left back seat play only for that passenger. And when the driver needs to take over driving, the car turns off the movie, flashes warnings, and – if you ignore that to send another email – it will buzz your seat and get aggressive. Those cameras and driver prompts help ensure the driver stays focused when he is driving as well.

2. Inductive Charging

Right now, car buyers are happy to get a few USB ports to keep devices charged while driving. But in a few years, those USB ports will be the cigarette lighter of previous generations. Cars will increasingly install much slicker wireless inductive charging systems. Just drop your phone on a flat surface on the dash, and it will connect to your telematics system and charge your device wirelessly. In the back seat, perhaps you’ll find a larger mount for a tablet so the kids can watch a movie while charging their tablet. Inductive charging is already built into in many new smartphones. (I charged my own Nexus 5 while listening to the Delphi rep explain the system.) And these chargers are widely available for phones. (Just search for Qi wireless chargers on Amazon.com.) It’s just a matter of time before they comes as standard features in cars.

3. Delphi Connect

There were some amazingly connected cars at CES. And there's a lot of forward-looking technology that won’t be available until later in the year … or further. It all made me look at my car’s in-dash telematics system with disgust. This Delphi solution to connected-car envy is available now (at delphiconnect.com) and doesn’t require a new car or a professional installation. Just plug this little unit into your car’s OBD-II port, download an app to your tablet or smartphone, mount that tablet to your dash, and MacGyver yourself an elegant solution for $199 plus a data plan for your car. (A version without Wi-Fi is $99.) It’s even better, actually, than some current in-dash systems. It gives you location tracking of the car (with geo-fencing so you can get alerts if your car leaves home, or wherever you set up a fence, without you), health data on your car, and turns your phone into another key fob that can start the car.

4. Pioneer NEX

Another solution for connected-car envy is this in-dash system from Pioneer. Plug in your phone (Android or iOS), and it will grab all the apps you already use and make them pretty for the in-dash display. App developers have to have created a version for NEX for them to show up here; there are many of these. You can listen to your own Pandora station, send a Glympse, and watch Netflix (if you are parked). It's almost like having your smartphone re-created on the dash. There's a range of models, but the high-end one boasts a slick capacitive touch screen with pinch and zoom.

5. Head-Up Display in the Mazda 3

Mazda was showcasing some slick technology in the Mazda 3 on the show floor. My favorite tool in that arsenal was the small rear projector just above the steering wheel that projected driver-related information to a spot that appeared about five feet away from the driver’s eye on the hood of the car. This is a secondary display; the car also has a raised display in the dash for navigation, music, apps, and other information. It shows the driver only driver-related information such as speed and when, according to the nav system, you should turn next. It’s a slick way to help keep the driver informed without asking her to look away from the road and find clues in a confusing in-dash screen.

6. 4G in the Car

As if Onstar – with its team of people at the ready to help you at the push of a button when you’re driving – wasn’t cool enough, going forward into 2014 and 2015, buying a GM car with Onstar means your car will come with a 4G LTE hotspot that delivers fast Internet access to up to seven devices in your car. Best part? According to the man in the GM booth at CES, it won’t matter if you buy a high-end luxury car or something in the $12K range, the Webernets come with. That’s the best reason to buy American you can give to a geek.

title: Has Michelin Made a Safer Tire?

promoTeaser: Hidden grooves on Premier A/S tires appear as the tread wears down, to keep good traction longer.
metaTitle: Has Michelin Made a Safer Tire? - JeanKnowsCars.com
metaDescription: Has Michelin Made a Safer Tire? News of a tire that can extend

pageElements.text: Michelin unveiled a new tire at the North American International Auto Show in Detroit today, the Premier A/S. So far, so dull, but it does have a new technology with an encouraging name: EverGrip.

EverGrip is all about making a tire stop quicker for a longer period of time, always good news for the frugal and the safety concerned. Michelin claims that when this tire is 50 percent through its normal life span, it will still stop a car length shorter than the competition's brand-new tires. (When they're both new, it will stop two car lengths sooner, the tiremaker says.) Here's how it works.

Key to the new Michelin tire's stopping power is a blend of ingredients including an "extreme" amount of silica and sunflower oil to help the tire maintain grip, especially at low temperatures and in the rain. But the magic sauce is that, when the tire begins to wear out, a second set of grooves emerges. These grooves on the tire's shoulder—some 150 of them—were hidden when the tire was brand-new (so the surfaces of a new and an old Premier A/S look very different).  There's also a set of expanding rain grooves that get wider as the tread wears out, which Michelin says helps keep the tires channeling water away for continued good traction.

As Jean has pointed out in a recent Number One Ladies' Driving Academy video, you are counting on four little patches of rubber, each about the size of an envelope, to keep you on the road. And, as Michelin points out, the average family car comes to a stop 41,288 times a year. (Go ahead, count for a year, and see if they're right.)
The tires go on sale this spring in thirty-two sizes for cars ranging from the Toyota Camry to the Cadillac CTS. They'll cost a suggested retail price of $156 and come with a 60,000-mile warranty.

contributors.bio:
Sheer serendipity.  That’s how I became a contributor to Jean Knows Cars.  Well into a lovely dinner party, I received a most unlikely suggestion:  “You should write about cars from your perspective – a 4’11” single mother with a ten-year-old minivan who drives around three overactive children and a Bernese Mountain Dog.  Theatre, swimming, hockey, lacrosse, figure skating, field hockey… You love to tell stories. Tell them about cars.”  I suggested that my background possibly lacked necessary expertise – B.A. from Duke in art history and medieval/Renaissance studies; Fellow of the American Academy in Rome; Ph.D. from the University of Michigan in medieval architecture --  nothing about cars there!  My friend persisted, “You may be an art historian, but you are also a hockey mother who can whistle like a trucker, a runner, and a lover of good food, wine and the written word.”

I pondered.  The auto industry and I did have a long, if tangential, history.  I did a stint as an executive secretary to the president of a car dealership and spent fifteen years negotiating a dual identity as an academic and as auto company spouse.  I have always suffered from car envy, particularly acutely when I lived in Europe.  (As envy and lust are amongst the seven deadly sins, I’m in trouble.) Automobiles, functional objects that often shape image, are fundamental elements of today’s society.  This would be another mode of cultural analysis and critique.  Couched in that light, it made perfect sense!

(And, I really can whistle like a trucker, but louder. I may be an art historian, but don’t sit next to me at a hockey rink.)

pageElements.text: Most consumers tend to approach auto insurance with an eye to the vehicle insured. What’s the deductible? Would my repairs be covered in the event of an accident? There are, however, four components to insurance. The first two involve the vehicle, of course, but the second two help you by protecting you financially. My agent, Nathan Lamb, whom you may have met in last week's Insurance Checkup Time, explained it all this way. It's important to note that I live in Michigan, one of twelve states with "no fault" laws governing the way auto coverage works. The laws in your state and therefore, the insurance coverage, may be different.

1. Collision Coverage

Collision insurance, as its name implies, covers you if you hit something. If you’re at fault, your rating will be affected, likely making future coverage more expensive. The type of collision coverage you chose will depend on a variety of factors, including the age of the car and your tolerance for risk.

In Michigan, a “no fault” state (offerings vary state by state), there are three types of collision coverage.
    1. Regular collision pays for damage to your car from an accident. Regardless of who is at fault, you are responsible for the deductible.
    2. Broad collision also pays for damage to your car from an accident. It absolves you of paying the deductible if you are not more than 50 percent at fault.
    3. Limited collision coverage says that, if you’re at fault, the policy won't cover you at all; if the other party is at fault, your insurance covers the damage, although you still have to pay the deductible.

2. Comprehensive Coverage

"Comprehensive" insurance covers acts of God, things like hail damage, a tree falling on your car, or a deer trying to jump in for a ride. It will trigger payment of a deductible, as our recent story on a flying-tire incident unfortunately highlighted.
Check your liability. No one likes to think about the Worst Day, but it is, in fact, that day for which you really have insurance coverage.,

3. Property Protection (PPI)

Property protection insurance covers damage to other people's property. Say you blow a tire driving down Main Street, lose control, and hit someone’s front porch. That’s when property damage coverage comes into play. In Michigan, the state minimum is $10,000; most insurers recommend coverage for $1 million.The increase in coverage generally costs only a couple of dollars a month, and, think about it, $10,000 doesn’t cover you for much if you’ve inadvertently done structural damage to the house when you "parked" on the porch.

4. Residual Liability

This coverage, known as Residual Bodily Injury and Property Damage Liability insurance, covers you if you are found responsible or get sued as the result of an accident. In Michigan, the state minimum follows the 20/40 rule; you must have coverage for $20,000 per person and up to $40,000 per accident. Such minimal coverage, however, does not protect you from what Nathan calls “the Worst Day” event. Black ice prevents you from stopping at an intersection and when you slide through, you hit a car with four occupants, causing injury, or God forbid, death. You are at fault; they sue and win a $250,000 judgment per passenger. You are now responsible for $1 million. Under 20/40, which may have seemed the best option because of the minimal monthly premium, you are covered for only $40,000. The other $960,000? Your responsibility, and you could work for rest of your life, with 25 percent of your wages garnished, until you have settled that debt. Check your liability. No one likes to think about the Worst Day, but it is, in fact, that day for which you really have insurance coverage.,

contributors.bio: I have spent a lot of time on the road. I started touring with a band along with my older brother, Ryan, when I was still in high school, and in all I have put in a little over ten years of touring. Eventually we were in a band named Thunderbirds Are Now! We played many festivals including SXSW, CMJ, and Pitchfork, toured all over the country and all over Europe, went to Australia, were in a lot of magazines, and had an exciting time. We spent thousands of hours inside a 15-passenger red Ford Econoline van we bought that we called Old Magent. That was where we had our down time. We spent more time in the van than we did playing the shows. When we toured outside the country, we had drivers. My strongest memory of that is being picked up in a Mercedes Sprinter van by someone we had never seen before and being driven through deep snow from Germany to Sweden—a 15-hour drive—through the mountains at high speed. Everyone in the band wrote final messages to our families and put them in our pockets just in case. Touring with a band is very scary but also very fun. A lot of weird and new things happened in my life, but they are great memories I'll never forget, and it was time well spent living a dream that came true. But all good things come to an end. You're up every night, and it just gets hard. I was lucky that my father was a musician and built a recording studio in our basement, and he also shot a lot of videos. I have been recording my own music and making stop-animation video since I was a young kid. After leaving the band, I went to Washtenaw Community College to study videography and won a couple of awards—Most Creative two years in a row, and Best in Show. I was doing freelance post-production video editing when I met Jean Jennings, and we instantly clicked. She likes music, I like music, and we just "get" each other. I've had a very, very strange route to where I am now. I'm happy that I can settle in with Jean Knows Cars and live a normal life but still with a creative outlook. Here's an interview with Scott by CBS Detroit in July 2013:

Jean Knows Cars is not just the name of this website; it's a true fact. I have been writing about cars and the car business for more than 30 years, having learned about cars at the kitchen table from my late father, Robert Lienert, who was the editor of Automotive News. At age eighteen, I bought a used car, painted it yellow, installed a toplight and a meter, and joined the Yellow Cab Company in Ann Arbor, Michigan, as an owner/operator. Five years later, I got a job at Chrysler’s test track as a test driver, welder, and mechanic in the impact lab. In 1980, I was hired as a writer at Car and Driver magazine after getting laid off at Chrysler, and in 1985 I left to establish Automobile Magazine with David E. Davis, Jr. I was the magazine’s first Executive Editor, became Editor in Chief in 2000, and added the title of President of Automobile Magazine in 2006.

I’ve been profiled in The New Yorker and have been a guest on the Tonight Show with Jay Leno. I was a guest on the Oprah Winfrey Show, teaching Oprah and her studio audience how to change a tire and to jump a battery. I was Good Morning America’s automotive correspondent from 1994 to 2000 and then did the same thing for the Oxygen network.

 I have won awards for feature writing, car reviews, and my monthly Automobile Magazine column, “Vile Gossip,” including the 2007 Ken Purdy Award for Excellence in Automotive Journalism.  I’m a regular on-air contributor to Fox Business Network; CNBC’s Closing Bell, Squawk Box, Behind the Wheel, and Power Lunch; MSNBC; CBS This Morning and Evening News; and CNN’s American Morning and Headline News. In fact, I would almost call myself a TV slut, but I’m proud to say that I turned Geraldo down.

All of this has taken place in a male-dominated automotive space, where I’m all too frequently the only woman in the room. I know the secret handshake, but JeanKnowsCars.com is going to be a place where you don’t have to. 

I live in the Michigan countryside with my husband, Tim, and the entire food chain. You’re going to get to know my driveway and my dogs really, really well. Just keep reading.

pageElements.text:
I found the Cadillac ATS to be the most refined and beautiful execution of the Cadillac design language, which, up to this point, has been sharp edged and wedge shaped to a fault. There is no question about what you’re looking at when you see a current Cadillac go by, so in that case, the mission has been accomplished. In this ATS Coupe, the wedge is knocked down and smoothed out. It’s very much reminiscent of the sensuous Elmiraj concept that was shown first at the 2013 Pebble Beach Concours d’Elegance and was at this year’s Detroit Auto Show in all its glory.

My immediate response to it was absolutely visceral. I wanted to touch it, I wanted to walk around it, and as chief exterior designer Bob Boniface talked about it, I kept putting my hand on it. If you listen to him on this video, you’ll hear a very lyrical explanation of just why I responded the way I did.
