title: 4 Scooters to Try
subTitle: Dolce vita motoring at popular prices. If we're showing you scooters, can spring be far behind?
promoTeaserSmall: Dolce vita motoring at popular prices. If we're showing you scooters, can spring be far behind?
promoTeaser: Dolce vita motoring at popular prices. If we're showing you scooters, can spring be far behind?
metaDescription: 4 Scooters to Try

contributors.bio: I'm the auto and motorcycle critic for the Orange County Register. Previously, I  was a staff writer at the Los Angeles Times for fourteen years, writing about motorcycles, cars, green living, and anything else that caught my fancy. Originally from Ann Arbor, Michigan, I currently live in Los Angeles with my ten-year-old son.

pageElements.text: Catering to urban riders who are more concerned with pragmatism than with puffery, scooters aren’t just a fun way to get around. They’re easier to ride and less intimidating than motorcycles. Having no-muss-no-fuss automatic transmissions and step-through, rather than swing-a-leg-over, designs that let the fairer sex dress like sophisticates rather than gearheads, they’re also less expensive to buy and to operate.
Scooters start at a mere $2,000 and boast fuel economy figures that are likely to inspire a double take: 100-plus mpg.

While the average U.S. passenger car costs about $30,000 and chugs along at 23 mpg, and a typical motorcycle stands at a slightly improved $14,000 and 50 mpg, scooters start at a mere $2,000 and boast fuel economy figures that are likely to inspire a double take: 100-plus mpg.

Available in a surprising array of sizes and styles, ranging from 50cc college campus runabouts to 650s that can pack an extra person and even luggage for a cross-country trip, it’s no surprise that scooters are so popular among women. So let me walk you through a handful of models to get started.

Vespa LX ($3,399+)

The gold standard of scooters, Vespa is the brand that birthed the whole concept back in 1946. In the years since, its iconic Italian style has barely changed. It is the only scooter with a body built from a single sheet of stainless steel rather than a tubular frame covered with plastic. Available in a palette of classic colors, including mint green, the Vespa LX 50 gets 85 mpg and has a top speed of 39 mph, as well as a disc brake on its front wheel to help it stop more effectively. Under-seat storage can accommodate a half helmet. The LX is also available with a larger 150cc engine, which jacks up its top speed to 59 mph and its price to $4,599.

Genuine Scooter Co. Buddy ($1,999+)

It’s funny that a bike looking so shamelessly similar to something else—Vespa—calls itself Genuine, but the twelve-year-old Chicago-based scooter maker has distinguished itself with one of the top-selling scooters in the United States, the Genuine Scooter Co. Buddy. Coupling vintage style with modern technology, its Buddy model offers modern conveniences such as a twelve-volt cell phone/iPod charger. It’s available in a range of perky colors and increasingly peppy engine sizes, from a 50 cc (with a starting price of $1,999 and top speed of 30 mph) to a 125 cc ($2,799 and 50 mph top speed) and 170 cc ($3,349 and 55 mph). Think Vespa, only the Buddy is made in Taiwan and costs about half the price.

Honda Ruckus ($2,649)

If attention is what you want, you’re likely to get it on board the Honda Ruckus. One of the more eye-catching scooters on the market, the Ruckus is a so-called “naked” because the bodywork is missing and the frame is exposed. In Honda’s home country, scooterists were ripping the body panels off their scooters to make them look more radical, so the Japanese company cut to the chase and did it for them. Powered with a 49-cc single-cylinder engine and weighing just 194 pounds, the Ruckus’s biggest strength is its style and its fuel economy, which Honda estimates at 114 mpg.

Yamaha Zuma ($2,590+)

Yamaha is best known for sport bikes that can go 100 mph in first gear, but the Japanese company imports some of that technology to the Yamaha Zuma scooter, which can be had as both a 50 cc ($2,590) and a 125 cc ($3,390). The Zuma’s windswept body work and twin headlamps give it a a more sporty, modern style that also plays out under the hood. Its tires are wider than most scooters, and they’re stopped with a front disc brake painted racy red. Under-seat storage can even hold a sport biker-esque full-face helmet.

contributors.bio: When I turned sixteen, my dad brought home the very first-generation Ford Escort wagon, and it just so happened to have a manual transmission. Since—like every other sixteen-year-old—I knew everything, I was sure that I would just get behind the wheel and effortlessly shift gears. Visions of screeching into the school parking lot with my shiny red "world car" and impressing all the burnouts who hung out near their Detroit muscle cars danced in my head. All of those dreams were quickly extinguished in the first fifteen minutes of my driving lesson from my dad. Although he has a teaching certificate, patience is not his strongest skill. The subtle foot-hand coordination escaped me, and we were jerking around the subdivision like the contestants in a game of Red Light Green Light. I blamed my dad, and he blamed me. To my astonishment, he decided it was best to abandon ship and allow me to figure out how to get home. Somehow I managed to limp home without needing therapy for whiplash. After our wounds had healed I did end up learning to drive a manual on that trusty steed. I ended up driving my Escort to Northern Michigan University in Marquette, in Michigan’s frigid Upper Peninsula, where I obtained a BFA, with a concentration in Graphic Design, and a future husband. I joined Automobile Magazine at the tender age of twenty-eight and fell in love with the energy and passion for automobiles and the way they enhance our lives. Later, I took a five-year hiatus and boned up my design and web skills and am now turbocharged to be a part of the Jean Knows Cars team. Many years have passed, and now my sixteen-year-old only child is poised to learn to drive a manual, and I can’t help but be transported back to my teens. Unlike my parents, I am a helicopter mom. Riding in the passenger's seat with her behind the wheel is like waterboarding. I want to order her to pull over and allow me to drive and throw her in the back seat with airbags strapped directly on her. Many of her peers will not learn to drive a manual, but I believe that it is the building block for a good safe driver. It is a perfect synergy watching my daughter learn to drive and helping Jean Knows Cars celebrate and embrace the automobile and how it is woven into our lives.

pageElements.text:
2014 Nissan Altima 2.5 SL

Price: $28,550 (base price of this model, including destination)
$30,625 as tested (including destination)
Engine: 2.5-liter four-cylinder, 182 horsepower
Transmission: Continuously variable (CVT)
Fuel economy: 27 mpg city/38 mpg highway
My favorite standard feature: Heated leather-wrapped steering wheel
Option I can’t live without: Lane departure warning (part of $1,090 Technology package)
Notable standard features on this model: Easy Fill Tire Alert, remote start
Notable options on this model: Blind spot warning, land departure warning, moving object detection, and a navigation system, all included in the $1,090 Technology package; Moonroof ($800)
You might also be considering: Ford Fusion, Honda Accord, Hyundai Sonata, Toyota Camry

I associate Nissan with slightly quirky design—think Cube, Juke, Leaf, and even Murano. But, when it comes to the Altima, Nissan has always leaned toward a more conservative style. It is number three in the jam-packed mid-size-sedan segment in sales behind the Toyota Camry and Honda Accord, and it did not get to this lofty position by taking risks.

In 2013 the Altima was completely redesigned. It achieved a modern appearance without straying far from its predecessor. A curving character line flows from the front headlight and along the side, leading nicely into the small spoiler on the rear. The trapezoidal grille that is integrated with the standard halogen headlights delivers a slightly aggressive look to the front. It is more Miss Congeniality than Miss Mid-Size Sedan, but really, with whom would you rather spend the day?

I drove the 2.5-liter four-cylinder version and stayed mostly to city driving. I found the experience sportier than I had anticipated. There was plenty of power, and the car delivered adequate acceleration for passing when I did take a quick highway drive. For buyers who want an even sportier family sedan, there is also a 3.5-liter with a V-6 that includes paddle shifters. As a fan of paddle shifters, I vote for the V-6, but if fuel economy is paramount in your decision stick with the four-cylinder, since the V-6 gets 22 mpg in town and 31 mpg on the highway, which compares unfavorably with the four-cylinder's 27/38 mpg. Both engines are paired with a continuously variable transmission that helps achieve the impressive mpg numbers, but it does make for a louder ride.

Warning to coupe buyers: Nissan is no longer offering the coupe version. In fact the Honda Accord is your only coupe choice, unless you jump up to the premium category. Some buyers whose main desire is for a mid-size coupe may opt to move into the muscle car category and take a look at the Chevrolet Camaro or the Ford Mustang.

There are three available trim levels, the S, the SV, and the top-of-the-line SL, each of which can be paired with either engine. It is worth mentioning that every Altima comes with push-button start and a clever feature called Easy Fill Tire Alert. This feature is perfect for me (and anyone who's not mechanical): you can just start adding air to your tires, and when you achieve the proper pressure the horn beeps. Genius.

During the snowy week when we tested the Altima, I was glad to have the SL, which comes standard with a triumvirate of heated features: front seats, steering wheel, and outside mirrors. To put the icing on the cake and take the ice off your windshield, the SL comes standard with remote start—cue the angels singing. Had the Altima arrived in Los Angeles for a drive the same week, I might have overlooked these details and bestowed my praise instead on the virtues of the LED taillights, the eight-way power driver's seat (with power lumbar), or the premium Bose sound system.

We opted to add a moonroof for $800, carpeted floor and trunk mats for $185, and the Technology package for $1,090. This reasonably priced package includes navigation, blind spot warning, lane departure warning, and moving object detection that up the safety features of this model and to me are a must.

If safety is guiding your decision, you will need to step up to an SV or SL. In either version, the Technology package is an option and a backup camera is standard. The National Highway Traffic Safety Administration (NHTSA) gave the Altima the top five stars overall and five stars each for front and side crash protection. The Insurance Institute for Highway Safety rated it Good, the IIHS's best rating, in three crash tests: offset front (moderate overlap), side impact, and roof strength. In the new small-overlap front test, the Altima earned the second best Acceptable rating.

The interior of the Altima follows the same conservative design cues as the exterior. The SL has wood-tone trim that left me unimpressed, but the NissanConnect that integrates apps such as Pandora gets my nod. The hands-free texting is a good idea in theory, but in my opinion a step too far. Please wait until you are not responsible for piloting a 3,200-pound vehicle down the road to send your text messages.

The cabin is generally roomy, but the rear headroom may have your taller passengers calling foul. The 4.0-inch LCD screen for driver information is situated between the speedometer and the tachometer. The seats were inspired by research done by NASA on "zero gravity" seats, and the SL version is leather. These seats are among the most comfortable seats my behind has ever experienced, especially at this price. All trim levels have a 60/40 rear seat that affords a wide pass-through to the trunk.

The Verdict:

If you are in the market for a mid-size sedan, the fuel economy of the Altima demands your attention. The upscale interior at a fraction of the cost of a premium-price sedan may be enough to entice you to plunk down the modest cost of the Altima. If economy or luxury don’t win you over, the NASA-inspired seats may push you over the edge if you are a long-distance driver. Your tush will thank you.

Peanut Gallery:

Laura Sky Brown: You can't tell by looking at the Altima how pleasant it is to drive. Even with the four-cylinder engine, it has enough of everything: power, spirit, and comfort. Kudos to Nissan for getting 38 highway miles per gallon out of a sedan that doesn't feel like a compromise. It explains why it's a strong seller in the ultracompetitive mid-size segment. You can get a nicely equipped Altima for under $25,000, but I would strongly recommend getting the upper trim levels to be eligible for the Technology package, which contains many of the latest safety features for a reasonable $1,090.

Having said that, if I were buying a Nissan, I might want to go with some of the more colorful ones, such as the Juke or even the Leaf. It would be hard for me to sail past those at the dealership in favor of the rather bland Altima, but it just might be the right thing to do.

contributors.bio: When I turned sixteen, my dad brought home the very first-generation Ford Escort wagon, and it just so happened to have a manual transmission. Since—like every other sixteen-year-old—I knew everything, I was sure that I would just get behind the wheel and effortlessly shift gears. Visions of screeching into the school parking lot with my shiny red "world car" and impressing all the burnouts who hung out near their Detroit muscle cars danced in my head. All of those dreams were quickly extinguished in the first fifteen minutes of my driving lesson from my dad. Although he has a teaching certificate, patience is not his strongest skill. The subtle foot-hand coordination escaped me, and we were jerking around the subdivision like the contestants in a game of Red Light Green Light. I blamed my dad, and he blamed me. To my astonishment, he decided it was best to abandon ship and allow me to figure out how to get home. Somehow I managed to limp home without needing therapy for whiplash. After our wounds had healed I did end up learning to drive a manual on that trusty steed. I ended up driving my Escort to Northern Michigan University in Marquette, in Michigan’s frigid Upper Peninsula, where I obtained a BFA, with a concentration in Graphic Design, and a future husband. I joined Automobile Magazine at the tender age of twenty-eight and fell in love with the energy and passion for automobiles and the way they enhance our lives. Later, I took a five-year hiatus and boned up my design and web skills and am now turbocharged to be a part of the Jean Knows Cars team. Many years have passed, and now my sixteen-year-old only child is poised to learn to drive a manual, and I can’t help but be transported back to my teens. Unlike my parents, I am a helicopter mom. Riding in the passenger's seat with her behind the wheel is like waterboarding. I want to order her to pull over and allow me to drive and throw her in the back seat with airbags strapped directly on her. Many of her peers will not learn to drive a manual, but I believe that it is the building block for a good safe driver. It is a perfect synergy watching my daughter learn to drive and helping Jean Knows Cars celebrate and embrace the automobile and how it is woven into our lives.

pageElements.text: Have you ever played a game called Forza Motorsport? Now in its fifth edition, the game lets you customize, collect, and virtually drive some of the most exciting cars in the world. You have to think that a lot of the gamers would choose that fetish tuner car, the Honda Civic Si. And you're right: players have downloaded more than a million Honda accessories through their relationship with this game.

So it's logical that Honda would come up with a tie-in promotion. Players were invited to design a Civic Si within the game and enter it into a contest. The gamers themselves voted and chose a winner. Okay, can you picture the car-crazed teenage boy (or middle-aged dreamer) who won? Guess again.

Tiffany Labedz won. That's right, I said it, a girl. She is an avid player of Forza Motorsport 4, saw a popup for the contest, and entered it. One look at her customized Civic Si, which I got to see in person at the Chicago Auto Show, and you understand why her car was chosen out of 170 entries.

Tom Peyton of Honda told me a little about the rationale for the contest. "We understand that the gamers are a point of entry for getting into the actual vehicles," he said. "We're trying to get people to have an affinity for our products," with the idea that they'll buy a real one when the time comes. "People have a huge emotional relationship with the cars" in Forza Motorsport, he explained.
One look at her customized Civic Si, which I got to see in person at the Chicago Auto Show, and you understand why her car was chosen.
That makes sense to me, as a northern Michigander who has spent many hours listening to the Chevy truck and Ford truck guys sitting in bars arguing over why the brand they own is better.

And it clearly makes sense to Tiffany. She lives in Mesa, Arizona, where she works for U-Haul. I asked her, "Do you find that you're a little lost in this whole boy world?" She said her best friend is a gamer, too, and she was extremely articulate about her reasons for liking Forza Motorsport, including the fact that you can add realistic options onto the car and customize the interiors. She even knows people who have taken the game further and actually gone out and test driven the cars they enjoyed most in the game.

Other than the Honda Civic Si, Tiffany has driven a Cadillac CTS during game play. I asked her, "Can you tell the difference from one car to the other in the game?" She says you can. She and others of her ilk will enjoy a new Honda Legends Car Pack for the newly released Forza Motorsport 5, which includes the 2014 Civic Si, the 1984 Mugen CRX, and the 1994 Prelude. The game is only playable on the also newly released Xbox One gaming system.

The Chicago Auto Show appearance must have been a fun perk for Tiffany, and she also won prizes including an Xbox gift card and a steering wheel for gaming, but she doesn't get to drive her Honda Civic Si away. The car will continue on a publicity tour without her.

contributors.bio: I am a person who loves to study other people. I like to interview them, learn about their lives, photograph them, and write their stories. The people at Jean Knows Cars noticed me through my project, Humans of Ann Arbor. In that project, I tool around the city of Ann Arbor, introducing myself to anyone who draws my eye. If they are open to it, I take a photo of them and hear a little bit about them. Then I post the photos and stories on Facebook. Humans of Ann Arbor has followers from all over the world who check in on a daily basis to see ordinary people and their extraordinary stories. I have been studying people since I was a little girl in Missouri. Where I grew up, studying people often led you to the cars they loved. My grandpa had a gas station in Claycomo, Missouri, which he opened in the 1950s, and he passed his love of cars and taking care of the people who drove them down to my dad. Dad was a mechanic and a service supervisor all his life. We had a steady barrage of cars coming into our lives…mostly Chevys. To impress my dad, I learned to identify every car I could, and I used to name the cars while we drove down the road. Car culture is big in Missouri. Would you believe that I had friends who were sisters named Nova and Chevelle? If you didn’t grow up the way I did, you might not get the significance of that, but suffice it to say that my people love their cars. The car I adored most was the Chevrolet Corvair my dad gave me when I was in high school. It spent more time in my dad's shop than it did on the road, but in those moments when it was drivable, I knew what it was to love a car. It was a thing of beauty: pale cream with a plaid madras interior. I loved the sound and feel of the engine…it was more like a soft purr than a roar. I can still remember how it smelled and what it was like to drive it with the windows rolled down on a warm day. I've had lots of cars since then, and I loved some of them, too. But the Corvair was my first car love and will always be my favorite. After high school, I drove my car to Springfield, Missouri, to study communications at Missouri State. Later, I drove a different car to Chicago to study photography at Columbia College. I worked in Chicago as a freelance photographer and studio manager for many years before moving to Ann Arbor, where I continue to do freelance photography. I am excited about combining my love of studying people with my interest in cars. I want to explore how cars serve us, how they are intertwined in our lives, and what makes us love them. I can't wait to let you know what I find out.

pageElements.text:
Don’t tell my kid, but before the term “screen time” was coined I spent a huge chunk of my
childhood playing video games and pinball in my neighborhood arcade.  It was the pinball
that separated me from most of my lunch money, though.  There was something I loved
about the mechanical whir of the machine paired with bells and flashing lights as the ball
ricocheted its way around.  I don’t get to spend much time in arcades anymore, though, so I
was ecstatic when I came across the Ford Mustang pinball machines at the Chicago Auto Show.

Ford and Stern Pinball teamed up to create a trio of pinball games that celebrate the fiftieth anniversary of the iconic Mustang, and the game is rolling out to the public at the Chicago Auto Show. It goes on sale on April 1, mainly intended for arcades and other public spaces. (But you can pre-order one of your own through Ford's merchandise website; it'll cost $4,995, plus $300 shipping.)

The pinball machine is as shiny and sleek as the car it represents. Instead of bells, the sound of revving Mustang engines punctuates the game play, and in place of levels there are “gears” to work through. Mach 1, Cobra, and Boss Mustangs are all represented as well as, of course, the 2015 Mustang. There are eight scenarios from drag racing to road rallies to police pursuits. At the highest level of achievement, you advance to the Silverball Stampede, a coast-to-coast run set to the music of the past fifty years, from Jan & Dean through Motörhead. Stunt driver/TV host Tanner Foust narrates the action.

It was the absolute luckiest time for me to have found those pinball machines.  Zach Sharpe, who holds the honor of being 2013’s World’s
Greatest Pinball Player, was on hand to demonstrate the game.  Zach reminded me of a
few of the fundamentals, and before long my flipper fingers were warmed up.   If, like me,
you are an aspiring pinball wizard, here are Zach’s tips to up your game:

1. Read the Game

Don’t just drop your quarter in willy-nilly. Pinball machines have basic instructions to get you started. Look at text near the flippers and on the display board before you play. Sometimes pressing the flipper gives you additional information.

2. Follow the Light

Don’t worry, no one has ever died from playing pinball that we know of, so we don’t mean that kind of light. Pinball machines have lights that tell you where to aim the ball. If you watch the display, it will help you know when to go for extra points and multi-ball play. Targets that will earn you points also light up.

3. Get Physical

Move the machine with your body to get the ball to go where you want it to. “Don’t be afraid to get physical,” Zach advised. “The game will let you know when you’ve pushed it too far.” Yep, with a big, fat TILT. I had forgotten about that. Luckily for me, the machine was set on a two-minute unlimited ball setting, or I would have been done in about thirty seconds.

4. Control the Chaos

It may seem like happenstance that the ball goes where it does inside the pinball machine, but experienced players can call a shot and send the ball exactly where they say they will. One way to gain some control is to stop the ball with the flipper. With some practice, you can learn to let the ball start to roll down the flipper, and pick the right moment to flip it to make it go in the direction you want.

5. Flip Independently

“A lot of people make the mistake of using both flippers at exactly the same time,” Zach said. “You have to use them separately to gain control of the ball sometimes.” Giving that a try significantly improved my game.

You might want to keep these tips to yourself, at least until you take a shot at getting the high score at the Chicago Auto Show.  I’ll be practicing myself, and I’ll probably be taking my son.  A lot.  I mean, technically it isn’t screen time, right?

More about the Ford Mustang Pinball Machine

• The artwork is by Ford GT designer Camilo Pardo.
• There's a 1/24 scale decorative Mustang inside.
• The letters in the Mustang logo spell out one by one as you progress through the game.
• The game has twin stacked supercharger ramps.
• Among the cars that make up the game are the 2015 Mustang, plus GT, Mach 1, Cobra, and Boss Mustang models of the past.
• You race them against game characters in eight scenarios, including drag racing, road racing, rallying, drifting, and police pursuit.
• Make your way up through the gears by taking down the "shift" drop targets to get to Gears Multiball.
• Earn Ford Racing parts to customize and modify your cars as you play.
• Get to the ultimate destination, the Silverball Stampede, described as "an all-out coast-to-coast run against all of the wacky opponents in the game."
• Narration by Tanner Foust; music by artists from the past fifty years, including Jan & Dean, Motörhead, and the Romantics.

contributors.bio: I have spent a lot of time on the road. I started touring with a band along with my older brother, Ryan, when I was still in high school, and in all I have put in a little over ten years of touring. Eventually we were in a band named Thunderbirds Are Now! We played many festivals including SXSW, CMJ, and Pitchfork, toured all over the country and all over Europe, went to Australia, were in a lot of magazines, and had an exciting time. We spent thousands of hours inside a 15-passenger red Ford Econoline van we bought that we called Old Magent. That was where we had our down time. We spent more time in the van than we did playing the shows. When we toured outside the country, we had drivers. My strongest memory of that is being picked up in a Mercedes Sprinter van by someone we had never seen before and being driven through deep snow from Germany to Sweden—a 15-hour drive—through the mountains at high speed. Everyone in the band wrote final messages to our families and put them in our pockets just in case. Touring with a band is very scary but also very fun. A lot of weird and new things happened in my life, but they are great memories I'll never forget, and it was time well spent living a dream that came true. But all good things come to an end. You're up every night, and it just gets hard. I was lucky that my father was a musician and built a recording studio in our basement, and he also shot a lot of videos. I have been recording my own music and making stop-animation video since I was a young kid. After leaving the band, I went to Washtenaw Community College to study videography and won a couple of awards—Most Creative two years in a row, and Best in Show. I was doing freelance post-production video editing when I met Jean Jennings, and we instantly clicked. She likes music, I like music, and we just "get" each other. I've had a very, very strange route to where I am now. I'm happy that I can settle in with Jean Knows Cars and live a normal life but still with a creative outlook. contributors.bio:
I am a recent graduate of Boston University thrilled to be working my first real job (in this case, “real” means I never have to use a mop).  I have previously appeared as a lifeguard, a mailroom lackey, a part-time nanny, and a fudge chef, but the real reason I'm here today is because someone once told me I could write and I believed them. As a writer and publisher for BU’s online magazine, I wrote about politics and current events and wrote two series: Foxy Congressperson of the Week, which is exactly what it sounds like, and An American in Paris, detailing my misadventures abroad. 

Growing up in Southeastern Michigan means that love of cars is practically a birthright, and one I’ve always been proud of. I still drive my first car, a beloved orange Chevy HHR that has been through the war and keeps on chugging. After three years on the East Coast, I’m happy to be back in a place where the speed limit is treated more as a guideline than a rule.

pageElements.text: Evidence is mounting that the doomsayers had it wrong when they told us that young people don’t care about cars. The newest study to suggest that people under the age of thirty-five like and want cars comes from Enterprise Holdings, the rental-car company. It says that young people are often inspired to start shopping for a new vehicle after a positive experience in a rental car.
The survey data came from more than 1,300 car owners, all over the age of twenty-five, all of whom had rented a car within the past six months. And here are five interesting things it revealed.

1. As a mind changer.

Enterprise found that, for 88 percent of millennials—twenty-five-to-thirty-four-year-olds, for these purposes—a positive car rental experience could change their opinion of a particular make or model. Just 71 percent of older respondents had their perception of specific cars altered by a rental experience.

2. As a technology showcase.

The study also found that young people were most likely to experience new automotive technology by using it in rental cars, since many don’t have access to brand-new cars of their own to drive. In the study, 68 percent of millennials reported they were more likely to experience new automotive technology as part of a rental car experience than any other way. This likely contributed to their potential to be impressed by rental cars, which are typically not the most thrilling cars on the road.

3. As an image enhancer.

We’ve heard before that young people are especially concerned with image when purchasing a car and want a brand and model that they feel will reflect their own personal style and sensibilities. Enterprise says youngsters approach choosing a rental car the same way: 57 percent of twenty-five-to-thirty-four-year-olds believe that a rental car choice says a lot about a person’s style, personality, and values. Young people aren’t just walking onto the lot and choosing the first car they see; they’re seeking out just the right vehicle to complement their character.

4. As a temporary change of pace.

Young people also view the car rental experience as an opportunity to try something new. More than half of the millennials surveyed indicated that they had a “desire to try something new” when driving a rental car. Older drivers want to play the field, too, if not in quite the numbers of their more youthful counterparts. More than one-third of all respondents said that they want to try something “completely new” when they drive a rental car.

5. As a pre-purchase test drive.

A good rental-car experience can do more than just change brand perception. It can actually propel people to the dealership. According to Enterprise, 58 percent of those surveyed consider cars they have previously rented when shopping for a vehicle, and 28 percent of surveyed millennials were inspired to start shopping for a car after a positive rental experience.

Drivers tired of boring rental cars can hope that this study inspires carmakers to flood rental fleets with fun new models aimed at buy-curious renters, but don’t expect too much: Escapism aside, nearly half of all the women surveyed said that fuel efficiency was one of the most important features in a rental car.

title: Bruce Weber's Detroit

pageElements.text: This is not the best time of year for Detroit’s closeup. The gray snow by the side of the road calls for hibernation, not glamour shots. So this is an especially nice time of year to see the photography of Bruce Weber, who has teamed with high-end watch and bicycle maker Shinola on a set of photos and videos to communicate the beauty of Detroit and its people.
These images and videos, titled “The Spirit of Detroit,” are up on the Shinola website now.
Video from Shinola's YouTube channel

If you’ve never heard Bruce Weber’s name, you’ve probably seen his work in places like Vanity Fair and Vogue magazines and the Abercrombie & Fitch store. You might also recognize blond model Carolyn Murphy, brought in to be part of the Detroit photos because she represents “the independent spirit of the American tomboy.”
We choose to enjoy these photos, hoping they help more people around the world think of Detroit as the vibrant, viable city it is.

These images are gorgeous, but are they an authentic picture of the struggling metropolis that is Detroit? Well, here's the thing. As the automakers return to their former greatness, buildings are repurposed, and the city in general begins to rise from the ashes, it’s important, we think, to avoid an “us versus them” mentality that holds Detroit back. So we choose to enjoy these photos, hoping they help more people around the world think of Detroit as the vibrant, viable city it is.

I asked young Detroit entrepreneur and grassroots change agent Andy Didorosi, who is the guy behind the nascent Detroit Bus Company and the Thunderdrome racing series, what he thinks about the Shinola/Bruce Weber photo project. He offered an incisive commentary on the project that's worth reading:

"Shinola is one very carefully executed marketing campaign.
While it's presented like a story of a die-hard Detroit-based company, it's really more similar to Astroturf.

"But the takeaway is: Let them spend their money. Let them hire Detroiters. Not everyone is going to be authentically local and we should be proud that the allure of the history of Detroit is strong enough to attract capital of that scale.
We're certainly not at the point—nor should we ever strive to be—where we can turn people away from taking part simply because they weren't born or raised here. And that goes for both brands and people.
"Is it marketing? Totally. Is it constructed? Every bit. But they're marketing us to the rest of the world and they're doing a damn good job of it."
The Bruce Weber videos and photography perfectly sum up the warmth I feel for Detroit, my birth city. - Jean

Setting aside all philosophical marketing arguments, Jean loves Shinola's products enough to have bought three different Shinola watches (The Runwell, The Gomelsky, and The Birdy) with leather straps made by Hadley-Roma in Largo, Florida; a set of small linen notebooks (made by historic Edwards Brothers Malloy in Ann Arbor); and a gorgeous leather envelope for her iPad Mini made by craftsmen in Missouri from hides tanned by a 100-plus-year-old Chicago company, Horween. She explains: “I love my watches, I love the thickness and richness of my iPad cover, and I love to use the little notebooks. The specialness is not only in knowing where each one came from, but in actually knowing the name of the people who made each of the Shinola pieces I bought.

“I’ve gotten over the fact that the company is owned and led by people who aren’t Detroiters, but who are using Detroit to give themselves an air of urban authenticity. In the end, they are creating jobs and they’re producing desirable, fashionable products, and they’ve stamped MADE IN DETROIT on them. I like that very much. The Bruce Weber videos and photography perfectly sum up the warmth I feel for Detroit, my birth city.”

pageElements.text: IntelliChoice, the automotive value analysis firm, announced its picks for Best Overall Value of the Year (BOVY) awards this week, and the results are interesting, even if they probably won’t surprise you.

Each year, IntelliChoice looks at data from each car model sold to determine the vehicles that have not only low overall ownership costs, but also lower than expected costs compared to similar models. It then picks several cars in each category (convertible, coupe, hatchback, sedan, utility, truck, van, and wagon) for the BOVYs. IntelliChoice also picks overall winners for the best value in a popular and premium vehicle and a popular and premium brand.

Together, Toyota and Lexus swept the four top honors, adding credence to the carmaker’s reputation as a smart buy. Toyota and Lexus were named best overall value in a popular brand and premium brand, respectively. The 2014 Toyota Yaris two-door hatchback was named best overall value for a popular car.
The Lexus RX350 crossover took best overall value for a premium vehicle. Together, Toyota and Lexus won twelve classes, including a sweep of the truck, hatchback, and van categories.

While Japanese carmakers earned many of IntelliChoice’s awards in 2014, German automakers held their own in the premium and performance categories. Audi made a strong showing in the convertible and coupe segments, earning BOVYs for several versions of the Audi R8 supercar and Audi A5 sport coupe.
The brand-new Mercedes-Benz CLA45 AMG was recognized the best value in a premium performance car, earning Mercedes-Benz’s only BOVY award for 2014.
Other awards were garnered by BMW, for the BMW Z4 28i (shown here) and 528i, and the Mini Cooper convertible.

By contrast, only two American-brand vehicles snagged awards. The 2014 Ford Mustang GT was recognized as BOVY for a performance car, while the Chevrolet Tahoe took home honors in the premium full-size utility category.

There’s a lot to consider when buying a car. If you’re looking for a Lamborghini or a Bentley, value probably isn’t as high on your list as style or brand cachet. For the rest of us, though, the BOVY awards can be a valuable tool in the car-buying process. They look beyond sticker price to see how much a car will cost to own, and how it stacks up to its direct competition. If you’re in the market for a new car, take a look at IntelliChoice’s rankings to see if your top choice made the cut.

contributors.bio: I am a freelance writer in North Carolina, and I have been covering technology --including the technology in automobiles--since before Bill met Melinda or any of us met Google. I also write about education, parenting, family travel, and gardening. I currently write the Family Tech column in Family Circle magazine and Family Tech with Christina at FamilyCircle.com, and I blog on the Geek Girlfriends site. Clients--past and present--include Better Homes and Gardens, Popular Science, This Old House Magazine, USA Weekend, PC Magazine, PC World, Jaguar, Saks Fifth Avenue, and many others. I am thrilled to be a part of Jean Knows Cars.

pageElements.text: I need a car. I’d like to buy a used one, something luxurious with a few miles on it. But I dread that trip to the dealership for any car, new or used. Hunting Craigslist and negotiating with strangers for a car with a suspect history is even worse. And my husband hates any kind of shopping so much that to get him involved would require roofie drugs and duct tape. So I’ve been procrastinating this purchase for over a year.

When I heard about Carvana, a site that would let me buy that car—and arrange to have it delivered—in less than fifteen minutes without getting up from my desk, I had to try it. “Buying a used car is the worst experience that exists,” opines Ernie Garcia, Jr., founder and president of Carvana. “And used-car salesman are the least trusted people. It is also an expensive experience where a lot of the money goes into running dealerships in high-priced locations. The industry is spending $2,000 per transaction to give customers an experience they hate.”

Carvana aims to change that, simply by cutting out salespeople and showrooms and thereby making a profit on the car sale so no one has to sell you extra stuff like warranties. “There is no combination of choices where we lose,” explains Garcia. “So we don't have to talk you into something in order to profit. We are trying to undercut that crappy experience with something easy.”

Cautious (and perhaps sneaky) by nature, I was unwilling to venture my own hard-earned cash without dipping my toes in first. So I used my position as a writer for JeanKnowsCars.com to convince Garcia to let me test-buy a car with their money.

Even though the money wasn’t mine, I had to drag the shopping out. I think it’s actually possible to buy a car in fifteen minutes at Carvana. But spending $25,000 that fast would have me outspending Justin Bieber (who, if Internet gossip and my feeble calculations are to be believed, spends an average of $350 every fifteen minutes). So I dawdled as much as possible. I browsed the online inventory of cars slowly and at random. Then I searched by criteria: price, color, body style, miles, brand. I collected a half-dozen cars in my online garage. Then I explored each in exquisite detail.
Carvana posts detailed photos of the car you will be buying, complete with scratches, wear on the interior, and other imperfections, called out so you won’t miss them.

Carvana posts detailed photos of the very car you will be buying, complete with scratches, wear on the interior, and other imperfections, all called out so you won’t miss them. It also gives you a thorough tour of the features, gas mileage, and other relevant information. That's the sort of thing it’s difficult to keep straight with a clipboard and memory when shopping in the real world. (That is, if you ever get around to comparing more than one car. According to Carvana’s Garcia, more than 70 percent of buyers drive only one used car when shopping.)

I spun the cars around. I zoomed in. I compared prices to the Kelley Blue Book. When I had winnowed my garage down to three cars, I sent a link to my garage to friends so they, too, could look over my options and vote. My husband voted willingly and immediately (saving me a tidy sum on drugs). But the entire decision process still only took about an hour. By the time Carvana had the votes tallied, I knew what car I wanted: a 2011 Infiniti M37 with nearly 30,000 miles on it for $24,500. And I was satisfied I was getting it at a fair price.

Paying for it (with fake money anyway) was pretty easy, too. I entered some financial information, uploaded my proof of residency, an ID, and proof of insurance. Then I fake-paid my deposit and scheduled delivery of my vehicle.

Carvana keeps its cars in Atlanta. The closer you live to Atlanta, the cheaper the delivery. It’s free if you’re within seventy-five miles, $199 if you are seventy-six to 250 miles away. It goes up from there. To have my car delivered to Wilmington, North Carolina, where I live, would cost $480. If I lived in Oakland, California, the cost jumped to $1,250. Or I could fly to Atlanta, pick my car up in an automated “vending machine” where I’d enter a code to unlock the garage and free my car, and road-trip my new wheels home. And, for that, the company would give me $200 toward a plane ticket and pick me up at the airport.

Can you get a Certified Pre-Owned car this way? And what about inspections? Carvana offers its own 100-day, 4,189-mile Carvana Certified program, plus a seven-day "no questions asked" money-back guarantee. That leaves time to get it to your mechanic for a look.

I didn’t actually take delivery of my fake-bought car. But the site claimed it could have it to me within three days. If, within seven days, I decided I didn’t want it, I could return it, no questions asked.

I’m convinced. I am going to buy my next used car this way. I am clearly much too lazy to buy a used car the old way. I’m just grateful that I live in the year 2014 where, if I procrastinate long enough, someone will invent a better way for me to sit around and have the things I need delivered to my door.

pageElements.text: The 2014 Honda CR-V knows what it is, a capable utility vehicle with just enough refinement to make it a beloved family car or versatile everyday commuter. Redesigned in 2012 and starting in the neighborhood of $24,000, the CR-V has been known for delivering safety and respectable gas mileage but without some of the trendier style attributes of its rivals. The CR-V offers 1,500 pounds of towing capacity and 37 cubic feet of cargo space even with the rear seats up, giving it plenty of room for errands around town or family road trips.  The engine has spirit, and the car’s steering and handling are assets, especially for its size. Honda didn’t do much to change the CR-V’s interior or exterior styling when it recently overhauled the vehicle, but that might be because the existing model worked fairly well.  One of the issues Honda should look to address in the future is the level of road noise.  It’s not quite enough to scare off buyers, but after living with the car for a while drivers will tire of the persistent outdoor sounds that bleed into the cabin.  And although the CR-V has intuitive controls, the navigation system could use an update.  Standard on every CR-V you’ll find one-pull fold-flat seats and a rearview camera, Pandora interface, and Bluetooth HandsFreeLink.  Owners of old CR-Vs will appreciate a lighter all-wheel-drive system that not only conserves fuel but also helps with tire slip. Don’t expect to customize your new CR-V too much. There are exterior color choices to be made that determine the interior, but only one engine and transmission services the various trims.  That’s the CR-V for you: not many options, but lots of loyal customers.

pageElements.text: What could be more twenty-first century than carbon fiber? This ultra-lightweight, durable, and—let's face it—awesome-looking material has been used on cars for years, starting with Formula 1 cars in the 1990s. It has expanded to be used for a variety of products: violins and cellos that play well consistently, even in humid conditions, for example, as well as sillier purposes such as mouse pads and phone cases.

Most recently, the electric BMW i3 made its debut in Germany last fall, claiming the bragging rights as the first mass-production car made mainly of carbon fiber. The plug-in hybrid BMW i8, our brother publication Automobile Magazine's Design of the Year, will likewise have a passenger cell made of weight-trimming carbon fiber.
So it is only fitting that owners of the new BMW i8 can accessorize it with this smashing four-piece luggage set made of (you guessed it) carbon fiber from Louis Vuitton.

The set includes a Weekender GM i8 for the trunk, with both shoulder and hand straps; the Garment Bag i8, which is intended to fit snugly on the rear shelf; the Business Case i8, a hardshell piece that is shaped to match the i8's rear seats and "is also ideal for carrying laptops"; and the Weekender PM i8, a smaller bag that's designed to fit onto the rear seat.

Adrian van Hooydonk, design chief at BMW, says the tie-in with Louis Vuitton makes sense because both companies "share both a profound appreciation of tradition and a commitment to constant further development."

If you share that sensibility, bring some cash along. Louis Vuitton has not released pricing yet, but a comparable Weekender bag made of the traditional Vuitton brown patterned fabric runs $1,830, while a comparable leather Garment Bag is priced at $3,900.

Whether or not you're prepared to buy an i8, which will retail at $136,625 when it goes on sale in the spring, you can aspire to own the luggage: it's sold at Louis Vuitton's stores in eight cities worldwide, including New York City and Los Angeles, starting on April 1.

title: Apple CarPlay
subTitle: iOS in the car is here. Hang up & drive, but with seamless ability to work that iPhone while you do.

metaDescription: Apple CarPlay: Apple-quality upgrade lets you use iPhone in the car the same way you use it the rest of the time. Read about its debut on JeanKnowsCars.com.

pageElements.text: If you’re among those who rail against the distracting telematics in modern cars, look out. Apple has just announced CarPlay, which ties the company’s iPhone in to the automobile in ways only dreamed of in the recent past. Apple claims it will cut down on distraction, and let’s hope that’s true. The new setup will be an update to iOS 7 that will work with all the iPhone 5 family.
It will make its official debut this week at the Geneva Auto Show.

Yes, this is the "iOS in the Car" that people have been talking about for more than a year. The Google version for Android phones is reportedly almost here, too, and many tech blogs are breathlessly reporting that it will be called Projected Mode.

But the big news is that it's actually about to roll out on production cars you can buy. CarPlay will be introduced at the Geneva show this week in Ferrari, Volvo, and Mercedes-Benz cars first: Ferrari on the new California T convertible and the FF, Volvo on the all-new XC90 (photo below), and Mercedes on the C-Class (right). Many global auto companies will also have it “down the road,” Apple says, including BMW, Ford, General Motors, Honda, Hyundai, Nissan, Subaru, and Toyota, among others.

In participating vehicles, you simply connect your iPhone to the car’s interface, and you’ll be able to use Siri through the steering wheel’s voice control to ask questions, listen to messages and respond, and of course to make phone calls. It also works with Maps to give Siri-voiced turn-by-turn directions or to look at the route on your car’s screen.
Beyond the merely productive, you can also use CarPlay to gain access to all your iTunes stuff, including iTunes radio, podcasts, and music, and to Spotify and iHeart Radio apps.

In short, this is nothing you can’t already configure in your car, but not as seamlessly as this. Now, you will be making your iPhone part of the car, able to use it easily for everything you’d normally do with the addictive handheld.

pageElements.text: Where do you stand on the appearance of Nissan’s quirky crossover, the Juke? We trod that ground earlier this year, trying out the “mutt ugly” looks of the Juke on Ray the Stray, who begged to differ.

If Ray liked the old Juke, imagine what he’ll say about this updated version, which made its debut last week at the Geneva Motor Show. U.S.-market Juke details aren’t out yet, but we can surmise from this Euro Juke that it will be highly tempting for those of you who want something truly different from the average. It goes on sale in Europe in the summer.

You’ll be able to find this in the parking lot, all right! Nissan has given the little crossover a new Rogue/Qashqai-style V-shaped grille, LED headlamps integrated into the daytime running lamps, and Xenon lower headlamps, plus a redesigned lower fascia. The taillamps are boomerang-shaped LED lights, and the lower rear fascia is new, too.

Once you’re inside, you’ll appreciate the the NissanConnect telematics, the Around View monitor with its four cameras so you can park anywhere with ease, and the (optional) sunroof that opens, sliding up and back over the top of the vehicle so it doesn't cut into headroom inside.

There are personalization packages available with contrasting colors for the mirrors, side sills, door handles, and roof-mounted spoiler.  For the inside, personalization packs let you change colors on the center console and door trim, making it red, white, black, or yellow. A set of optional eighteen-inch wheels are available with five-spoke inserts that match the personalization color you select.

The Juke's Safety Shield package offers up-to-the-minute safety features including lane departure and blind spot warning, as well as moving object detection to make you aware (though visual and sound cues) of the presence of bicyclists, pedestrians, or other possible collision dangers.
On a more prosaic level, there’s more than 40 percent increased space for luggage and gear (up to 12.5 cubic feet on the two-wheel-drive version).

pageElements.text: Not into prosaic things? You could always check out the Juke Nismo or the Juke Nismo RS, which made a late winter debut in the U.S. market. Or stand by to see this refreshed "regular" Juke reach our shores soon.

contributors.bio:
Jean Knows Cars is not just the name of this website; it's a true fact. I have been writing about cars and the car business for more than 30 years, having learned about cars at the kitchen table from my late father, Robert Lienert, who was the editor of Automotive News. At age eighteen, I bought a used car, painted it yellow, installed a toplight and a meter, and joined the Yellow Cab Company in Ann Arbor, Michigan, as an owner/operator. Five years later, I got a job at Chrysler’s test track as a test driver, welder, and mechanic in the impact lab. In 1980, I was hired as a writer at Car and Driver magazine after getting laid off at Chrysler, and in 1985 I left to establish Automobile Magazine with David E. Davis, Jr. I was the magazine’s first Executive Editor, became Editor in Chief in 2000, and added the title of President of Automobile Magazine in 2006.

I’ve been profiled in The New Yorker and have been a guest on the Tonight Show with Jay Leno. I was a guest on the Oprah Winfrey Show, teaching Oprah and her studio audience how to change a tire and to jump a battery. I was Good Morning America’s automotive correspondent from 1994 to 2000 and then did the same thing for the Oxygen network.

 I have won awards for feature writing, car reviews, and my monthly Automobile Magazine column, “Vile Gossip,” including the 2007 Ken Purdy Award for Excellence in Automotive Journalism.  I’m a regular on-air contributor to Fox Business Network; CNBC’s Closing Bell, Squawk Box, Behind the Wheel, and Power Lunch; MSNBC; CBS This Morning and Evening News; and CNN’s American Morning and Headline News. In fact, I would almost call myself a TV slut, but I’m proud to say that I turned Geraldo down.

All of this has taken place in a male-dominated automotive space, where I’m all too frequently the only woman in the room. I know the secret handshake, but JeanKnowsCars.com is going to be a place where you don’t have to. 

I live in the Michigan countryside with my husband, Tim, and the entire food chain. You’re going to get to know my driveway and my dogs really, really well. Just keep reading.

pageElements.text: Greetings from sunny Southern California! I moved to Seal Beach for six weeks, and not a moment too soon. In fact, it was quite a few moments later than I would have appreciated. I effected my escape from the Great White North two days after the thundersnow (three inches in an hour accompanied by thunder to rival a military exercise) and two days before Polar Vortex, Part Three, came down from the North Pole. Goodbye -35 degrees; goodbye, ice storm; goodbye, crumbled roadways.

I am working on a reality show from the talented Bunim-Murray team who bring us Top Chef and the Project Runway franchise, among many other of the genre so near and dear to Americans. This show is called Motor City Masters, and the ten-episode season will run on Turner’s truTV cable channel beginning in June. Motor City Masters is sponsored by Chevrolet, which provides cars as the basis for design challenges. The framework of the show is meant to do what my favorite Bunim-Murray productions do: focus attention on an area of interest that fascinates me; bring in talented, imaginative contestants with skills that I do not possess; add in knowledgeable judges and an interesting host; and then make crazy TV out it all by creating challenges that can be absurd, surreal, impossible, and so compelling that you can’t take your eyes off them.

image.altText: what i drove in la last weekend

pageElements.text: Of course there is weeping, wailing, and gnashing of teeth, or it wouldn’t be that special kind of real we know of as “reality.” I am loving it. To my left on most episodes, the host is actor Brooke Burns, a firecracker who made serious fame as a Baywatch girl and pinup favorite of the lad mags like Maxim. She is so much more than that, you should know. She is wickedly funny, nutty, can talk like a Munchkin without using nitrous oxide, and also happens to possess muscular arms, thighs, and calves that are the circumference of my ankles. A thinking man’s hottie. To my right is car designer Harald Belker, living proof that Germans can be laugh riots. Apparently, they have to be from Dusseldorf. He worked at Porsche and Mercedes before following in Syd Mead’s footsteps to Hollywood, working on cars for the first Transformers movie and cars for Minority Report, Ironman, Batman, and more. Here's a look at my dressing room.

Brooke is close to six feet tall in her cruel shoes, I am six feet tall, and Harald is a solid 6”7,” making me look like a delicate flower. The three of us are thick as thieves, and driven like a northeast wind.
I have a month to go, and I'm trying like hell not to ruin my driving record.  I’m holding out for one killer late-night blast down an empty Long Beach Freeway.

image.altText: what i drove in la last weekend

pageElements.text: At the end of the thus far long, long days of filming, I walk to my parking spot, where a spanking yellow Chevrolet Corvette Stingray is waiting—the perks of being the editor of a national car magazine and a judge on a show sponsored by Chevy. It is still as rare as hen’s teeth out in the real world. I’m not the only one excited about it. I was pumping gas, and a guy came over to ask me about my “Lamborghini.” Tough guys cruising Long Beach the other night slid next to me on the Pacific Coast Highway, where I waited for a light, and gave me the nod. A mom in a Buick Enclave stopped me as I entered my apartment to say her daughters were going crazy for my car.

Me, too. The brilliant nav system and pretty decent (but occasionally flawed) voice-activated Bluetooth phone are about all I’ve used in my freeway commute. Not that there are a lot of cars (there are, in fact, a lot of cars), or that I was driving in the middle of the torrential downpour that began this week’s horrendous nationwide snowstorm. It’s that I have a month to go, and I'm trying like hell not to ruin my driving record. I’m holding out for one killer late-night blast down an empty Long Beach Freeway.
More on the Corvette—and Motor City Masters—as my month unrolls before me.

title: Pro/Con! Should 16 Be the Driving Age?
subTitle: Molly and Laura, both parents of teen drivers, argue the point. Whose side are you on?

metaTitle: Pro/Con! Should 16 Be the Driving Age? - JeanKnowsCars.com
metaDescription: Pro/Con! Should 16 Be the Driving Age? Molly and Laura, both parents of teen drivers, argue the point. Read their commentary on JeanKnowsCars.com.

contributors.bio: When I turned sixteen, my dad brought home the very first-generation Ford Escort wagon, and it just so happened to have a manual transmission. Since—like every other sixteen-year-old—I knew everything, I was sure that I would just get behind the wheel and effortlessly shift gears. Visions of screeching into the school parking lot with my shiny red "world car" and impressing all the burnouts who hung out near their Detroit muscle cars danced in my head. All of those dreams were quickly extinguished in the first fifteen minutes of my driving lesson from my dad. Although he has a teaching certificate, patience is not his strongest skill. The subtle foot-hand coordination escaped me, and we were jerking around the subdivision like the contestants in a game of Red Light Green Light. I blamed my dad, and he blamed me. To my astonishment, he decided it was best to abandon ship and allow me to figure out how to get home. Somehow I managed to limp home without needing therapy for whiplash. After our wounds had healed I did end up learning to drive a manual on that trusty steed. I ended up driving my Escort to Northern Michigan University in Marquette, in Michigan’s frigid Upper Peninsula, where I obtained a BFA, with a concentration in Graphic Design, and a future husband. I joined Automobile Magazine at the tender age of twenty-eight and fell in love with the energy and passion for automobiles and the way they enhance our lives. Later, I took a five-year hiatus and boned up my design and web skills and am now turbocharged to be a part of the Jean Knows Cars team. Many years have passed, and now my sixteen-year-old only child is poised to learn to drive a manual, and I can’t help but be transported back to my teens. Unlike my parents, I am a helicopter mom. Riding in the passenger's seat with her behind the wheel is like waterboarding. I want to order her to pull over and allow me to drive and throw her in the back seat with airbags strapped directly on her. Many of her peers will not learn to drive a manual, but I believe that it is the building block for a good safe driver. It is a perfect synergy watching my daughter learn to drive and helping Jean Knows Cars celebrate and embrace the automobile and how it is woven into our lives.

pageElements.text:
Molly Says: No! Let's Raise the Driving Age

The mere suggestion of raising the age requirement for a driver’s license seems like a ludicrous suggestion. Parents and adolescents alike anticipate the freedom that a driver’s license represents. But is the cost too high? Should we take a step back and look at how the majority of the world does it, and make the age a tad older?

When I think back to my high-school years, mixed in with almost every memory is a car. Cars defined my teen years, and I feel like a traitor even suggesting that the age be raised. But I cannot ignore that, according to the Insurance Institute for Highway Safety, teen drivers' crash rates are three times higher per mile driven than those of drivers aged twenty years and older. As a parent (that's me with my daughter, Elle), that statistic is staggering. Am I alone in wondering if shifting the age higher means saving lives? Perhaps it is worth giving teenagers another reason to think adults are unreasonable?

As teenagers move toward independence, their frontal lobes are still developing. In fact, research suggests that it continues to develop into the twenties and even thirties. Functions such as planning, reasoning, judgment, impulse control, and memory are all controlled by this portion of the brain. Coincidentally, those are  the exact traits that are most important in driving.
I know many of my peers would acknowledge that we made dangerous decisions almost every day of the week when we were young drivers.

Any parent will attest to the volatility of the teenager. When I ride with my daughter, I tend to overreact, but she can be downright irrational at times. Add unsupervised driving to the equation of a developing brain. Now add loud music, a few friends, and a healthy helping of peer pressure, and it stands to reason that the accident rate is higher for this segment.

In car accidents involving teens ages sixteen to nineteen, alcohol is involved 23 percent of the time. And the time when teenagers are the most likely to experiment with drugs and alcohol is exactly the same time they are awarded a driver's license. I know many of my peers would acknowledge that we made dangerous decisions almost every day of the week when we were young drivers. Even when we lost several of our classmates it didn’t stop our risky driving. Obviously, it is against the law for members of this age group to drink, but a significant portion of teens do. Again, remember the developing impulse control, reasoning, and judgment. Once you mix in alcohol, even good kids make bad choices. If the driving age is moved by just a year or two it may allow the maturity to keep the two separate.

My formative years of driving were in the dark ages, and by that I mean before mobile phones and the complicated infotainment options available today. I was plenty distracted by friends and an eight-track player, but it is nearly impossible for teens today to ignore the impulse to constantly check their social networks and adjust their music. According to the National Highway Traffic Safety Administration (NHTSA), “For drivers fifteen to nineteen years old involved in fatal crashes, 21 percent of the distracted drivers were distracted by the use of cell phones.”

There are plenty of campaigns that stress no texting, but they gloss over the dangers with other smartphone functions such as apps that control stereos. My daughter promises that she will not be lured by her phone, but I question whether she will be able to keep that promise. I know that I am not setting a good example of resisting the urge to use the phone while driving. I lamely explain that I have years of experience behind the wheel. Not only does that argument not hold water, but I am sure that it goes in one ear and out the other. I do believe that more time behind the wheel in a supervised setting will provide her a better understanding of the importance of giving driving her full attention.

I am conflicted about raising the age, but if I were starting from scratch in creating a system to develop great drivers I would start with a year of supervised driving time, followed by a comprehensive written test, and a rigorous road test. The young Molly is officially appalled by the adult that I have become, and she would peel out of the driveway and flip me off—below where I could see of course.

Laura Says: Yes! Start Driver Education Young

I am not trying to run against the tide of safety and progress when I say this, but I think driver education should start as young as possible, and I think the current age of fourteen years and nine months (in Michigan) is just about right.
You only have the kids at home, under your influence, until they're out of high school, and they're really only listening to you until about tenth grade.

I might be in the best position of anyone I know to weigh in on teen drivers. I have three teenagers, and I myself didn't learn to drive until age twenty-two. So there are two things I know: First, you only have the kids at home, under your influence, until they're out of high school, and they're really only listening to you until about tenth grade. And second, if you don't learn a skill with your peers, it's hard to pick it up on your own later.  So let me address those, one at a time.

The best argument for driver education starting young is that your child is still listening to you at that age. His or her friends are still listening to their parents at that age. (Here's me with my fourteen-year-old, Sam. He and his friends are sassy, but they're still children, and we can still tell them what to do.) A parent can easily and naturally take the lead in answering questions, setting examples, and participating in the driving education experience. Try that with an eighteen-year-old who is about to leave for college, and see where you get. (I have two of those right now, too. They don't want my advice on anything.)
A parent can naturally take the lead in answering questions, setting examples, and participating in the driving education experience. Try that with an eighteen-year-old.

Also, if your child takes driver education when the "other kids" are doing it, basically in the ninth-to-tenth-grade window, it becomes a shared experience. There is peer encouragement and, yes, peer pressure to get through the curriculum successfully and get that license.

Let me hasten to add that I am in favor of graduated driver's license programs, which have been rolled out all over the United States, including in my home state of Michigan. This allows students to get driving privileges gradually over a period of time, not all at once. That's good, because I agree with Molly that there are dangers involved in just handing over the keys to a sixteen-year-old. The Insurance Institute for Highway Safety feels strongly that the older teenagers are when they start driving, the fewer accidents they will get in. If you want your eyes opened, spend some time on the IIHS's risk calculator for teen drivers. You can dial in your state and see how many fewer accidents there'd be with more supervised driving hours, a longer time between permit and license, and other scenarios.

I don't disagree with the premise that people take fewer and fewer risks as they get older. But I think the problem of inexperienced drivers is less easily fixed than just making everybody wait until they're older.

Or are you talking about making people go through the whole driver education scenario only when they're adults? That's how a lot of European countries do it. Until there's mass transit everywhere in the U.S., it's not practical to set that up here.

So, yes, graduated driver's license laws, which require teens to spend a long time practicing with an adult co-driver and to take a second segment of driver education before the test, are a good way to drag out the process so kids have as much practice time as possible before they're allowed to go solo. But when should they start the process? Young, when parents and teachers can still have an influence.

pageElements.text: On this Pi day (3/14), you can be sure that math teachers around the country are celebrating the day by serving pie (fruit or pizza variety) to their students and playing pie-related games. It's not just an excuse to have treats. These hard-working public servants know their game theory: make math fun, interesting, and an "in" thing, and more kids will want to go further in the subject.

Two auto companies are going to a deeper level to make mathematics interesting to students: Toyota has a professional development program for teachers to help them be better at bringing future technologists along, and Nissan has invited high-school girls to a science and technology event called DigiGirlz.
On this Pi day, it's a perfect time to appreciate the many new opportunities that students are getting, thanks to involved automakers.

We at Jean Knows Cars are all in favor of the more DigiGirlz, the better, because it's a science-and-math-dominated world out there, and women need to have a central place in it. Here are some inspiring details about these two initiatives, to savor while enjoying a slice of, well, you know.

Nissan DigiGirlz

On March 2, Nissan invited 100 high-school girls to its Nashville, Tennessee, headquarters for an event (shown here) that was co-sponsored with Microsoft and the area's Middle Tennessee State University. The event was intended to entice the students toward careers in the STEM fields (science, technology, engineering, and math). The students got to rub elbows with members of Nissan's Women's Business Synergy Team and other members of the automaker's staff.

This is part of a larger diversity initiative by Microsoft, which runs two-day technology workshops around the country and in India, Bulgaria, and Egypt for female students interested in STEM studies. Microsoft's aim is "to dispel stereotypes of the high-tech industry," but there's no doubt that a program like this could be the extra push girls need to continue their technological educations.

Toyota's STEAM Initiative

This one is close to my heart, because Toyota is involved in a new kindergarten through eighth grade STEAM (science, technology, engineering, arts, and mathematics) magnet school, to open next year right here in Ann Arbor, Michigan. Also, as we speak, two of my children's teachers from middle school are in a group visiting Singapore on a study tour sponsored by Toyota Motor Sales. This is the fifteenth year that Toyota's STEAM program, previously called the Toyota International Teacher Program, has sent teachers to other countries to expand their knowledge about science and technology education.

Toyota has also sent teachers to Japan, the Galapagos Islands, Costa Rica, and South Africa to expand their horizons about teaching on math, science, and environmental topics. The automaker says it's motivated by "the critical need to invest in the professional development of STEAM educators in order to develop a pipeline of students that will meet the workplace demands of tomorrow." (I already thought my kids' technology teacher Mr. Pachera and math teacher Mrs. Newing were awesome, but this focused study trip can only help.)

Toyota's Technical Center is located here in Ann Arbor, with 800 engineers and technicians among the 1,250 employees—and a projected 30 percent increase in the need for qualified employees in the coming few years. If you want to see future technology superstars in their incubation phase, check out the balloon cars built by fifth-grade girls in this video from Ann Arbor's Lakewood Elementary, learning about Newton's second law with a little help from visiting Toyota engineers.

On this Pi day, it's a perfect time to appreciate the many new opportunities that students are getting, thanks to involved automakers, to become full participants in the technological future.

pageElements.text: Fans of the film 2001: A Space Odyssey will be no doubt simultaneously excited and worried about some recent developments in automobile intelligence. In that 1968 vision of the future, HAL 9000, a sentient computer, controlled the ship’s navigation and mechanics. HAL was also a keen observer of his human colleagues. But when HAL got paranoid and turned into a control freak, things didn’t end well for the astronauts.

Today, quite a bit later than predicted by that film, car manufacturers are finally on a quest for a car with a computer intelligence that’s smart enough to handle driving duties. Some of the technologies developed to that end, such as lane assist and predictive cruise control, are already emerging in cars. But automakers and researchers are still busy developing sensors and technologies that let cars “see” the world around them, anticipate traffic, control the car’s speed and direction, and communicate with other cars on the road.

image.altText: Sensor To See Where Driver Is Looking.Volvo

pageElements.text: At some point, even the best self-driving car has to hand control back to the driver. To do that, it needs to know its driver (just as HAL knew his astronauts) well enough to be able to answer the questions, “Is this human driver awake? Alert? Coherent enough to control of this vehicle?”

Knowing that much about humans will require sensors inside the car to observe the driver that are able to accurately interpret his or her behavior, so it can decide between handing over the controls or pulling off the road and calling for help.
Beyond vague predictions that a fully autonomous car will be “safe” by 2017, it is difficult to pin down the date when you might encounter a car that “gets" you.

Because of the difficulty of interpreting human behavior, this part of the self-driving-car package is a bit of a sticking point in the R&D world of autonomous driving. Manufacturers are working out technologies that watch the driver, determine what he’s paying attention to, and get his attention back on the driving. Delphi showed a technology at the 2014 Consumer Electronics Show in Las Vegas that can see where the driver is looking. And when it sees a driver look away from the road for too long, it flashes a light on the dash or rumbles the steering wheel to get his or her attention back on driving. Volvo has developed a similar technology.

But researchers in Switzerland, at the École Polytechnique Fédérale de Lausanne's Signal Processing 5 Laboratory (LTS5), are collaborating with PSA Peugeot Citroën to take this people-watching technology one step further. They have developed an emotion detector that analyzes not only where the driver is looking but also interprets facial expressions to see how the driver is feeling. Groggy? Angry? Irritated? These emotions can affect how a person drives and could lead the car to decide things might go better if it takes—or keeps—control away from a tired or even road-raging human.

Knowing how the driver is feeling, though, is just one aspect of teaching a machine to understand its driver. The Swiss research project is also working on a fatigue detector that measures how frequently a driver's eyes close and on a machine that can read lips for use in voice recognition. Volvo is testing a sensor installed in the dashboard with small infrared-light LEDs to determine where the driver is looking and how far open his or her eyes are, and to monitor the position and angle of his or her head. It's all in the service of adjusting safety technology to work best for that driver at that time.
But, beyond vague predictions that a fully autonomous car will be “safe” by 2017, it is difficult to pin down the date when you might encounter a car that “gets" you.

But the potential for improved safety from cars that know what their driver is feeling is promising, which is why Volvo says of its research, “This technology is one of the many initiatives bringing Volvo Cars closer to its goal for 2020: that no one shall be killed or seriously injured in a new Volvo.”

But anyone who watched 2001: A Space Odyssey might look at these developments slightly differently. In that movie (spoiler alert), HAL took control of the Discovery One spaceship and murdered most of the crew, after reading the lips of the astronauts who were planning to disconnect him. You'd be excused if you feel a chill of concern about getting into a machine smart enough to read your lips and take over the driving if it decides you aren’t handling your emotions well enough.
]

pageElements.text: I'm very sad to learn that the esteemed Gruppo Bertone styling house, which created some incredibly important cars in its 102-year history, is in bankruptcy court and could soon be closing its doors. This would be a tragic loss, and so unfortunate that Bertone has not been able to secure a corporate angel like Volkswagen, which bought Italdesign.

There was some hope recently when Lilli Bertone, widow of the founder's son, Nuccio, was able to revive the company and put American designer Mike Robinson in charge. His car, the Pandion, a wild exercise with crazy 90-degree doors that were 11.8 feet high when opened, was proudly displayed along the ocean side of the lawn as part of Alfa Romeo's 100th-year celebration at the Pebble Beach Concours d'Elegance in 2010. It was always surrounded by a mass of people. Unfortunately, it wasn't enough to put Bertone back in the game.
<iframe width="560" height="315" src="//www.youtube.com/embed/GdKJEGieopY" frameborder="0" allowfullscreen></iframe>

The end of Bertone would leave Pininfarina, founded in 1930, as the last of the great Turin coachbuilders still in existence. Its own troubles accelerated when it lost CEO Andrea Pininfarina, a bright star, so personable and smart and worldly, in a Vespa accident in 2008. His father, Sergio, continued to run the company, but his own death in 2012 leaves that firm's future in serious doubt.

Read my reminiscence of meeting Nuccio Bertone in 1981 in this recent story on JeanKnowsCars.com.

Related story: The Last Italian Design House, by Robert Cumberford in Automobile Magazine, February 2011
