contributors.bio:
Sheer serendipity.  That’s how I became a contributor to Jean Knows Cars.  Well into a lovely dinner party, I received a most unlikely suggestion:  “You should write about cars from your perspective – a 4’11” single mother with a ten-year-old minivan who drives around three overactive children and a Bernese Mountain Dog.  Theatre, swimming, hockey, lacrosse, figure skating, field hockey… You love to tell stories. Tell them about cars.”  I suggested that my background possibly lacked necessary expertise – B.A. from Duke in art history and medieval/Renaissance studies; Fellow of the American Academy in Rome; Ph.D. from the University of Michigan in medieval architecture --  nothing about cars there!  My friend persisted, “You may be an art historian, but you are also a hockey mother who can whistle like a trucker, a runner, and a lover of good food, wine and the written word.”

I pondered.  The auto industry and I did have a long, if tangential, history.  I did a stint as an executive secretary to the president of a car dealership and spent fifteen years negotiating a dual identity as an academic and as auto company spouse.  I have always suffered from car envy, particularly acutely when I lived in Europe.  (As envy and lust are amongst the seven deadly sins, I’m in trouble.) Automobiles, functional objects that often shape image, are fundamental elements of today’s society.  This would be another mode of cultural analysis and critique.  Couched in that light, it made perfect sense!

(And, I really can whistle like a trucker, but louder. I may be an art historian, but don’t sit next to me at a hockey rink.)

pageElements.text: Red-and-white polka dot bandana? Check. Red socks? Check. Black boots? Check.  Blue denim coveralls?  Not an item in my closet…yet.

This is not my usual attire. I'm an art historian, a group known for our fondness for black. It is, however, the outfit needed for the next attempt to set the Guinness World Record for “The Most Rosie the Riveters in One Place.”  If you were ever to put a “save the date” on your calendar, March 29, 2014, 2:00 p.m. at Hangar 1, Willow Run Airport, in Ypsilanti, Michigan, might be it. On that day, more than 250 women of all ages are expected to assemble in Rosie uniforms to set that world record.

The event serves a dual purpose: to honor the “Rosies,” the women who played such a significant role in the manufacturing movement for the World War II war effort, and to raise funds for the Save the Bomber Plant campaign. The campaign seeks to save part of the original Willow Run Bomber Plant and convert the space to house the Yankee Air Museum.
The timing is crucial, as the campaign has only until May 1 to raise the funds to prevent the total demolition of the plant that produced 8,600 B-24s during World War II.

Jane Vass, the "head Tribute Rosie," had coordinated an effort to break the “Rosie record” on a cold and damp October day last fall, and the “Rosie” turnout was close enough to the record to prompt support for this new attempt in the spring.  The timing is crucial, as the campaign has only until May 1 to raise the necessary funds to prevent the total demolition of the plant that produced 8,600 B-24 Liberator bombers during the war.

This being a Guinness World Record attempt, the rules are quite strict: no high heels, no colored shoes, no T-shirts, no denim shirts (only solid dark blue fabric), and the shirt must be long-sleeved and rolled up. The red bandana must have large-size white polka dots. There will be chairs provided for "elderly" Rosies, while under-eighteen Rosies must have a parent or guardian with them. Arrival is requested by 2:00 p.m. for check-in. Get all the details here and RSVP to the organizers here.

We just hit an all-time record for snowfall and cold this winter. Who knows what the weather will bring on March 29? The real Rosies on that factory floor, however, were tenacious women, and the weather would not have stopped them.  Snow, rain, or shine, all women are invited to join the effort as Tribute Rosies to help break a different kind of record.

contributors.bio: I'm the auto and motorcycle critic for the Orange County Register. Originally from Ann Arbor, Michigan, I currently live in Los Angeles with my ten-year-old son.

pageElements.text:
Women in the Winner’s Circle: The Traveling Exhibit
NASCAR Hall of Fame, 400 E. Martin Luther King Blvd., Charlotte, N.C.
Through June 8
Details: www.nascarhall.com

Move over, Danica Patrick. There are plenty of other fast women who’ve been racing their way into history books over the past century. Now they are getting their due through Women in the Winner’s Circle—a traveling exhibit that has just kicked off at the NASCAR Hall of Fame in Charlotte, North Carolina, and will run through June.

For example: Long before Patrick became a household name, there was Camille du Gast, a French tobogganer, balloonist, and expert riflewoman, who turned her attention to auto racing in 1901, only to be banned after two races when her native country prevented women from participating in the fledgling sport, citing “feminine nervousness.”

Then there was Dorothy Levitt, the “Fastest Girl on Earth,” who, almost 100 years ago, broke the ladies' land speed record when she got her De Dion-Bouton up to 90.88 mph. In addition to teaching the queen of England how to drive, the fur-wearing Brit is credited with inspiring the rearview mirror.
In addition to teaching the queen of England how to drive, fur-wearing Brit Dorothy Levitt is credited with inspiring the rearview mirror.

The list of female racers, and their colorful stories, spans decades, starting with early twentieth-century "pioneers" and continuing to “trailblazers” of the 1940s to 1970s, such as Louise Smith, Pat Moss-Carlsson, and Janet Guthrie.

Smith started driving at the age of four and was as well known for surviving horrific crashes as she was for becoming one of the first women to compete in the NASCAR precursor Grand National series in the 1950s.

Moss-Carlsson started driving at the age of seven, when her future racing legend (and brother) Stirling Moss taught her how to drive the family’s Jeep. Despite being a petite 5'4", Moss-Carlsson went on to win Europe’s grueling Liège-Rome-Liège Rally in 1960 driving an Austin-Healey; its brake and accelerator pedals were strapped with blocks of wood so she could reach them.

The daughter of a pilot, Guthrie began flying at age fifteen, sky diving at sixteen, and racing at twenty-two. The first woman to pass the Indianapolis 500 rookie test in 1976, the first woman to compete in a NASCAR Winston Cup in 1977, the first woman to earn a starting spot in the Daytona 500, and the first woman to start at the Indy 500, she was also among the Mercury 13—the thirteen women who tried out to become U.S. astronauts in the 1960s.

The Women in the Winner’s Circle exhibit is a joint production of the Henry Ford Museum in Dearborn, Michigan, and the Women in the Winner’s Circle Foundation founded by racing driver Lyn St. James. She was the first woman to win Rookie of the Year at the Indy 500 in 1992 and is featured as one of the “modern racers” of the 1980s and 1990s in a show that also highlights present and future female racers, such as drag-racing star Erica Enders-Stevens.



Helping to bring the women’s stories to life are racing cars, helmets, racing suits, and trophies, as well as awards and photos of the many women who’ve put pedal to metal to help make motorsports more gender neutral.

pageElements.text: The world has no shortage of people behaving badly, and many of those people transition easily into being bad drivers as well. And then, anybody who has ever read (or seen the film of) Stephen King’s “Christine” or taken a look at a car like the raggedy Plymouth Caravelle that my brother used to drive in the late 1990s (the one with a giant cartoon beaver mural on its hood) will know that there’s even such a thing as bad cars.
How do I know this? I’m a 911 operator in a major metropolitan area. It’s my duty to receive emergency calls, many of them after some form of automotive mayhem.
I’ve tracked and studied my activities for one full shift to bring you some tips that could help avoid disaster or trouble, and to aid in your travels behind the wheel and through life.

1. Watch out for pedestrians in areas where one would least expect them to be, like busy, dimly lit thoroughfares.

To start, it’s commonly believed that roadways are for car, truck, and bicycle traffic. Some disagree, and hopefully, you won’t run into those folks (literally). Case in point is my twelfth caller, who sees a pedestrian dressed in dark clothing walking in the roadway on a busy street with fast-moving traffic. A squad was sent to check on him. They determined this pedestrian’s demonstrated aversion to using the city’s sidewalk infrastructure meant he might not survive if left to his own devices and transported him home. Likewise, call fifty-three was about a male staggering in traffic. The guy was intoxicated, as it turned out, and decided that he was going to hail a cab by floundering around in the middle of an intersection. Regardless of how much a person has to drink, nobody wants to see anyone come to harm via the business end of an automobile, so the police helped him get a taxi.

2. Be alert in gas station parking lots, which serve as venues for all kinds of odd behavior, including romantic.

Maybe it’s not shocking that roadways are not a safe place to hang out. Would it be surprising to learn that the common gas station can also serve as a setting for unexpected mayhem and mystery? Such was the case for my fourth caller, who found himself on the losing end of a minor brawl near the gas pumps. He didn’t know the woman who smacked him in the face, and I got the sense that he felt embarrassed. Still, assault is assault even if it’s a woman throwing the punches. This incident seemed to stem from a territorial dispute over who had first dibs on that particular gas pump.

Caller sixty-one was at a different filling station, and was watching a guy in the parking lot attack a car occupied by two women.  The suspect was trying to punch out the windows with his fists.  It’s not clear if he was angry at the car or its occupants, and the story never did come to light, because both the vehicle and the guy took off before the police arrived.

Call 101 came from a gas station employee who was growing increasingly concerned about three vehicles in the parking lot of the business. One car was sitting at the pumps for almost an hour. Two other cars were occupied and parked in front of the store for nearly as long. Police checked it out. The first one was sitting at the pumps for so long because its owner accidentally locked the keys inside and walked home to retrieve a spare set. The other two vehicles belonged to a male and female who were meeting in person for the first time after becoming acquainted online. They chose to meet at the gas station because it was a public place where both felt safe. The suspicious vehicles turned out to be perfectly benign, but their occupants could just as easily have been up to something, so the clerk’s vigilance and willingness to call 911 are still good in my book.

3. Keep your hands off people inside the car or anywhere else, either.

Of course, there are worse places to be than a gas station parking lot, and not just for first dates. Near the top of that list would be in the back seat of a squad car on its way to jail. Call sixty-four was about an incident that generated a flurry of calls from neighbors with a one-block radius. Information was vague, but reports indicated that people were fighting and screaming outside an apartment building. Several people saw a Jeep on the scene, in which the driver was attempting to strangle the passenger. The next caller wanted police to know that the Jeep was speeding away even as squad cars were closing in. Cops didn’t locate the Jeep, but if they had, that driver would probably have spent the night in jail, while his Jeep would likely have been towed to impound.

4. Hypervigilance and caution may be called for when performing even seemingly routine tasks, like walking down the street, walking to your car, or loading groceries into the car.

Things can get much worse when weapons are brought into the mix. I've taken calls in which cars are involved as a bone of contention, as a backdrop for a murder, and as a means of escape.

First up is caller thirteen, who reports that a man has just brandished a handgun at a woman in her eighties outside a grocery store and carjacked the woman’s aging Honda sedan. Ironically, the vehicle this suspect has chosen to take at gunpoint sports a “War Is Not the Answer” bumper sticker. The Honda most certainly went right to a chop shop, and its frame and some of its less valuable pieces, like the plastic bits, will likely turn up abandoned behind a vacant property eventually. For whatever reason, I really hope that bumper sticker survives this ordeal somehow.

When I return from my lunch break, I learn that there has been a fatal shooting just a few blocks from where I live. This type of thing makes me especially wary of my surroundings when I pull in my driveway after work, and I scanned the call screen for any descriptions of suspects or vehicles to keep an eye out for on the drive home. Information indicated that the victim was walking to his car from a party when he was approached by a male who may have been trying to rob him.  He died in the street outside his vehicle. When paths cross between two people, one of whom is willing to put their immediate wants and fulfillment of their whims over another person’s very life, the result is a senseless thing like this. These kinds of calls make me cringe, and when they’re in my own neighborhood, they’re even scarier and more depressing than usual, because there’s always that worry that the victim could be a neighbor or friend.

Call 109 is the last call I answer on this shift, and it’s a shooting.  The phones light up as a wave of incoming calls about this same thing hits all at once.   My caller witnessed two men shoot a third guy, who fell down to the ground.  The shooters walked away, but then turned around, walked back, and shot the third man two more times before running away.  As police were headed to the scene, a fourth man came along and dragged the shooting victim into a van, which took off.  I don’t know if the victim in this shooting ever turned up at the hospital, but it is certain that the van he was loaded into was not an ambulance.   Regardless, I hope he survived.

5. Leaving the car running unattended may seem like a good way to warm it up, but some people interpret this to mean “Hey, free car!”

The victims in these calls likely couldn’t have done much to prevent what happened to them without having some kind of sixth sense. In certain cases, though, people unwittingly fling open wide the windows of opportunity for folks with bad intentions to climb right through. This is the case in call thirty-eight, an auto theft report. The owner of the vehicle had what must have seemed like a good idea at the time: he started his car and left it idling and unattended to warm it up. Turns out that car thieves are more than happy to take a joyride in a toasty warm car. Which leads me to rule number six:

6. Learn how to properly use (or not use) the fancy emergency technology that’s built into your car so that the vehicle doesn’t end up crying wolf to the monitoring company and the police.

That story above was a case of user error, you might think, but what if your car is loaded with enough technology to take care of itself and a small colony of astronauts? Take call forty-six, for example, from a company that handles mobile dispatching for Infiniti brand automobiles. They called to have officers check on one of their vehicles in which the panic/SOS button push signal was activated. The monitoring company was unable to get a response from inside the car, nor could they get an answer on the phone that was linked to the account. Police located the vehicle unoccupied, locked, and completely intact. Perhaps the driver or an occupant mashed the panic button without even realizing it? Or perhaps this car was lonely. You be the judge.

7. An argument over car keys can sometimes escalate until police intervention is called for. It may be best to avoid loaning out the car altogether.

If you can’t trust strangers or technology with your car, surely you can trust your friends, right? Well, if call ninety-eight is any indication; you can’t. In this instance, two women were having a very spirited argument over one loaning her car keys to the other, who refused to return them. There was talk of escalation and profanity galore from both parties as this battle of words raged on over the phone lines. However, when the one with the keys realized that the police really were going to come out to chat with her, the two managed to bury the hatchet.

8. If enough people spot you driving a car like you stole it, eventually, somebody is going to share that information with the police.

Some people’s driving techniques are better suited for competing in a demolition derby than for commuting. Caller number ten wants to tell me about a reckless driver in an old Cadillac sedan that was swerving over lane lines and nearly striking pedestrians. Caller sixty-seven reported a black Chevy pickup truck that was speeding and blowing through stop signs and red lights. This kind of driving is really dangerous and puts a lot of people at risk. In both calls, I gathered vehicle information and direction of travel, ran the license plates, then sent a message to the squads on duty so they could track down the vehicles and their drivers.

9. Drive defensively, but if you do get in a wreck, try to get a plate number, just in case the other guy takes off.

Sometimes, careless drivers leave a trail of wreckage in their wakes. In call twenty, it’s in the form of a multiple-vehicle accident. This mess was initiated by a black sedan that struck my caller’s Saturn, knocking it out of its orbital trajectory and shoving it, coincidentally, into another Saturn, which then hit a Pontiac parked along the side of the road. The black sedan fled the scene, making this a hit and run. Call twenty-nine involved two SUVs. One of them turned into the path of the other, causing the initial collision. The one that caused the accident then fled the scene, striking a third vehicle while fleeing. I can relate to how my callers felt, because my own car was struck by a hit-and-run driver a few years ago on my way home from work.

Hit-and-run calls are extremely common; enough that one’s faith in humanity would be destroyed if it hinged solely on whether or not people stayed on the scene of an accident.  Who knows if that other driver has an invalid license, lacks insurance, has active warrants, may be intoxicated, or all of the above?  Well, you don’t.  But I bet the officer answering the call does.

10. If you’re feeling lost, try going to your left. It works for some people. Just don’t forget to stop when you get to where you are going.

It’s always good to have a sense of direction while navigating through whatever city you’re in, even if you’re on foot. Take it from the new operator sitting across the aisle from me. I overheard him talking to one of our frequent callers: a woman who tends to drink in excess, then wander about until she’s lost downtown or gets kicked out of a business for stumbling around and pestering patrons. My co-workers and I start to worry about her if several days pass without a call from her. This call was our new guy’s first time dealing with her, and he didn’t know where to send help because she didn‘t know where she was. In the years that I’ve been taking calls from her, the only instruction I’ve ever been able to get her to follow is to walk to her left until she finds a street sign that she can read. I advised the new guy to try this technique, and he did get a cross street out of her so she could find a corner to wait for police.

Even if each of the calls we receive at 911 involved something awful (which would not be the case, thanks to accidental dials, non-emergency calls, and people who let their babies and toddlers play with the phone), the odds are still in your favor to avoid disaster.  Look at the numbers.  The population of the city I work for is right around 400,000 people.  During my shift, we averaged six call takers on the phones.  Assuming each of them answered the same number of calls I did (109), that’s a 611:1 ratio of people to calls.  By my calculations, there’s only a 0.1635 percent likelihood of disaster or doom per person in a given eight-hour time span, and only a quarter of those (0.041 percent) are automotive related.
I hope these examples help you gather the tools needed to avoid a phone chat with someone like me.

contributors.bio: I was born a suburban Detroit gal where the preoccupation with cars is practically genetic.  As a young adult I kicked around motor-racing, training to drive while I worked at a Brands Hatch satellite in Miami.  I've been race staff at the Detroit Grand Prix, worked TV coverage of Formula 1, Indy and NASCAR and done the occasional ride and drive program.  Eventually my racing aspirations gave way to a long held interest in filmmaking and I got my B.A. from the University of Michigan's burgeoning film program.  U of M taught me to write and introduced me to my excellent husband.  We spent five adventurous years in Los Angeles in the entertainment and publishing industries before returning to Ann Arbor where our lovely daughter came into the world.  Personally, I expend a good deal of energy on K-12 public education advocacy.  Professionally, I've been a freelance writer for the last ten years specializing in health issues and automotive content from a lifestyle perspective.  There's a lot more to auto life than zero to sixty.

pageElements.text: We've been thinking for a while about ways to keep our dogs safe while riding in cars.  Restraining your dog in the car not only keeps him safe in the event of a collision but also prevents him from being the furry distraction that may cause a crash.
<iframe width="560" height="315" src="//www.youtube.com/embed/Y6p9-A2zRNo?list=UUKWoLlV8-sE8zQnoWHI9qoA" frameborder="0" allowfullscreen></iframe>

It was exciting last fall when the Center for Pet Safety, sponsored by Subaru, did formal safety testing of several dog harnesses on the market. The only one to emerge with the Top Performer label was the Clickit Three-Point Dog Harness, by Sleepypod. And that's the harness we're testing in this video. (See the complete Center for Pet Safety test results here.)

The harness costs $89.99, comes in three colors (orange, red, and black), and is available from Sleepypod's website. It comes with three adjustable components: the Y-shaped vest that your dog wears and two tethers that secure the dog to your car’s LATCH child safety restraint anchors.

An important reminder: Measuring your dog per Sleepypod's online size guide is essential. We tried to fit the harness on Molly's ten-pound Bizee and found that even size XS hung way down off her scrawny frame, before discovering the harnesses are designed for dogs who weigh eighteen pounds and up.

For really small dogs (like Bizee), Sleepypod's Air carrier ($159.99, in a range of colors), like the one shown in the video, will strap into the car; it also fits under an airline seat. Sleepypod also makes the pet bed for which the company is named, which zips open on top, straps into the car, and looks adorable. It would also work well for a cat. These come in even more designer colors, including Dark Chocolate and Blossom Pink, and cost $179.99.

contributors.bio:
When Automobile launched in 1986, my byline appeared on a sidebar to the cover story written by our founding editor David E. Davis, Jr. Yet it wasn’t inevitable that I’d write for the magazine, even though my childhood was heavily automobile-flavored: my father raced jalopies and late-model stock cars on the oval tracks around Omaha, Nebraska, where we lived, and my favorite uncle liked drag racing and hot rods.

After earning a B.A. in English from the University of Nebraska, I moved to Los Angeles to become a screenwriter. Instead, though, I ended up holding cue cards on TV shows, including the soap opera Days of Our Lives. My first magazine story, the inside scoop on how we prepared those cue cards, appeared with my own photos in Soap Opera Digest.

In my freelance career, I’ve written for Bon Appétit, the Wall Street Journal, and many others. I started corresponding for the Automobiles desk at the New York Times in 2010, which is proving to be a great relationship. As a change of pace, my historical column for DBusiness (“Detroit’s Premier Business Journal”) has run since 2006. But while a food-and-wine tour can get boring after a couple of days, nothing beats a call from Automobile. I’ve been behind the wheel of everything from a Ferrari 458 Italia (“Blood Red to Goodwood,” March 2011) to the Fiat 500 Abarth. On assignment for “Three Zero Heroes,” I co-drove the winning BMW X3 in the 2004 Alcan Winter Rally. Teaming again with the same navigator, we won the 2006 Carolina Trophy, bulldogging a 1951 Chrysler Saratoga to the finish for “Substance over Style.”

Other assignments have placed me not only in the driver’s seat of a Porsche 911 Targa for the 2002 Targa Newfoundland, a plummy nod that seemed to indicate my editors’ favor, but also in the co-driver’s seat of a Class 1 buggy for the 2003 Baja 1000, suggesting they wanted me dead.

As you might guess, there’s no regret about failing as a screenwriter. And now I’m beginning something new: teaching automotive journalism at Art Center College of Design, in Pasadena. My workshop, Creating Content for Automotive Media, launched in 2012 and will be offered twice a year. I look forward to helping students along on their way to incomparable automotive adventures and working with the best editors in the business.

pageElements.text: This website and Automobile Magazine generally take up enough of Jean's day, but this past month, she has added a new item to her portfolio: reality-show star. Jean has been filming a new series that will improve the viewing public’s appreciation for good design and could ultimately even cleanse the highways of ugly cars.

Well, in truth, that may be too much to ask. But when Motor City Masters premieres this summer on truTV, viewers will be engrossed in the nuances of automotive design as contestants, all with established backgrounds in the subject, meet a series of weekly challenges in the pursuit of a $100,000 prize and a new Chevrolet Camaro Z28.
As the result of watching the reality show, viewers will gain a refined understanding of good design.
In typical reality-show style, contestants are eliminated after each episode, so the surviving pair face off when meeting a challenge in the final episode.

To judge their efforts, producers chose Jean along with Harald Belker, who trained at Art Center College of Design and has drawn every sort of car, from Hot Wheels toys to sci-fi movie vehicles. A changing cast of celebrity guests provide additional judging assistance.
I recently visited the production, which was under way at a studio in an obscure part of Long Beach, California.
I found Jean on the set, regally ensconced in a director’s chair, her brown eyes gleaming and her head delicately topped with a peach-accented hat to complement her blouse.
With about half of the season's ten episodes already in the can, secrecy had nevertheless been maintained, so everything about the show was news to me, and I had to ask what made her want to do it.

Besides the opportunity to escape Michigan’s winter, she said Motor City Masters was giving her the opportunity to apply herself afresh to familiar subject matter. “The coolest thing is to do something different with what you know,” she said.
I needed no reminder of her extensive reporting on design, which has led to friendships with some of the most talented people ever to create cars.

But I wondered if her taking this opportunity involved some risks. Mindful that Bunim/Murray Productions was behind Motor City Masters, she read the treatment “very, very carefully” and liked it. “I’m a big fan of Project Runway because of the format,” she said, naming one of the company’s hits. “And this show’s the same format. They have contestants who have actual talent, they have judges from the business, and then it goes crazy from there.”

As one who has occasionally let his adverbs stray off and later walked into her office to find them, I know that Jean will not hesitate to speak her mind about hits and misses. Getting into the flow of the show wasn’t likely to be her problem.

What has gratified her, though, was affirming that she had plenty of substance, even when teamed up with Harald. It “pops out in the funniest way,” she said. “Between us, we are almost constantly in sync. I had no idea I knew what I knew.”
Even the most popular designer in the world is subject to criticism, to the consumer’s point of view. That's why the judging aspect of this show is important.

Executive producer Rick de Oliveira, whose background in reality TV goes back to the second season of The Real World, said Jean was chosen after being recommended by people in the auto industry who knew she understood the consumer. And in this regard, she has made a big impression on the contestants.

“They have come to really understand that she has a very strong voice,” de Oliveira said. “And that voice: I don’t care if you’re the most popular designer in the world, you’re going to be subject to the criticism, to the consumer’s point of view. I think that’s a really important judging aspect to all this. Jean brings that practicality. We’re trying to relate this back to an audience that needs to be educated.”

Motor City Masters host Brooke Burns, whose breakthrough came on Baywatch, said she, Jean, and Harald have struck up a “three amigos” relationship. What’s impressive about Jean, Brooke said, is her realness. “She is such a natural on camera. She has such a great sense of humor and a spin on the way she writes. That definitely comes across. It’s wonderful to see someone from day one be so natural, expressive, and obviously smart. She knows her stuff. She’s not faking.”
Being a part of the show has opened her eyes to what makes a car unique, Brooke said. And she hopes the enthusiasm spreads.

“I know that it’s inspired me.” Repeating the old show business saying, “The camera tells all,” she said: ”We’re having fun. We’re being inspired. I certainly hope that translates to the American public, that they will also enjoy watching the show and be inspired to look at car design in a new way.”

contributors.bio:
Robert Cumberford is a designer who became a writer by accident. His race report on the 12 Hours of Sebring was published when he was an eighteen-year-old Art Center student in 1954. Subsequently he has published thousands of articles on cars and airplanes, in American, Asian, English, European, and South American magazines. He contributed to several books, including the entire text of the well-reviewed Auto Legends, now available in five translated editions -- French, German, Spanish, Italian, and Polish in addition to the original English version. In 1985, Automobile Magazine founder David E. Davis, Jr., invited him to be one of two executive editors when Automobile was in the planning stages. Cumberford demurred, saying he knew nothing about magazine production and claims he still doesn’t, except that it’s important to meet deadlines. He contributed features from the beginning and began his popular “By Design” column in the sixth issue, September 1986.

In car design, Cumberford was even more a youthful prodigy. He sketched the body for the first car ever built to his designs when he was a fifteen-year-old Los Angeles high-school student. That car, the Parkinson Jaguar Special, is still active in historic racing sixty years after it was created. Hired directly by General Motors’ legendary Vice President of Design, Harley J. Earl, Cumberford became a professional car designer at nineteen. Leaving Detroit, he returned to California to attend UCLA to study philosophy. He rejoined the automotive world in the early 1960s and has continued to create new automotive shapes since then, always as an independent design consultant. He has lived and worked in six of the fifty United States and in France, Mexico, and Switzerland. The range of his design projects includes both racing and touring cars, trucks, aircraft, boats, hovercraft, and even ecological architecture.

He is known worldwide for strong opinions but is well-respected in the design world because it is known that he is always completely honest in his views, with no agenda other than respect for good design and good designers. “There’s no ad hominem,” he says, “I judge the design, not the designers. There are designers I really like personally who’ve been credited with designs I heartily dislike -- for reasons I always state very clearly -- and designs I love done by people with whom I have absolutely no affinity. Except that we both like their work.”

pageElements.text:
Backstory: Automobile Magazine's design editor, Robert Cumberford, wrote a must-read essay on the end of the Italian coachbuilding era. Read it here. One of the coachbuilding firms discussed in the article, Pininfarina, responded through its communications department; that response is below. Here is Cumberford's commentary on the response.

So the Pininfarina Communications Department is unhappy with me. That was to be expected. Anything less than panegyric enthusiasm always distresses them. Too bad.

I have frequently praised designs carrying Pinin Farina and Pininfarina labels, specifically mentioning the purity, beauty, and classicism of cars made during the past eighty-three years that featured those badges, but that does not change my view of the problems visited upon Pinin’s proud house—or Nuccio Bertone’s—by the founding family’s third generation miring those companies in debt.

It is easy to blame “outside forces,” but the bankruptcies of General Motors and Chrysler cited here by Pininfarina came from the same causes: incompetent management, arrogance, and unwillingness to see the world as it is, not as desired to be by those who made the bad decisions.

I hope Pininfarina SpA will indeed continue to exist and prosper, but as it does so it will be under the direction and control of others, not Battista’s descendants, whatever their titles and roles in the enterprise.
—Robert Cumberford
The Letter from Pininfarina:

Dear Mrs. Jennings, We read with great dismay the article “The Death of Italian Coachbuilding” by Robert Cumberford, respected journalist who has been following Pininfarina since decades. This is the reason why, this time, we are very astonished by the many inaccuracies and false statements in his story. Firstly, we are disappointed by such little respect towards the Pininfarina family. Unfounded personalized criticisms, such as the ones addressed to Mr. Andrea Pininfarina, and statements about Mrs. Lorenza, do not deserve any comments. The role of the third generation has been - and still is - central for the Company.

Under Paolo Pininfarina’s chairmanship, the Company is perpetuating the image of a brand that is still perceived as synonymous with excellence. Pininfarina continues to cooperate with a great number of automakers and has undertaken new collaborations expanding the range of business from automotive to boating, aeronautics, industrial design, interior design and architecture, as evidenced by the many recent successful projects in the United States, Latin America and Asia.

The global crisis occurred in the latest years, in particular to automotive industry, is an undeniable fact. However, the crisis did not hit only companies organized around families, as confirmed by the bankruptcy of giants like GM and Chrysler. Pininfarina has gone through difficult years as many others but continues on its path offering the world its interpretation of creativity, as borne out by the Gran Lusso created with BMW [right] and the acquisition of new customers from among the world's top ten car manufacturers.

Growth in the engineering sector has been achieved mostly in Germany and Asia, in particular in Japan and India. On the Italian market, important projects underway in collaboration with Ferrari and its Styling Centre are evidence of the strong, long-lasting ties between the two companies.
The era of coachbuilders as contract manufacturers is over. However, today Pininfarina continues to dedicate resources and talents to the creation of unique pieces.

Besides design, Pininfarina provides all-round support to automotive companies by engaging in a variety of activities: engineering, product development, testing, prototype construction. More generally, we do not share Mr. Cumberford’s opinion when he argues that "there is no longer any advantage for a company to go to Italian firms." Prestigious clients such as Ferrari and BMW continue to rely on Pininfarina’s creativity. The models on display in Geneva this year showcase the role of Pininfarina as the standard bearer for the aesthetic values of Italian design in the world and strengthen the brand, the firm's true distinctive character. The new Ferrari California T, together with the F12 berlinetta, the FF and many other recent projects, are part of a history that has generated the finest cars of all times through an evolution that started over 60 years ago and shows no sign of waning. And the Gran Lusso confirms our mission not only as global designers, but also as makers of exclusive high-quality cars.

Mr. Cumberford is right when he says that the era of coachbuilders as contract manufacturers is over. However, today Pininfarina continues to dedicate resources and talents to the creation of unique pieces, reinterpreting its artisan roots. The dream of the Ferrari Sergio [right] is becoming true for a few collectors thanks to Pininfarina skills and experience. At our style and engineering center in Cambiano we continue, as ever, to conceive, develop and manufacture one-off models and small series.

It's a job that is so noble and so peculiar to the Turin area. It is a return to our origins, to a niche that is fully keeping with our vision, our history. Pininfarina, in essence, is still a strategic partner with which the internal OEM styling centers continue to compete on all the proposed designs. Being considered a reference point in style is testified by the many awards received also in recent times, such as the 2012 Interior Design Award of the Year for the Cambiano, the Best Design Study 2013 for the Sergio, the GOOD DESIGN™ Award 2013 and German Design Award 2014 for the BMW Pininfarina Gran Lusso Coupè.

Despite the “de profundis” sung by Mr. Cumberford, Pininfarina is more alive than ever. We kindly invite your readers to follow us on www.pininfarina.com and www.facebook.com/PininfarinaSpA. There they will see how vital our company is. Thank you very much in advance for publishing this note.
Best regards. Pininfarina Communication Department

contributors.bio: Holly has reported on cars, lifestyle, travel, and everything else for publications including the New York Daily News, Redbook, Elite Traveler, and Fox TV. She lives in New York City with her family, including Jack, a toy poodle (and test driving partner!).

pageElements.text: Do you think that your commute is a grind? You’re not alone.

In a recent survey conducted by Ford Motor Company, polling 800 American adults who commute to work with their own vehicles or by carpool, almost half said they always or frequently encounter traffic while commuting.
The drivers described their commutes as frustrating, stressful, unpredictable, and long.  A note: 47 percent of the 800 respondents were women.
Ford wants to change this mind state with "The Pursuit of a Happy Commute," a campaign that examines how your commute affects well-being, relationships, mood, and money.  And what to do about it.

To ignite the initiative, the automaker invited us to a lunch/discussion in New York City, moderated by Catt Sadler of E! News (who is shown above), with Flywheel (spin) co-founder Ruth Zukerman and author/relationship expert Steve Santagati.
The findings:

1. Driving is eating up our free time.

Two-thirds of Americans spend at least thirty minutes commuting, which is more time than they are exercising.

The cure: The mind/body connection.

Make the extra effort to plug in exercise before or after your journey; you’ll feel so much better. Eating a healthy diet is key. Forgo fast foods, and check out Food Tripping, an app for Android and iOS developed by Ford and SHFT.com. It shows you a variety of healthy food resources, from farm-to-table restaurants and juice bars to fresh produce stands and organic grocery stores. Then, of course, there's planning ahead: I always keep wholesome snacks like nuts and raisins, whole-grain crackers, and apples in my glove compartment to keep me from getting too hungry.

2. Multitasking is common.

As the Ford survey shows, commuters do things other than drive while they're on the road. They listen to the news, radio, podcasts or e-books. Two out of five make personal or work-related phone calls, and nearly a quarter of commuters grab a snack or meal when on the road. Some even put on makeup or fix their hair (that would be me!).

The cure: Give yourself a break.

Try to stop multitasking in the car and get off the grid. To help commuters do this, Ford has developed a Do Not Disturb feature to block calls. The idea is to let you disconnect on the way home and thereby decrease your stress levels. If you don’t drive a Ford, you can just elect to turn off your phone. And if you’re going to listen to tunes, or if you find your blood boiling, put on some soothing spa tunes or classical music, or chill out to jazz.

3. Most of us don’t consider our commute a happy place.

More than half of commuters feel that their commute has little positive impact on their lives. They say that it takes away from: Maintaining a regular exercise routine and eating healthy Spending quality time with family and friends. Having personal interests or hobbies.

The cure: Navigate your way to a better result.

Avoid traffic jam headaches by using your nav system to dodge the gridlock. Check out alternative routes. Even if you drive more miles, you’ll get to where you’re going feeling less stressed.

And another cure: Change your attitude and put a smile on your face.

Catt Sadler lives in Los Angeles, where traffic jams burden each driver with an average of sixty-four wasted hours a year. That's on top of already heavy commute schedules. At the Ford meeting, she quipped: “Let’s think about collective happy commuting. Let someone pass, pay attention to your neighbor, and send them a small dose of “carma.”

One last reminder: Hands on the wheel, eyes on the road. Steve Santagati reminded us, “Never forget that you have thousands of pounds of steel under you. Your number-one priority is watching the road!”

subTitle: How to plan a great road trip using only apps and online resources. Look what I found on day 1!

metaTitle: Tour through Texas by (GMC) Terrain  - JeanKnowsCars.com
metaDescription: Tour through Texas: I relied on apps and online resources to plan a 1,300-mile road trip. Here's day 1: Crossing Texas. Read my story on JeanKnowsCars.com.

pageElements.text:
If you read A Teenager's First Road Trip last week, you know that I'm a high school junior and I was just given the privilege of being put in charge of planning a cross-country road trip with my mom. We're on that trip now, and here's how it's going:

Before beginning the 1,300-mile drive from Austin, Texas, to Ann Arbor, Michigan, my mom and I first spent the weekend in Austin with my aunt and uncle. We had picked up a brand-new 2014 GMC Terrain for our cushy ride. It proved to blend in well with all the other sport-utility vehicles and trucks in this trendy Texas town. As my aunt and uncle showed us their town, I paid attention to the differences in Texas driving from what I have experienced back home.

First of all, the traffic lights here are horizontal, rather than vertical. To me, this seemed outrageous and slightly mind-boggling. The next strange thing was the yield lane for turning right. Instead of having to stop at the light there is a separate lane to the far right where drivers slow down and then yield as they merge into traffic. In Michigan, you can turn right on red but you need to make a complete stop first. It seemed like this Texas turn worked to keep traffic moving.

The drivers in Texas are very courteous and actually follow the speed limit. I was shocked that people would not tailgate you on the highway to intimidate you to get out of their way. But the big surprise was the terrible traffic—apparently, Austin is ranked in the top five worst cities in the U.S. for traffic. To make the situation worse, there is road construction everywhere. Seriously, the entire time we drove around the city we could see signs of construction. The roads are in perfect condition, unlike the potholed streets that I have been learning to drive on at home.

These subtle differences are slightly unsettling. Add that to the fact that the entire route is brand-new to us, and we would need to follow the on-board navigator the entire time. I realized that it was important to pay extra special attention to road signs since we would not be familiar with the laws of the road in all of the states we would be driving through. But since I am riding shotgun for this trip, I can help my mom read signs and navigate through tricky situations.
The Terrain's center console was so deep that I was able to store our candy, chargers, camera, and even a small emergency kit inside with plenty of room left over.

The night before we left Austin, I organized the Terrain's cabin so that everything we needed was at our fingertips. The center console was so deep that I was able to store our candy, chargers, camera, and even a small emergency kit inside with plenty of room left over. I easily paired our phones via Bluetooth, which would let me be the DJ for the trip. My final job before we went to bed was to put the address for our first stop—Inner Space Cavern—into the navigation system. I was able to do it without having to look at the manual, which I bet few owners ever crack open.

Georgetown, Texas, and the Inner Space Cavern

This is the shortest day of our six-day adventure. The final destination was a room I booked through Airbnb in Dallas, but we first stopped to take a tour of the Inner Space Cavern in Georgetown just north of Austin. I found this attraction, as well as our other stops, on Roadtrippers.com.

What is the Inner Space Cavern? you ask. In 1963, the Texas Highway Department was drilling core samples to determine if the ground was stable enough to support a highway overpass over I-35. While they were drilling one of the test holes, the bit suddenly fell twenty-six feet, and that's how the cavern was discovered. The gift shop and ticket office looked like they were straight out of the Sixties, but once underground I was impressed. The tour guide was funny and informative. The tour took us on a one-mile loop, and at the very bottom we were more than seventy feet underground, and it was close to eighty degrees. Definitely worth the time and the $19.95-per-person fee. There is also a three-to-four-hour wild tour where you crawl through tiny spaces with only a light on a hard hat—no thank you.

As we continued on toward Dallas, we noticed how much Texans love their flag. We Michiganders may be smitten with the mitten, but the lone-star state has a love affair with the star. It is embossed on their new overpass stanchions, and it does look impressive. In fact, all of the Texas roads so far have been smooth and in near-perfect condition.

We made a quick stop at a rest area, and it not only had a playground but a storm shelter, which could be very helpful since we were driving through Tornado Alley. My mom had reminded me the night before we left to check the weather so that we wouldn’t have any surprises along the way.

As we drove toward Dallas, the speed limit was 75 mph, which allowed us to make great progress without breaking the law. Apparently there are also roads in Texas where the speed limit is as high as 85. My mom complained that the A-pillar was blocking her view, as she pointed out to me the part of the car where the roof attaches to the hood. I agreed that it did create a blind spot.

We listened to music via Pandora on my phone, played a whodunit game, and talked about college and my dream of getting a car of my own. The nav took us right to the door of the room we reserved through airbnb. It was located in a neighborhood that was slightly sketchy, and I realized that I should have explored the neighborhood with Google Earth. If I had, I probably would have passed on this spot. The neighborhood made me nervous, but since I was with my mom, I was okay. It was actually a cabin in the back yard of an art gallery that was super cute and artsy. We met the owner, Wanda, and she told us she had lived in the neighborhood for four years. Her calm demeanor put us at ease. But we did pull the car up into the empty yard next to the house to reduce the chance of bringing attention to the shiny new GMC.

A Perfect Little Park in Dallas

Once we unloaded our gear into our little cabin, we scheduled a ride through the Uber app to take us to Klyde Warren Park. It is a 5.2-acre park that is actually built over the highway. If I lived in Dallas, I think I would love to hang out in this park. It had an outside reading room that supplied books and magazines to read while in the park. There were games available such as ping-pong, foosball, and croquet, and there was even a putting green. It also had areas for dogs, fountains to play in, and a play area for kids. Shockingly, there were not many people in the park. After a few appetizers in an ultra-trendy restaurant called Savor, we took the Uber ride back to our cabin in the city and dead-bolted the door and hit the hay. In the morning, we're on our way to Hot Springs, Arkansas. More later!

subTitle: What this show means to New York, and the world. A preview.

contributors.bio: When people ask me how I started writing about cars, I tell them I'm from Detroit. I tell them about my father, who was a Chrysler engineer, and the crazy cars he would bring home to test drive. But before I discovered the glamorous life of an automotive journalist, I was a writer living in the Motor City, covering music and art in the Nineties. Things changed when I became curious about the industry that made the city tick and interned at AutoWeek magazine. I moved to New York City in 2003, where I’ve worked as a freelance writer for almost a decade. I’ve written for more than 100 magazines, newspapers, and websites, including the New York Times, Rolling Stone, Forbes, Jay-z’s Life and Times, Vibe, Automobile Magazine, AutoWeek and the Detroit Free Press. I finished an MFA in creative writing at the New School this year. I live with two car buffs, Lee Quiñones and our four-year-old son, who both think what I do is pretty cool.

pageElements.text: The New York Auto Show is the country’s oldest, most-well attended auto show. It's also proof that you don’t need to have a car—or even a driver’s license—to be intrigued by the promise of new car designs.

Only 23 percent of Manhattanites actually own a car. When the compass spreads to include all five boroughs, about 1.4 million out of 3 million households actually own a car. This is small potatoes compared with the rest of the country, where most households own and drive cars as a matter of necessity.

Cars in New York City clearly aren’t a matter of practicality, which makes them all the more appealing. It’s costly to park here, driving is often slower than taking the subway, and this spring the potholes are particularly atrocious. Drivers share the lanes with cabs, bike lanes, and pedestrians, none of whom think you’re as tough as they are—and will cut you off in your lane to prove it.
Automobiles are another stopping point on the culture calendar in a city that prides itself on insomnia. And brands are in competition to make their imprint.

However, what is considered rare is also a delicacy. Cars in New York capture the psychological appeal of exotic goods. Simply put: people are curious about what they don’t—but could—have. It’s part of why New Yorkers love a theme week, whether it’s fashion, films in Tribeca, or seasonal art auctions. Automobiles are another stopping point on the culture calendar in a city that prides itself on insomnia. And brands are in competition to make their imprint.

The most anticipated moment at the upcoming show is the unveiling of a Mustang that will hang over Manhattan. In the re-creation of a 1965 car stunt, the Ford Motor Company will hoist a 2014 Mustang to the top of the Empire State Building. The climb coincides with the pony car’s fiftieth anniversary and the New York Auto Show media preview days. And this year the show will feature several never-before-seen models: Dodge’s Challenger and Charger, the raring Mercedes-Benz S63 AMG, Subaru’s flagship Outback, a new Murano by Nissan, Toyota’s mid-cycle refresh of the Camry, and a slew of BMWs from the rip-roaring M4 to the X4. Attention in New York gives brands incentives to reserve space for splashy events at the city’s endless array of hot spots to woo producers and editors who often do not drive themselves.
New York City legitimizes the pulse of trends. It’s built on clichés about power, ambition, grit, and glamour, and most of these truisms hold up.

New York City legitimizes the pulse of trends. It’s built on clichés about power, ambition, grit, and glamour, and most of these truisms hold up. It helps that several luxury brands have their East Coast outposts here: Mercedes-Benz, Jaguar Land Rover, and BMW. Ford and General Motors both have New York City offices. Let’s not forget about Wall Streeters who work in New York but actually live in car-friendly Greenwich, Connecticut, where Porsche Cayennes are built for the average grocery getter.

For borough dwellers and Westchester County and Jersey drivers, the auto show is a reason to go to “the city.” Tri-staters love a reason to go the city. The New York Knicks don’t give much consistent incentive to their fans,  and the improved Javits Center is square in the heart of the West Side. The auto show is a sneak peek to the road of the future. And real New Yorkers know that everything comes to New York that matters, even if it doesn’t.
The New York International Auto Show press preview days are April 16 and 17. The show is open to the public from April 18–27.

title: 25th Anniversary Mazda Miata
subTitle: A quarter-century? Time does fly. While we wait for news of the all-new 2016 Miata, here's a treat.

metaDescription: 25th Anniversary Mazda Miata: A quarter-century? Time does fly. While we wait for news of the all-new 2016 Miata, here's a treat. Read about it on JeanKnowsCars.com.

pageElements.text: I still remember the buzz around the offices of Automobile Magazine when the first Mazda MX-5 Miata arrived, prior to being named Automobile of the Year for 1990 ("Lemiata here," exclaimed one editor, the minute the keys were handed to him), and it’s hard to believe that has been twenty-five years already. But, yep, it has. This 2015 Mazda Miata 25th Anniversary Edition proves that time flies. And so can the 100 buyers of this limited-edition model, which will be on sale before summer.

The roadster was unveiled at the New York Auto Show, partly slaking the thirst of people wanting to know more about the all-new Miata coming for 2016. This is the last hurrah for the third-generation Miata before then. All 100 copies will be sold in Soul Red Metallic. The contrasting color is black, including on the power retractable hard top. Six-speed manual or automatic transmission versions will be available, with the manual versions equipped with Bilstein dampers as standard. Mazda trumpeted the fact that individual engine components have been selected by hand for each copy of the 25th Anniversary Miata: a nice touch.
More easily visible to the passer-by is 25th Anniversary badge with serial number, located on the driver’s front fender.

Inside, the seats and door trim are almond-colored leather, matched to piano black steering wheel spokes, a black seat back, and leather on the steering wheel, shift lever, armrests, and parking brake handle. All get contrasting red stitching. The drilled aluminum pedals are worth noting as well.

contributors.bio: Holly has reported on cars, lifestyle, travel, and everything else for publications including the New York Daily News, Redbook, Elite Traveler, and Fox TV. She lives in New York City with her family, including Jack, a toy poodle (and test driving partner!).

pageElements.text: The 2015 Honda Fit is already out, as we showed you last week, and now it’s joined by an all-new compact SUV, the Fit-based HR-V. Well, sort of. We saw photos, but no actual vehicle, at the New York Auto Show this week.
Not to worry, because this HR-V is definitely going to be seen a lot once it goes on sale next winter.

The new HR-V is to be assembled alongside the Fit at a purpose-built new plant in Mexico, and both models are huge for the Honda brand in North America. And since, as Honda senior vice-president and general manager Jeff Conrad points out, the Fit has the most brand-loyal customers of any Honda product, there will probably be a lot of people ready to look kindly on the new HR-V.

“Great things can come in small packages,” Conrad said. Is this going to be great? Let’s consider. It has the same clever packaging as the Fit, which has surprising amounts of interior space thanks to its center gas-tank layout and easy-folding Magic Seat. One hint about its looks: It will have hidden rear door handles, for what Honda terms a sportier appearance.

This is a smaller SUV than the already not huge CR-V; you may remember the size of it as shown in this Urban SUV Concept (right), which was displayed at the Detroit Auto Show in January 2013. Want to see it posed right next to the Fit, for size comparisons? Us, too. Soon!
Other details will just have to wait, but since the 2014 CR-V starts just under $24,000, expect this smaller version to have a very interesting price to go with its new look.

title: What Future for Maserati?
subTitle: CEO Harald J. Wester talks to Automobile Magazine's Jamie Kitman about the brand's transformation.
promoTeaserSmall: CEO Harald J. Wester talks to Automobile Magazine's Jamie Kitman about the brand's transformation.
promoTeaser: CEO Harald J. Wester talks to Automobile Magazine's Jamie Kitman about the brand's transformation.
metaKeywords: Maserati North America CEO Peter M. Grady
metaDescription: What Future for Maserati? CEO Harald J. Wester and Maserati North America CEO Peter M. Grady talk Ghibli, Quattroporte, and more with Automobile Magazine's Jamie Kitman. Read the story on JeanKnowsCars.com.

contributors.bio: Jamie Kitman, a lawyer and rock band manager, contributed to Automobile Magazine in its first year, when its editor bought a story he'd swritten while in law school, about attending a Volvo market research session in Boston. "Earn $75 if you thought about buying a Volvo and didn't" the classified ad that changed his life read. After several years freelancing, he became a columnist for Automobile Magazine in 1991 and has now written more than 200 columns as well as numerous features for the periodical, in the process becoming its New York Bureau Chief. In 2009, Kitman won a National Magazine Award, the "Ellie," for three columns on the collapse of Detroit, marking the first time a car magazine had ever won an NMA. Earlier, he won the IRE Medal for Investigative Magazine Reporting for his in-depth review of the history of leaded gasoline for The Nation, a subject about which he is writing a book for Simon & Schuster, as well as several other IAMA awards. A frequent contributor to GQ, The New York Times, Foreign Affairs and other publications, he writes blogs for NPR's Car Talk and Yahoo! The father of three children, (one of whom is named Ellie,) Kitman's musical clients, as president of The Hornblow Group USA, include OK Go, They Might Be Giants, Mike Doughty, Mike Viola, Moon Hooch and Vandaveer. Former clients have included Violent Femmes, The La's, Meat Puppets, Pere Ubu, Edwyn Collins, Beautiful South, Trashcan Sinatras and Yo La Tengo. He lives in a rivertown not far from Manhattan, where he keeps company with, yes, you read it right, thirty old cars.

pageElements.text: Maserati’s only debut at the 2014 New York Auto Show was a pair of special-edition cars, but that doesn’t mean the Italian brand is resting on its laurels. We sat down with Harald J. Wester, CEO of Maserati, as well as Maserati North America president and CEO Peter M. Grady, to learn what’s next for Maserati.

Peter M. Grady: The Ghibli (shown here) is our first entry into this attainable price range. We’re pretty pleased with where we are so far. We’ve got a fair amount of growth to go in a number of markets. But if you go into New York, south Florida, L.A., our traditional markets, it’s been very well accepted. This is our opportunity to reach in to a number of consumers who would never even think about Maserati before.
Automobile Magazine: How do you reach those people?

PG: A bunch of different ways. We have our traditional ride and drive events, getting people into the car – these cars really do sell themselves. But we’re reaching into the digital side of the business, we’re doing a little bit of TV after the Super Bowl. The Super Bowl ad put us on the charts. The awareness we got off of that Super Bowl ad was spectacular. It spiked awareness. And the beautiful thing is, we’ve maintained that level of awareness. Really a watershed for Maserati here. We’re running now in some of the key luxury markets a cutdown, bookended by fifteen seconds on either side. Where it’s a version of that ad, with the same feel and texture. We’re on news and sports programs with it, that’s really where the demographic is. We’re getting a lot of good traffic in the showrooms. People are loving the car.
Automobile: Who’s looking at your car?

PG: If you’re a [Mercedes-Benz] E-Class driver at $499 a month and you walk into a Maserati showroom, you’re generally blown away by what you see. And you’re probably not as much of an enthusiast or an aficionado as what we would normally get. And those kind of people are discovering the brand and they’re trying to decide if they fit it. Then you’ve got some legitimate [BMW] 6-Series, 5-Series, [Mercedes] AMG types that come in and they’re converted. They’re loving the vehicles.
Automobile: How are you feeling about the volume so far?

PG: It’s good, we’re not satisfied, and we’ve got a way to go, how’s that?

I’m not that interested in talking about volumes; traditionally, we don’t. We’re trying to become a player in this segment, so if we can be legitimate competitor and sell legitimate volume in that sports sedan segment then we’ll be pretty pleased.

Automobile: There was the idea, fomented by Mercedes in the 1990s in my view, that you need to sell a million cars to have sufficient economies of scale. But then you see a Jaguar Land Rover, who sell a fraction of the volume, but manage to make money and deliver a very credible product. You seem to be following much more in JLR’s footsteps, as far as volume goes, and having driven it there’s no doubt Ghibli is credible, yet it too is a relatively low volume enterprise. Of course, for exclusivity, actually being exclusive has to beat saying you’re exclusive, while selling a million or more examples of similar cars. But as a manufacturing and business proposition, can you speak to making money at these lower volumes? Maserati would be happy to sell 50,000 cars.

Harald J. Wester: Yes. If you look back to 2012, from the old QP [Quattroporte], Gran Turismo, and Gran Cabrio, we sold 6,200 cars globally. Now we have a new architecture, new engines, two new cars which we’ve launched. I can’t talk too much about the future – the SUV is on its way and will be ready Oct ’15, early ’16. As with any dogmatic statements, there are a lot of “buts” and “ifs” around it. If you talk about the extremely competitive mass-volume market, I think a million is a good number. We’re in a totally different business. The future of Maserati – and we sold 15,400 cars last year, 50 percent in the last quarter thanks to Quattroporte and Ghibli – we are going to make a significant step towards the 50,000 goal. Without making a precise number, I expect our global sales this year to be beyond 35,000. Obviously, the U.S. is an important portion. For the time being I expect it to remain. China has become a very important market for the Quattroporte. For the time being, it outsells Ghibli there. Totally different demographics than the rest of the world. Forty percent female. Average age: below forty.
PG: This is the demographic that everybody for twenty years has been chasing. In China, they’re buying the cars.

HW: So the answer is yes. We are making and always make money at volumes far lower than a million and the new Maserati, with more products and shared components and drivetrains, makes us well-equipped to compete.
Automobile: A V-6 engine is likely to show up in the forthcoming SUV (called the Maserati Levante). Will it be shared with Alfa Romeo, as well?

HW: No. We believe that you need to have – in this range of iconic brands and products – there are ingredients (like a well-functioning multi-media system) which just need to be properly adapted and work well, not creating problems, perfect function. And there are distinctive elements – for us it’s engines, transmissions, how the car drives, how it looks, the materials (there is no Maserati with fabric seats) and so on. So there is no intention to share this engine [with Alfa].
PG: You don’t mess with the soul of the brand.

Automobile: Describe the interplay between Alfa Romeo and Maserati. There was much grumbling among Fiat dealers when it was revealed Maserati dealers would be selling the Alfa 4C sports car, which they said they’d been promised, along with the rest of the coming U.S. Alfa line-up.
HW: We will reveal this May 6.
Automobile: I’d keep Ferrari and Maserati together and let the Fiat dealers have Alfa. That makes sense to me.

HW: There are some critical issues within a combination of Ferrari and Maserati –particularly with the Ghibli and maybe the entry-level QP – you are entering a new business. You have a lot of customers trading in cars.

PG: It’s not an order-taking business any longer. You have to have a legitimate used car business, you have to understand the customer needs that are different than what they are for the Ferrari owner.

The Ghibli opens up quite a bit of the U.S market for us. It’s a huge segment. Where maybe we didn’t have a lot of demand opportunity, now we do. So we’re expanding, we’ll be somewhere around 120 dealers in the U.S. at the end of this calendar year, up from seventy-four at the start of the year. And it’s not just a simple densification in some of these markets, it’s places that really have a large segment that we can hit. Some places you may not think of, but we’re underserved in the energy sector – Oklahoma City, Dallas, Houston we need expansion. There’s places like that we’re going into right now, where we’ve got some really solid dealers that have come to us and said ‘I like where this brand is going, can I be a part of it?’

We’re primarily going for standalone [dealers]. We’re not going into small markets where the business can’t stand on its own two feet. Separating from all the other brands because we really think we’ve got the product line. We’re requiring building a new showroom and we’re assuming that for the time being they’ll do some dedicated service at an existing location, we’ll dedicate technicians and stalls, then as the business grows…
Cross-shopping has been very positive for us. There are some fantastic dealers out there that really understand the space and Maserati is on their radar.
The new Maserati customer? The people who really love driving the car. There is a simplicity in driving the car; it’s more visceral than just transportation.
Automobile: Psychographics of the new Maserati customer?

PG: It’s real enthusiasts. The people who really love driving the car. There is a simplicity in driving the car where it’s more visceral than just transportation. If you go on the blogs, our target is exactly who seems to be buying the cars.

HW: From 1998 to 2002, I was the head of product development for the road cars at Ferrari. And that was the time that we were working on the fifth-generation Quattroporte of 2003. I left Ferrari in early 2002, then went to Magna – the first time I worked for a supplier after fifteen years with VW/Audi and then Ferrari – and then I came back in early 2004 and took charge of the QP. The first thing we did after some reorganization and Fiat product development was to fix the product issues with Maserati and then I took over the helm for [Maserati] in 2007. It took us seven or eight years to earn the right to go to the next level. (Shown here: 2014 Quattroporte.)
Automobile: We have heard the upcoming Maserati SUV is no longer on the Grand Cherokee platform and instead will rely on the pieces developed for Ghibli and Quattroporte.

HW: It’s a good thing for the brand. Technically it’s a little bit more tricky but we have fixed it. We won’t go to a million cars, but obviously sharing engines, transmissions, within the family is helpful from a cost perspective. It’s more an issue of the purity of the brand. It was both. It was component related. But it was also, we didn’t have a place to produce the car in Italy when the car was first discussed – it’s a big car, the dimensions of the body shop [were insufficient. But] we sorted it out. And for the purity of the brand, the credibility of the product, being 100% Maserati, it was always clear that it would be much better on something that is 100% Maserati.
Automobile: Which competitor is in your rearview mirror?
We won’t go to a million cars, but sharing engines, transmissions, within the family is helpful from a cost perspective. It’s more an issue of the purity of the brand.

HW: We are competing with the real big guys. Sometimes it seems to me they have infinite resources, each and every piece of technology. Nevertheless, there are significant points where we distinguish ourselves. We have a clear strategy, a good understanding of what Maserati stands for and it is pretty much in line to our story the absolute opposite of volume. Offering a real alternative, how you say, in this sea of sameness…It seems to me, you work in New York City, you leave your workplace, you take the metro train home, I think if you would reprogram their remote controls, the people squeezing the buttons, they would open just another, black, whatsoever car and drive home without even recognizing that they are sitting in the wrong seat.
Automobile: Volkswagen’s about to unleash new high-end SUVs from Porsche, Audi, Lamborghini, and Bentley. Does that mean that we can expect a Ferrari SUV one day soon?
HW: I don’t want to talk for Ferrari. But the answer is “no.”
